story:
Short Summary

San Pedro La Laguna is a beautiful town on Lake Atitlan in Guatemala however there are many areas in town and also by the lake that are covered with rubbish.

We need funds to set up a good waste management system to keep the town clean and tidy.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds for:

  • Having rubbish picked up and taken to disposal facilities
  • Purchasing and installing rubbish bins
  • Employing people to clean rubbish
  • Designing and printing flyers
  • Educating children and people on environmental issues
  • Potential equipment for removing rubbish from the lake itself
  • General cleaning equipment
  • Rewarding the community for helping to pick up the rubbish

You will get public recognition on our website for helping us to help the environment and if you ever visit San Pedro (or already live here) you will enjoy the benefits of a cleaner lake, cleaner streets and cleaner nature.

The Impact

Currently the waste management in San Pedro is not capable of keeping the streets, lake and area properly clean. The local people bathe daily in the lake amongst the rubbish. We felt something needed to be done. We would like to set up a system where locals can be paid an above average wage to help keep their town clean. We will also utilise volunteer tourists and local children.

Keeping the town clean will not only be a beautiful experience for the locals and tourists but also for the plants and wildlife that live here.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in San Pedro La Laguna yourself, please come along to one of our rubbish pick up sessions!

Like Us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/KeepSanPedroBeautiful

If you run a local business here, help to spread the word.

story:
Eco-Houses for Hope

Gordon Fuller is raising funds for SiKanda's project to build Eco-Houses for the people who who live and work on the landfill rubbish dump at Oaxaca, Mexico.  He intends to complete a  cross-country ski marathon (42 km), in the Engadin Valley, Switzerland, on March 10thhaving never taken part in any long distance event.  Each house costs GBP 4000, which means that he has to raise GBP 95 / Euro 120 per kilometre in the marathon to pay for just one house.

SiKanda is a non-profit organisation that has been working with at-risk communities in Oaxaca since 2008.  It works to improve the lives of the Pepenadores who live and work at the landfill site. The Pepenadores (informal trash pickers) live in shacks with no sanitation and work 10 hours daily, 7 days a week, earning approximately 40 pesos a day (GBP 2).  SiKanda provides employment and works to improve the lives of the Pepenadores and the city's slum dwellers by:

  1. Assisting the Pepenadores to build high quality, durable eco-homes that have been designed to make use of conventional and recycled materials.
  2. Improving the health and education of the Pepenadores by providing suitable protective equipment and teaching them basic hygiene.
  3. Collecting rubbish that would be burned or dumped on the streets of the slums and compost the organic material.  The compost is sold or used for growing vegetables. (SiKanda's 2012 Worm Power project)
  4. Creating awareness in society about the harsh conditions and the extreme poverty of families living in slums and working as informal rubbish pickers.

 

The Project “Eco-houses for Hope”

SiKanda has built seven houses between 2009 and 2012 and aims to build a further five this year. 

SiKanda volunteers will work with each Pepenador family to build a new, decent home in just seven days. The project creates a bond between those families who live at the dump and the people of the city who help them to clear the land and build the houses.

Each house uses approximately 5000 recycled plastic bottles and 4000 TetraPak milk/juice cartons together with conventional timber, cement and roofing materials to a design that guarantees durability and security. 

 

The impact of this project

A family of six will benefit from each house.

5000 recycled plastic bottles and 4000 TetraPak cartons will be used for the construction of each house.

Over 50 volunteers from local schools and institutions will participate in the construction together with 60 Pepenadores.

For each house built, a family will save GBP 25 every month thanks to the Eco-House (1/3 of their income is used to cover health and housing expenses).

The Pepenador community as a whole will benefit from better sanitation, health and reduced housing repair costs.

You can see and learn more about SiKanda's activities by visiting our website:

www.si-kanda.org

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell your friends, family and co-workers about SiKanda's important work with the families who live in the slums of Mexico. You can create awareness for our programs, host a party or organize a fund-raising event of your own to help us.

Together, we can continue our mission towards a fair and just world! 

 

Gordon lives in Cambridgeshire, England, where snow is rare.  He is using roller-skis to train on a cycle route beside the guided busway from St Ives to Cambridge.

story:
About this campaign

This campaign is being run by the Toledo Institute for Development and Environment (TIDE), a Belizean non-profit conservation and development NGO (http://tidebelize.org).

We recently launched a new conservation volunteer program called Ridge to Reef Expeditions (http://www.fromridgetoreef.com/).

Ridge to Reef Expeditions will give international volunteers conservation experience and enable TIDE to conserve one of the most pristine parts of Mesoamerica.

We are about to launch our first ever expedition in July 2014. We have five international participants and we are seeking funding for a free place for a Belizean – Javier Alegria.

 

Javier Alegria, pictured here with his nephew, wants the opportunity to protect biodiversity in his native Toledo for future generations.


Letter from Javier

“My name is Javier Alegria and I am from the beautiful Toledo district of southern Belize. Toledo is filled with diverse ecosystems and amazing wildlife, from mountaintop rainforests to coral reefs, from tapirs to sea turtles.

Since I was a boy, I have been fascinated with nature. It makes me mad to see ancient trees being torn down and jaguars shot, so I decided to do something. I decided to study Natural Resource Management at the University of Belize.

Studying biology has given me the profound realization that all living things are interdependent and that we must give back to our environment, not just take take take.

It would mean the world to me to take part in Ridge to Reef Expeditions. I would use the experience and skills I learn to give back to my community as a teacher or a conservation biologist.

Please help me fulfil my dream. I promise to write you about my experience, and give back to my country by protecting this amazing place I am proud to call home.”

The Belize Barrier Reef is a "World Heritage Site in Danger". Photo credit: Jad Davenport.


What we need and what you get

We need $6,000 to send Javier on the expedition of a lifetime. This breaks down as follows:

$4,500 course fees (includes food, accommodation, travel to field sites, training, and SCUBA certification for the 8-week expedition)

$500 medical and dive insurance

$500 wetsuit, hiking boots and head light for expedition

$400 Indiegogo fee

$100 to fulfil our perks

In return, TIDE and Javier will show our appreciation by sharing a video of the expedition, highlighting the adventure, biodiversity and learning that our young participants experience. Javier will also write you a letter describing his personal journey.

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will still take Javier on expedition - just for less than the full eight weeks.

On a Ridge to Reef Expedition, Javier will learn to SCUBA dive and monitor coral reef health among many other skills.


Reasons to support Javier

·      He was the most passionate and promising candidate in a competitive application

·      It is his dream to protect the amazing Toledo District and Belize Barrier Reef

·      On a Ridge to Reef Expedition, he will meet like-minded international volunteers and take action to protect endangered turtles, manatees, jaguars, yellow-headed parrots, monkeys, corals, and more

·      He plans to stay in Toledo for the long term

 

Training locals in conservation makes sense because they are here for the long term. Here, TIDE community researcher Fernando relocates a hawksbill turtle nest that would have been lost to beach erosion.

On this summer's expedition, Javier and the other volunteers will participate in the first ever manatee survey of its kind in southern Belize.


Reasons to support TIDE

·      TIDE is a leading Belizean NGO that co-manages two national protected areas with the Government of Belize

·      TIDE works with communities to build environmental stewardship

·      TIDE has a strong track record in implementing projects

·      TIDE has won international awards for innovation

·      Ridge to Reef Expeditions is a non-profit initiative that will support TIDE to achieve its conservation objectives

Your support will make Javier as happy as this bottlenose dolphin in the Port Honduras Marine Reserve, co-managed by TIDE.


Follow TIDE on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/TIDEBZE

Live your own adventure - join us on a Ridge to Reef Expedition (http://fromridgetoreef.com).

story:
"A solution for the planet"


The Monkey Bubble House:

-Doesn't hurt the homes trees, the trees will never outgrow it!

-Built without screws or nails!

-It is 100% portable!

-Mimics the natural environment of primates. "eee eee ooo ooo ahh ahh"

-Can be made with everything from junkyard to space grade materials.

-Uses multiple repeating iterations of very simple architecture, making it highly upgradable!

-Theoretically self cleaning.

-Theoretically affordable to build and efficient to heat.

How it's made:

The FLT-1(Fully Livable Treehouse 1) aka, "Monkey Bubble House" is made from 3 parts: The Body, The Web, and the Wings.

The Body consists of a number of hexagon "frames" that crescendo and decrescendo in diameter according to PHI, 1.618 (aka the "Golden Ratio" found in biological geometry).

These hexagon frames are then transposed onto one another at the Fibonacci Spiral (137.5 degrees).

FLOOR: Any frame hexagon can hang a floor called the "Iris", which is a hexagonal joist that provides a floor with a central porthole. This porthole can be dilated to any diameter. 

This floor is connected to the frame with carabiners, so the floor can be 'unclipped' and raised or lowered to any level.

The Joints of the prototype frames are then connected by carabiners, I-bolts and rope. (In proceeding models, stainless steel cable will be used)

This geometric design seems to be incredibly strong(and has held 15+ people for ~1 hour), but its' minimum breaking force remains unknown.

 

-MISSIONS:

-To load test a 1 level MBH using barrels of water.

-Make a 2 person, "Glamping" model available for purchase.

-To make the frame of the FLT (Fully Livable Treehouse) strong enough to carry more people than it can fit, shock loaded to a factor of 10.  

-To complete the first fully livable prototype

-To beta test the first line of FLT's in order to research any unknown safety variables.

-ULTIMATE MISSION: To begin building treehouse villages and cities, incorporating our homes into the biosphere as a mitigation for climate crises... and because it's freakin' cool.

SIDING for glamping model? In an initial glamping model, I would like to test a softshell of Gabion mesh(a high guage chicken wire used in rock retaining walls) and a system of macro and micro shingles, (both opaque and translucent) will be tied to the structure, like the breathable & waterproof feathers of a duck. 

For winterized models, I want to test a set of insulated wings that can fold down during cold weather, and open during warm weather, like an upside down lotus flower.

Just like the desktop computer, the Monkey Bubble House can be upgraded substantially. You can add many frames and floors together to make it bigger.

The FLT 1, aka "Monkey Bubble House", is made by borrowing 12 concepts from nature, also known as Biomimicry Architecture:

1)Alder Leaf- 120/60/120 degree Floor design

I asked, "How can I create a floor that is simple, using multiple repeating iterations and cleans itself."

 I examined the leaves of the red alder tree, and discovered that most of the veins intersect the central stem at 120 degree angles, which are the angles found in a hexagon. These leaves also have a ridge that prevents them from collecting dust and water.

2) Milk Thistle- Rigging segmentation & Speed of hoisting.

I remember when I was a kid, sitting in my mom's garden, I saw a Milk Thistle plant grow 2 feet tall in 2 days. I thought to myself "why can't we build houses that quickly?"

The Milk thistle plant can grow larger very quickly because their leaves are pre-formed inside a sheathe, with individual segments that open up like a beach umbrella.

The Monkey Bubble House is not held together by 6 long cords, but rather, 72+ individual cords between each segment. This allows for greater safety (if one several cords break, the structure will always hold), and it allows the structure to open quickly and smoothly.

3) Honey Bee- The Hexagon is a shape that can be tessellated and presents the highest volume-circumference ratio. In Other words, the largest rooms, with the least amount of building materials.

 

4) Orb Weaver Spider- THE WEB (fractal weight diffusion system)

"How can we create tree houses that don't hurt the trees?"

A spider web will never hurt the grass or vegetation it connects to. The Orb Weaver spider diffuses the weight of its' web over a wide area for maximum strength and safety. Individual strands of silk will often fan out at the ends when connecting to their environment. So I designed a "collar" system that spreads the weight evenly over a wide area, using large loops, so the tree can never outgrow its' collar.  

"Hexa-fractal" collars diffuse the weight to less than 1.15lbs per square inch, which is lighter than the weight of a birds nest resting on the home tree. 

 5) Lotus Flower- insulated Wings designed to pull in like a marionette during cold weather. 

 Lotus "Wings" open when warm, close when cold. 

 6) Sunflower- Fibonacci spiral  

 7) Fig-Bottom symmetrical entry. What is the best way to enter a fig shaped structure? Ask the fig wasp! 

8 )Duck Feathers - Micro & Macro shingle design.

Duck feathers are waterproof, insulated, self cleaning, breathable, and extremely light. Each feather is shaped like an elongated oval.

I asked "how can I make a shingle system that is 100% portable and breathable?" 

 

Hexagonal shingles positioned with the corner pointed down are 100% waterproof, while using 17.5% less material, allowing the structure to be lighter.

10) Mammalian Iris- Contracted & dilated floor frame design.

Can contract and dilate like the eye of a mammal.

11) Natural environment of Primates- Jungle Gym

Primates often spend a % of their day hanging from their hands in the branches of trees, which decompresses their lower spine. Studies have shown that 85% of adult homo sapiens experience lower back problems at some point in their life. . . but the Monkey Bubble House mimics the natural environment of primates!

 

12) Stem cells- Transform-ability of frame components. Many parts of the FLT-1 can be switched into another area, and multiple Monkey Bubble Houses can combine to make bigger ones.

Economics

-FLT's (Fully Livable Treehouses) are free of concrete foundations, making them potentially more economical than ground houses.

-Can be built without clearing land.

-Circular structures facilitate heat convection, making them faster & more economical to heat.

-Hexagons and spheres allow the largest rooms, with the least amount of building materials. (due to the mathematical laws of Isoperimetric inequality).

-The desire for minimum weight burden on the tree encourages an efficiency of building materials. 

-Monkey Bubble Houses can be built from simple, multiple repeating iterations of the simple architecture.

-Can be built from junkyard materials to space-grade materials(like unfabricated titanium piping).

Environment

-FLT's are built into the biosphere, promoting a healthy climate.

 -Puts economic value on living Oldgrowth Forests

-The Monkey Bubble House is built with weight diffusion collars, allowing it to not hurt the Home Trees.

-Suspended structures free land for animals and permiculture.

-Homo Sapiens can enter into a symbiotic relationship with their home tree by providing human music, water, nitrogen(from their urine) and pruning.

Human Health/Hygiene

-The Monkey Bubble House is built like a jungle gym with multiple levels to climb around, making it an ideal fitness party for homo-sapiens!

 A hammock in a Monkey Bubble House functions like a gyroscope.

-Convection of a circular structure inhibits mold, making a healthy breathing environment!

-Playing music for Home Trees can encourage their growth. (4)

-In 2007 & 2013, it was scientifically proven that being in the very presence of ancient trees and forests can lower a persons blood pressure, and increases the immune system.(2)(3)

-Hygiene: half-moon floor structure is self cleaning because dirt rolls through the halfmoons; you can clean your Monkey Bubble House by jumping.

Portability/Upgradability

-The FLT-1 is 100% portable!

-Can fit a FLT-1 frame in the back of a small truck.

-Very fast to assemble & take down.

-The FLT-1 is highly up-gradable, adding more frame hexagons, going from a fig shape, to a pineapple, to a banana.

-Move the floors up and down as you like.

 Sketch of a "typical" FLT-1 frame. 

Safety:

SO far, the FLT 1 has a perfect safety record and has held up to 15 humans at once. Safety is the first priority moving forward.

Prototypes will be load tested and any weaknesses will be researched. 

Future models may use stainless steel cables, and high grade carabiners and rigging components.

Titanium, aluminum & steel pipes may be used..

-The Hexagonal compression dynamics suggest a high strength to weight ratio.

-The Fibonacci spiral, allows no joint to ever align with another joint, making them stacked like bricks.

-Uniform weight distribution: The floor joist hangs from the supporting hexagonal frame by carabiners so wherever you step, your weight is distributed evenly around the structure.

GOALS & COSTS:

DID YOU KNOW? This project has come to life exclusively through the sales of firewood.

For safety reasons, all future FLT's will use the highest grade components (carabiners, shackles etc.) available.

Typical requirements of a 2-3 storey Monkey Bubble House frame (Not including labour, logs, tools, fuel and arbourist work):

  • 36 small harness collars    
  • 72 high grade carabiners  
  • 6 big harness cables        
  • 6 small Weldless Steel rings 
  • 3 big Weldless Steel rings 
  • 1 Swivel crane Hook (rated for 11 tons)          
  • 3 big anchor shackles        
  • 108 medium-small shackles    
  • 108 forged I-bolts      
  • 36 stainless steel cables of 'x' length
  • 36 stainless steel cables of 'y' length
  • 500 Man Hours

$4000 would help: 

Load test a 1 level frame using barrels of water.

This will require xyz# of water barrels, a 1000 gallon water tank (I can put on my firewood truck and park at a higher level), a hose, 6 sturdy home trees outside the city, (possible) cherry picker rental, assembly labour, fuel, arbourist work, and misc.

Once it is load tested, it can become available for purchase in BC.

$10 000 would help:

-complete the first "glamping" (glamour camping) prototype with steel cables, high grade components, and siding.

$60 000 would help:

-Complete the first FULLY LIVABLE TREEHOUSE, with plumbing & electrical, and all the comforts of a ground house.

$1 Octillion dollars would help:

  • Engineering
  • Research & development
  • Wind Testing, wind mitigation/deflection systems & research
  • Fibonacci Spiral Staircase
  • Speaker system to play music for our Home Trees.
  • Designs for wheelchair access + experimental moneypower
  • FLT Training center + Licences
  • Live Tree Rentals for FLT research
  • Giant steel tripod for safety testing
  • Custom 120 degree steel timberframe joints
  • Space grade titanium designs
  • Arbourist & tree climbing gear
  • Experimental Moneypower.
  • Water barrels for testing the minimum breaking forces
  • Fuel
  • Monkey Bubble House Production line
  • Tools, both known & unknown 
  • Photography & Media production 
  • Interior design & aesthetics
  • Indiegogo Rewards 
  • Indiegogo fees
  • Taxes.
  • Diesel Generators
  • Labour costs
  • Custom Yurt fabric design
  • Gabion Mesh design
  • Snow Mesh design
  • Custom Hexagonal Shingles
  • Reflective Insulation
  • Marionette Wing System +Experimental Moneypower
  • Funnel cone for water catchment
  • Rocket stoves, fractal chimney & heated showers.
  • Plumbing
  • Electrical
  • Solar power wings
  • Website for Crowdsourced FLT Evolution platform - "FLTlaboratory.com"
  • Begin development of the "FLT 2" (which I already have designs for!)
  • +Experimental Moneypower.
  • Helicopter delivery to remote pre-colonial forest locations.
  • Giant speaker system for playing music through the forest (yes, I already said that)
  • Plexiglass tunnel system floating through the forests.

REWARDS:

Your Pledge rewards amounts are Fibonacci numbers!

Our rewards maximize the relationship with our backers, and reduces mailing labour in order to maximize our time & Money towards production. 

Scholarly References:

(1) http://summitcountyvoice.com/2012/02/03/study-deforestation-may-lead-to-drought/

(2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2793346/

(3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17903349

(4) http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/107555304322849039
story_txt:
"A solution for the planet"The Monkey Bubble House:-Doesn't hurt the homes trees, the trees will never outgrow it!-Built without screws or nails!-It is 100% portable!-Mimics the natural environment of primates. "eee eee ooo ooo ahh ahh"-Can be made with everything from junkyard to space grade materials.-Uses multiple repeating iterations of very simple architecture, making it highly upgradable!-Theoretically self cleaning.-Theoretically affordable to build and efficient to heat.How it's made:The FLT-1(Fully Livable Treehouse 1) aka, "Monkey Bubble House" is made from 3 parts: The Body, The Web, and the Wings.FLT 1- "Body, Web, Wings"Typical FLT 1 frame, in a grove of ~50 year old Home Trees. (Braeden standing below)
"Non-merchantible timber" The Monkey Bubble House is made from 10 year old trees. Salvaged from burn piles on a Vancouver Island clearcut. Millions of these logs are burned every year.
The Body consists of a number of hexagon "frames" that crescendo and decrescendo in diameter according to PHI, 1.618 (aka the "Golden Ratio" found in biological geometry).
These hexagon frames are then transposed onto one another at the Fibonacci Spiral (137.5 degrees).

(Above) Hexagons crescendo in diameter according to the Golden Ratio, and (below) are Transposed onto each other at the Golden Ratio (drawn by eye, not to scale)

Floors can be added at every 2nd frame hexagon.
FLOOR: Any frame hexagon can hang a floor called the "Iris", which is a hexagonal joist that provides a floor with a central porthole. This porthole can be dilated to any diameter. 
This floor is connected to the frame with carabiners, so the floor can be 'unclipped' and raised or lowered to any level.
The Joints of the prototype frames are then connected by carabiners, I-bolts and rope. (In proceeding models, stainless steel cable will be used)
This geometric design seems to be incredibly strong(and has held 15+ people for ~1 hour), but its' minimum breaking force remains unknown.
 
-MISSIONS:
-To load test a 1 level MBH using barrels of water.
-Make a 2 person, "Glamping" model available for purchase.
-To make the frame of the FLT (Fully Livable Treehouse) strong enough to carry more people than it can fit, shock loaded to a factor of 10.  
-To complete the first fully livable prototype
-To beta test the first line of FLT's in order to research any unknown safety variables.
-ULTIMATE MISSION: To begin building treehouse villages and cities, incorporating our homes into the biosphere as a mitigation for climate crises... and because it's freakin' cool.
SIDING for glamping model? In an initial glamping model, I would like to test a softshell of Gabion mesh(a high guage chicken wire used in rock retaining walls) and a system of macro and micro shingles, (both opaque and translucent) will be tied to the structure, like the breathable & waterproof feathers of a duck. 
For winterized models, I want to test a set of insulated wings that can fold down during cold weather, and open during warm weather, like an upside down lotus flower.
Just like the desktop computer, the Monkey Bubble House can be upgraded substantially. You can add many frames and floors together to make it bigger.

4 storey Monkey Bubble House. (It's actually 2 Monkey Bubble Houses merged together)

Top view of the Monkey Bubble House, Showing the Fibonacci spiral.
The FLT 1, aka "Monkey Bubble House", is made by borrowing 12 concepts from nature, also known as Biomimicry Architecture:
1)Alder Leaf- 120/60/120 degree Floor design
I asked, "How can I create a floor that is simple, using multiple repeating iterations and cleans itself."

Red Alder leaves
 I examined the leaves of the red alder tree, and discovered that most of the veins intersect the central stem at 120 degree angles, which are the angles found in a hexagon. These leaves also have a ridge that prevents them from collecting dust and water.

Alder leaf floor design: 3 parallelograms all made with 1 length of log, intersecting at identical angles.

"IRIS" floor frame

Alder leaf, half-moon floor allows dirt to roll down the sides. In order to clean your floor, you just have to jump!
2) Milk Thistle- Rigging segmentation & Speed of hoisting.
I remember when I was a kid, sitting in my mom's garden, I saw a Milk Thistle plant grow 2 feet tall in 2 days. I thought to myself "why can't we build houses that quickly?"
The Milk thistle plant can grow larger very quickly because their leaves are pre-formed inside a sheathe, with individual segments that open up like a beach umbrella.
The Monkey Bubble House is not held together by 6 long cords, but rather, 72+ individual cords between each segment. This allows for greater safety (if one several cords break, the structure will always hold), and it allows the structure to open quickly and smoothly.

Milk Thistle simply "Opens up"

"Pre-formed Monkey Bubble House simply opens up"
3) Honey Bee- The Hexagon is a shape that can be tessellated and presents the highest volume-circumference ratio. In Other words, the largest rooms, with the least amount of building materials. Hexagons allow for the largest number of cells, with the greatest area per cell, with the least amount of building materials. This allows the honey bees to make large nests every year, mortgage free.4) Orb Weaver Spider- THE WEB (fractal weight diffusion system)"How can we create tree houses that don't hurt the trees?"A spider web will never hurt the grass or vegetation it connects to. The Orb Weaver spider diffuses the weight of its' web over a wide area for maximum strength and safety. Individual strands of silk will often fan out at the ends when connecting to their environment. So I designed a "collar" system that spreads the weight evenly over a wide area, using large loops, so the tree can never outgrow its' collar.  Orb weaver will never hurt the vegetation it connects to."Hexa-fractal" collars diffuse the weight to less than 1.15lbs per square inch, which is lighter than the weight of a birds nest resting on the home tree. Hexa-fractal weight diffusion design. From the top comes six larger cables, which fractal into 36 smaller tree collars. 5) Lotus Flower- insulated Wings designed to pull in like a marionette during cold weather. Fresh water lotus.My geometric interpretation of a Lotus flower. Lotus "Wings" open when warm, close when cold. Sketches of the layers. (Left, right and top: Frame, shingles, wings, folded in)"Wings" pull down like a marionette in cold weather. 6) Sunflower- Fibonacci spiral  Fibonacci spiral seen in the sunflower.Fibonacci spiral shown in collapsed Monkey Bubble frame. 7) Fig-Bottom symmetrical entry. What is the best way to enter a fig shaped structure? Ask the fig wasp! The Fig wasp enters the fig from the bottom. This allows it to pollinate the fig without getting squished between leaves and branches during windy weather
Bottom porthole allows for entry & exit while the structure is rotating & rocking in the wind.
8 )Duck Feathers - Micro & Macro shingle design.
Duck feathers are waterproof, insulated, self cleaning, breathable, and extremely light. Each feather is shaped like an elongated oval.
I asked "how can I make a shingle system that is 100% portable and breathable?" 

Portable shingles tied to mesh using sin wave pattern. Will use gabion mesh in future models for greater strength & safety. Hexagonal shingles positioned with the corner pointed down are 100% waterproof, while using 17.5% less material, allowing the structure to be lighter.

In photos I am using square shingles, whereas in future models, I will use hexagonal shaped shingles. I can also use a mosaic of clear, translucent and opaque materials.

Reflective ceiling could allow for the structure to be lit with a single candle, if held above eye level.

Reflective interior can be made from junkyard materials.
10) Mammalian Iris- Contracted & dilated floor frame design.
Can contract and dilate like the eye of a mammal.
"Iris" floor design, all made from 1 length of log.11) Natural environment of Primates- Jungle GymPrimates often spend a % of their day hanging from their hands in the branches of trees, which decompresses their lower spine. Studies have shown that 85% of adult homo sapiens experience lower back problems at some point in their life. . . but the Monkey Bubble House mimics the natural environment of primates! "Anecdotal evidence suggests the Monkey Bubble Houses attract young homo sapiens, in search of their natural environment."12) Stem cells- Transform-ability of frame components. Many parts of the FLT-1 can be switched into another area, and multiple Monkey Bubble Houses can combine to make bigger ones.Economics-FLT's (Fully Livable Treehouses) are free of concrete foundations, making them potentially more economical than ground houses.-Can be built without clearing land.
20th century ground houses promote drought & deserts.
-Circular structures facilitate heat convection, making them faster & more economical to heat.
-Hexagons and spheres allow the largest rooms, with the least amount of building materials. (due to the mathematical laws of Isoperimetric inequality).
-The desire for minimum weight burden on the tree encourages an efficiency of building materials. 
-Monkey Bubble Houses can be built from simple, multiple repeating iterations of the simple architecture.
-Can be built from junkyard materials to space-grade materials(like unfabricated titanium piping).
Environment
-FLT's are built into the biosphere, promoting a healthy climate.

Live Tree Rentals? A source of revenue from Ancient trees without logging them.
 -Puts economic value on living Oldgrowth Forests
-The Monkey Bubble House is built with weight diffusion collars, allowing it to not hurt the Home Trees.-Suspended structures free land for animals and permiculture.-Homo Sapiens can enter into a symbiotic relationship with their home tree by providing human music, water, nitrogen(from their urine) and pruning.Human Health/Hygiene-The Monkey Bubble House is built like a jungle gym with multiple levels to climb around, making it an ideal fitness party for homo-sapiens!
 A hammock in a Monkey Bubble House functions like a gyroscope.

-Convection of a circular structure inhibits mold, making a healthy breathing environment!
-Playing music for Home Trees can encourage their growth. (4)
-In 2007 & 2013, it was scientifically proven that being in the very presence of ancient trees and forests can lower a persons blood pressure, and increases the immune system.(2)(3)
-Hygiene: half-moon floor structure is self cleaning because dirt rolls through the halfmoons; you can clean your Monkey Bubble House by jumping.
Portability/Upgradability
-The FLT-1 is 100% portable!

A 4 story FLT-1 frame in the back of my firewood truck. (Yes, this is literally a 4 story Monkey Bubble frame stacked in my truck)
-Can fit a FLT-1 frame in the back of a small truck.
-Very fast to assemble & take down.
-The FLT-1 is highly up-gradable, adding more frame hexagons, going from a fig shape, to a pineapple, to a banana.
-Move the floors up and down as you like. Sketch of a "typical" FLT-1 frame. 




Some skteches of a miniature version. (Above)

Miniature prototype, with 25 year old humans, in 25 year old Home Trees!


Safety:
SO far, the FLT 1 has a perfect safety record and has held up to 15 humans at once. Safety is the first priority moving forward.


Prototypes will be load tested and any weaknesses will be researched. 

I would like to test 120 degree steel timberframe joints and a variety of clamped joints and supports.
Future models may use stainless steel cables, and high grade carabiners and rigging components.
Titanium, aluminum & steel pipes may be used..

In future research, I would like to experiment with lashing the structure together, (above) mimicking the tendons and ligaments of biological joints.
-The Hexagonal compression dynamics suggest a high strength to weight ratio.
-The Fibonacci spiral, allows no joint to ever align with another joint, making them stacked like bricks.
-Uniform weight distribution: The floor joist hangs from the supporting hexagonal frame by carabiners so wherever you step, your weight is distributed evenly around the structure.
GOALS & COSTS:
DID YOU KNOW? This project has come to life exclusively through the sales of firewood.
For safety reasons, all future FLT's will use the highest grade components (carabiners, shackles etc.) available.
Typical requirements of a 2-3 storey Monkey Bubble House frame (Not including labour, logs, tools, fuel and arbourist work):

36 small harness collars    
72 high grade carabiners  
6 big harness cables        
6 small Weldless Steel rings 
3 big Weldless Steel rings 
1 Swivel crane Hook (rated for 11 tons)          
3 big anchor shackles        
108 medium-small shackles    
108 forged I-bolts      
36 stainless steel cables of 'x' length
36 stainless steel cables of 'y' length
500 Man Hours

$4000 would help: 
Load test a 1 level frame using barrels of water.
This will require xyz# of water barrels, a 1000 gallon water tank (I can put on my firewood truck and park at a higher level), a hose, 6 sturdy home trees outside the city, (possible) cherry picker rental, assembly labour, fuel, arbourist work, and misc.
Once it is load tested, it can become available for purchase in BC.
$10 000 would help:
-complete the first "glamping" (glamour camping) prototype with steel cables, high grade components, and siding.
$60 000 would help:
-Complete the first FULLY LIVABLE TREEHOUSE, with plumbing & electrical, and all the comforts of a ground house.
$1 Octillion dollars would help:

Engineering
Research & development
Wind Testing, wind mitigation/deflection systems & research
Fibonacci Spiral Staircase
Speaker system to play music for our Home Trees.
Designs for wheelchair access + experimental moneypower
FLT Training center + Licences
Live Tree Rentals for FLT research
Giant steel tripod for safety testing
Custom 120 degree steel timberframe joints
Space grade titanium designs
Arbourist & tree climbing gear
Experimental Moneypower.
Water barrels for testing the minimum breaking forces
Fuel
Monkey Bubble House Production line
Tools, both known & unknown 
Photography & Media production 
Interior design & aesthetics
Indiegogo Rewards 
Indiegogo fees
Taxes.
Diesel Generators
Labour costs
Custom Yurt fabric design
Gabion Mesh design
Snow Mesh design
Custom Hexagonal Shingles
Reflective Insulation
Marionette Wing System +Experimental Moneypower
Funnel cone for water catchment
Rocket stoves, fractal chimney & heated showers.
Plumbing
Electrical
Solar power wings
Website for Crowdsourced FLT Evolution platform - "FLTlaboratory.com"
Begin development of the "FLT 2" (which I already have designs for!)
+Experimental Moneypower.
Helicopter delivery to remote pre-colonial forest locations.
Giant speaker system for playing music through the forest (yes, I already said that)
Plexiglass tunnel system floating through the forests.

REWARDS:
Your Pledge rewards amounts are Fibonacci numbers!
Our rewards maximize the relationship with our backers, and reduces mailing labour in order to maximize our time & Money towards production. 

Logo of the Monkey Bubble House.
Scholarly References:
(1) http://summitcountyvoice.com/2012/02/03/study-deforestation-may-lead-to-drought/
(2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2793346/
(3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17903349
(4) http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/107555304322849039

story:
OUR ANTI-POACHING WORK

We are a dedicated wildlife conservation company based in South Africa. We are currently focusing much of our efforts on conserving and protecting rhinos. There has been a massive increase in poaching in the last few years and we are doing everything possible to fight back. 

As part of our work we have developed a great new tool which monitors the rhinos we work with 24/7. As part of the system we need to be able to respond to any poaching incidents immediately with a helicopter as the reserves we work on are very large. When we started working on this project 2 years ago we managed to get a helicopter for our work but unfortunately we had an in-flight fire in the cockpit and engine bay and we crashed it. Both pilot and I were unhurt but the helicopter was a complete wreck. 

As a conservation company we put everything we had into the system and especially the helicopter. The helicopter is a vital part of our anti-poaching projects but it was also a huge expense for us. After the crash we cannot afford to replace. We desperately need another Helicopter ASAP!

What We Need & What You Get

We need another helicopter. It needs to be a 4 seater as we need to transport a ground team and tracking dog to poaching scene. 
The helicopter (we are hoping for a Robinson R44) will cost us around $350 000. This is what a helicopter in this range costs with around 2/3 of its operational hours still remaining on the meter (helicopters have a certain amount of hours of operation before they must be rebuilt at great cost).
This helicopter will work as part of a new system which relies on incredible technology to stop poaching through constant surveillance and monitoring. We are already fitting the systems to the rhinos but without our own dedicated helicopter we cannot respond immediately to poaching incidents.
WE CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE and to date we have done very well in our efforts to stop poaching. 
If we do not reach our entire funding goal, the funds generated will go directly into our Rhino Anti-Poaching programs. We are currently working with a number of reserves which cannot afford the new system and any funds generated will go directly towards assisting these reserves to fund the fitment of a monitoring and surveillance system. 
Many rhino owners are giving up on their rhinos and moving them off their land which is very worrying. We are trying to help these reserves and we will assist them in any way possible.


The Impact

We also have a wildlife veterinarian service which we also supply to the community. Our helicopter was also a vital part of this service. 

By having another helicopter sponsored to us we will be able to use it as a community helicopter and sponsor the helicopter out to the community and conservation initiatives when work is needed. 

The helicopter will bring a sense of control and hope back to the reserves we work with. The helicopter helps to "level the playing field" with regards to poaching.

Risks & Challenges

To opperate a helicopter in the field is a very expensive excerise  There are maintanance costs and running costs. 

We have successfully managed a helicopter as part of a wildlife services before the crash and we know how to manage it so that the helicopter can be successful in its role as a service provider in our area. 

Rhino Anti-Poaching is also very dangerous as poachers are usually ex-military and well equipped. We accept this challenge. A helicopter helps to reduce the risk to all staff in a poaching situation as it gives the advantage back to the anti-poaching team. Poachers will often lay down arms and surrender (rather than fight back once spotted by a helicopter as this is the point where the poacher realises he is caught and there is no chance of escape through violence).

We have had had much success when using helicopters to arrest poachers and stop poaching and we will be able to continue with this as soon as we are able to get back in the air!

Other Ways You Can Help

Rhino poaching has  reached critical levels and we are facing extinction in the face. The number of poached rhinos per year will now begin to outnumber natural breeding rates. We need people to talk about it, ask questions and help us to create awareness.

Please tell everybody you can about our campaign and tell all their friends and colleagues. 

Set CHALLANGES: get together in groups and give up one luxury for a day e.g. instead of having a few drinks rather save this money or give up smoking for a day....! This can be used to help our helicopter appeal or even other efforts by other groups to fight poaching. If we all do this for a day we will achieve our goal and we can continue to work to stop poaching.


THANK YOU!

Anthony Peniston

VISION AFRICA WILDLIFE

story:
A Place to Bee, 

is an unspoiled place in the heart of Tuscany: Il Casellino, the sanctuary of the bees.  


“If the bee disappeared off the surface of the globe, then man would only have four years of life left. No more bees, no more pollination, no more man!” (Albert Einstein)

It doesn’t take Albert Einstein to understand this simple equation. Yet this phrase dates back to over sixty years ago.

Saving the bees means saving life. If the planet’s entire ecosystem rests on their tiny wings, we want to do something to help as well.

still seeing a rapid decline in bee numbers in California, the largest food producer in the US, one third of the bee population dies off every year. In Italy too, between 2012 and 2013.

The causes? 

There are two main reasons: lack of nutrition and exposure to pesticides. In other words, bees don’t have a habitat that promotes growth and allows swarms to proliferate. A safe place where they can do their crucially important work to best effect. More than 75% of cultivated plants are pollinated by bees, and cannot survive without them. This means that most of the fruit and vegetables we currently eat every day would disappear from our dinner tables.

Without them we have no future, help us to build a bee sanctuary.

What will we do with the money raised?

It is a simple exchange: the insects help the plants to grow, and the plants play host to the insects.

Where? In Tuscany at Il Casellino www.casellino.com

• We will completely fence almost one hectar of fruit garden to protect the beehives and the bees from wild animals.

• Increase the wild flowers, fruit trees and bushes, which are all sources of the natural nectar needed a for the bees to flourish and for the ecosystem to survive.

• Plant hedges of rosemary bushes, which also blossoms in winter, providing nourishment for bees.

• Cultivate more clover food thyme, lavender and rosemary for the bees.

• Not take more of 20% of the honey they produce and leave 80% of it to the bees, it is their natural food for the winter.

Without bees, the world would not be the same. That is why we have decided to raise the community’s awareness about the gradual drop in bee numbers, and the reason why we want to continue developing a habitat for them to grow in a healthy and natural way.


Be with us, be a BeeSitter! 

The First BeeSitter community in the world!





Our Bees at work for your future:

The hives will report your name branded and the certificate number.



A PERKS:

Official "A Place to Bee" mug


Official "A Place to Bee" unisex Hoodie



Official "A Place to Bee" T-shirt



Please support us, share our "A Place to Bee" adv,

share this link with your friend: http://igg.me/at/beesitter

story:
SenSprout’s mission is to make farming more efficient, to produce more crops using less water. We help farmers better understand their crops and fields with our low-cost sensor technology. Our wireless field-monitoring system is enabled by a unique “printed electronics” senor, making it possible to monitor soil conditions and environmental information in real time. The information captured helps farmers make informed decisions about water and fertilizer consumption without compromising crop quality. Other monitoring systems cost several thousand dollars which makes inaccessible for many farmers. We hope to bring a real change in the global agricultural economy with our advanced technology and affordable sensor.

[Vote Us!]
We are challenging the venture contest on "The Ventures"
Please click "VOTE FOR THIS FINALIST" if you like SenSprout!
https://www.theventure.com/jp/en/finalists/sensprout


MEDIAS (Selected)


SenSprout is simple as it can be.
Build the SenSprout using the craft kit and put the SenSprout into the soil where you wish to monitor the level of moisture.  The moisture level of soil and leaves can be seen separately, and the LED light on the SenSprout will change colors as the level of moisture changes. This allows you to decide whether you need to add more water which leads to save water and also to save the plant from wilting.

In the near future we aim to send moist level data not only to the LED light but also to PC and smartphones.

SenSprout could be used for large scale fields to small scale such as personal kitchen garden.

Depending on the water level, the LED light color changes to red, blue and green.
(LED design and the sign color may be changed from the above image.)

▲Concept of SenSprout.　
(The features  shown in the figures differ from that of the DIY kit. )

One of the natural resources that we cannot live without is water.
As we experience the development from infrastructure in our lives, we are starting to forget the value of the resources we use in daily basis, such as water resources. Getting water through the tap became a natural habit of consuming water. 

When we see the Earth as a whole, most are made of sea water - The fresh drinking water is about 3%, and if we exclude the water/ice in North and South Pole, the amount drops to 1%.
At the same time we face the issue with the water sources, contamination, drought, water level rising, and quantity of water intake to be faced as a serious issue.
The map below shows the drought level of the United States. As you can see the drought level in the west coast including California has become a serious issue. Last year not only the west coast but the state of Florida announced fishery damage in oyster industry. This occurred because of the excess amount of water consumption of fresh water in the state of Georgia. The level of the issue has reached to the point where it is obstructing the fisheries and agriculture.



Studies have proved that 70% of the fresh water used by humans are used in agriculture. The effects of climate change and urbanisation is making it harder to secure the water needed to meet these increasing demands. Therefore, farmers must improve the efficiency of their irrigation systems. Moreover, irrigation control helps to improve crop quality and can lead to an increase in the sugar content level of fruits such as grapes and oranges. Although this knowledge is widespread, because of the high cost of other monitoring tools, farmers have been unable to implement the methods needed to make a change until now.

It is easy to sprinkle water with a sprinkler. But what we need is to know how much of that soil has dried, and how much moist the crops are needing. If there is a device that is efficient and affordable, using modern technology with data that could be easily controlled, there may be a way to resolve the water resource issue.


We believe we can reduce the cost of manufacturing a sensor to match the cost of creating a printed leaflet, or as little as 10% of conventional systems, using state of the art technology developed at the University of Tokyo. In doing so, we hope to become the standard tool for “precision” agriculture.


We have been working on this project for over 2 years to launch SenSprout, but still we need more financial support to manage and keep the project moving forward to our goal. We want SenSprout to be approachable and to be known as the latest technology to save the world’s water resources. We want everyone to realize the importance of the water resources through the SenSprout project.
Through Indiegogo we have gained an opportunity to receive help from people all over the world. We believe crowdfunding would be a way to spread the word of SenSprout.
If our project interests you, or would like to try our product, please support us by funding our project or share with your friends through Facebook, Twitter and other social media to spread the word.


Kazuhito Mine, CEO
Kazuhito graduated from the University of Tokyo and joined Sony before launching a start-up incubator called Insprout in 2006.

Yoshihiro Kawahara, Associate Professor
Yoshihiro is an associate professor at the University of Tokyo, one of our Technical Advisers and our representative at The Venture final. His invention “Instant Inkjet Circuit” is one of the fundamental technologies in SenSprout.

Kazuhiro Nishioka, Technical Adviser
Kazuhirois a project researcher at the University of Tokyo who has contributed to both academics and the farming industry through scientific agriculture.

Ryutaro Okada, Business adviser
Ryutaro joined us after founding an Internet research business firm.



地球全体を見たときそのほとんどは海水で、飲み水として使える淡水はおよそ３％ほど、北極・南極の水や氷を除けば約１％にしかなりません。
しかしその一方で、水資源を巡る問題は沢山の課題があり、汚染問題や干ばつ、水位上昇、そして水の取水量の問題などが挙げられるでしょう。特にカルフォルニアを含めたアメリカ西海岸は干ばつの問題が深刻で、昨年はフロリダ州で牡蛎産業の漁業災害が宣言されました。これはジョージア州での淡水の水消費が原因だと言われ、水だけではなく水産や農業と言った私たちの生活を脅かすレベルまで達していることを知ると、もう人ごとでは居られません。
特に農業用水は、人間が使える水の中の７０％を占めていると言われています。
もちろん、作物を育てて収穫することは生きる上で大事なことですが、それでもこの７０％という数字は莫大なものです。
そこで私たちは、この７０％の水源は本当に作物にとって適切に使われているのだろうか、無駄はないのだろうか、という点に着目しました。今土壌がどれだけ乾燥していて、作物がどのくらい水を欲しているのか、もっと現代のテクノロジーで効率よくデータ化でき、ひと目みてわかる、そんなデバイスがあればこの水問題は少しでも解決するのではないだろうか。わたしたちはこの壮大な課題を、テクノロジーとものづくりの力で解決しようと思い、SenSproutを生み出しました。

SenSprout はインクジェット印刷技術を用いることで実現可能になった、土壌モニタリングのセンサネットワークのコンセプトアプリケーションです。静電容量の変化を検知できるセンサにより、土の中の水分量を測ることができるほか，葉濡れセンサで降雨も検知することが可能です。印刷技術を用いているため、小ロットでも大量生産でも低コストで製作できるという特徴があります。メンテナンスコストも最小限に抑えられるほか、大規模農業や高付加価値作物の灌漑の最適化、いつ起きるかわからない地すべりやがけ崩れリスクの評価といった応用が期待できます。 

使い方はSenSproutの作成キットを組み立て、水分量をモニタリングしたい土に差すだけ。難しい設置やバッテリーなどは不要です。

土と葉の水分量を別々に計測することができ、SenSprout上のLEDライトが水分量に応じて色を変えるので、一目見て水やりが必要かどうかが判ります。つまり今まで勘頼みだった水やりが、SenSproutのモニタリングから得られた情報に基づいて実施することにより水資源の大幅な節約に繋がり、水のやりすぎで植物を枯らせてしまうことも少なくなるでしょう。将来的にはLEDライトだけではなく、水分データをPCやスマートフォンなどでデジタル化させることも目標としています。
SenSproutは大きな畑は勿論、家庭菜園やプランター栽培など幅広く使って頂くことが可能です。

土の水分の量に応じて、LEDライトが赤、青、緑に光ります。
（色は変更される場合があります。）

▲SenSproutの構造予想
（リターンでご用意させて頂いているDIYキットのものとは特徴が異なります）

私たちは今までSenSproutを世に出すため、2年以上の月日を掛けて研究に力を注いで来ました。しかし、いくつかの助成金を頂きながら研究や運営をしながらもまだ改良のための資金が足りていません。
SenSproutをもっと手に取りやすく、もっと世界中の水資源を守るために使える最新のテクノロジーになって欲しい。世界中の人が、SenSproutによってもっと水資源の基調さを意識してもらいたい。そんな想いで、私たちはこの壮大な問題を解決するため、今でも研究を続けています。そして今回が、Indiegogoで一般の方へ実際に手に取って頂く機会を設けることが出来ました。私たちにとって、このクラウドファンディングは世界中の人からSenSproutに注目して頂くとても貴重な経験だと思っています。少しでもこのプロジェクトに賛同して下さった方、SenSproutを使ってみたい方は是非ともご支援のご協力をお願い致します。また、支援は難しい場合でもこのプロジェクトを皆様のFacebookやTwitterなどでシェアして頂くだけでも、私たちにとって大きな力になります、どうぞ宜しくお願い致します！

代表取締役 三根 一仁

技術アドバイザー 川原 圭博 博士

技術アドバイザー 西岡 一洋 博士

ビジネスアドバイザー 岡田 隆太朗

story_txt:
SenSprout’s mission is to make farming more efficient, to produce more crops using less water. We help farmers better understand their crops and fields with our low-cost sensor technology. Our wireless field-monitoring system is enabled by a unique “printed electronics” senor, making it possible to monitor soil conditions and environmental information in real time. The information captured helps farmers make informed decisions about water and fertilizer consumption without compromising crop quality. Other monitoring systems cost several thousand dollars which makes inaccessible for many farmers. We hope to bring a real change in the global agricultural economy with our advanced technology and affordable sensor. [Vote Us!]We are challenging the venture contest on "The Ventures"Please click "VOTE FOR THIS FINALIST" if you like SenSprout!https://www.theventure.com/jp/en/finalists/sensproutMEDIAS (Selected)


SenSprout is simple as it can be.
Build the SenSprout using the craft kit and put the SenSprout into the soil where you wish to monitor the level of moisture.  The moisture level of soil and
leaves can be seen separately, and the LED light on the SenSprout will change colors as the level of
moisture changes. This allows you to decide whether you need to add more water which leads to save
water and also to save the plant from wilting.

			In the near future we aim to send moist level data not only to the LED light but also to PC and
smartphones.

SenSprout could be used for large scale fields to small scale such as personal kitchen garden.


Depending on the water level, the LED light color changes to red, blue and green.(LED design and the sign color may be changed from the above image.)

▲Concept of SenSprout.　(The features  shown in the figures differ from that of the DIY kit. )One of the natural resources that
we cannot live without is water.As we experience the development
from infrastructure in our lives, we are starting to forget the value of the
resources we use in daily basis, such as water resources. Getting water through
the tap became a natural habit of consuming water.  

When we see the Earth as a whole, most are made of sea water - The fresh drinking water is about 3%, and if we exclude the water/ice in North and South Pole, the amount drops to 1%.At the same time we face the issue
with the water sources, contamination, drought, water level rising, and
quantity of water intake to be faced as a serious issue.The map below shows the drought
level of the United States. As you can see the drought level
in the west coast including California has become a serious issue. Last year
not only the west coast but the state of Florida announced fishery damage in
oyster industry. This occurred because of the
excess amount of water consumption of fresh water in the state of Georgia. The
level of the issue has reached to the point where it is obstructing the
fisheries and agriculture.
Studies have proved that 70% of the fresh water used by humans are used in agriculture. The effects of climate change and urbanisation is making it harder to secure the water needed to meet these increasing demands. Therefore, farmers must improve the efficiency of their irrigation systems. Moreover, irrigation control helps to improve crop quality and can lead to an increase in the sugar content level of fruits such as grapes and oranges. Although this knowledge is widespread, because of the high cost of other monitoring tools, farmers have been unable to implement the methods needed to make a change until now.It is easy to sprinkle water with a sprinkler. But what we need is to know how much of that soil has dried, and how much moist the crops are needing. If there is a device that is efficient and affordable, using modern technology with data that could be easily controlled, there may be a way to resolve the water resource issue.
We believe we can reduce the cost of manufacturing
a sensor to match the cost of creating a printed leaflet, or as little as 10%
of conventional systems, using state of the art technology developed at the
University of Tokyo. In doing so, we hope to become the standard tool for
“precision” agriculture.









We have been working on this
project for over 2 years to launch SenSprout, but still we need more financial
support to manage and keep the project moving forward to our goal. We want SenSprout to be
approachable and to be known as the latest technology to save the world’s water
resources. We want everyone to realize the importance of the water resources
through the SenSprout project.Through Indiegogo we have gained
an opportunity to receive help from people all over the world. We believe crowdfunding would be a
way to spread the word of SenSprout.If our project interests you, or would like to try our product, please support us by funding our project or share with your friends through Facebook, Twitter and other social media to spread the word.









Kazuhito Mine, CEOKazuhito graduated
from the University of Tokyo and joined Sony before launching a start-up
incubator called Insprout in 2006. 


Yoshihiro Kawahara, 
Associate ProfessorYoshihiro is an associate professor
at the University of Tokyo, one of our Technical Advisers and our
representative at The Venture final. His invention “Instant Inkjet Circuit” is
one of the fundamental technologies in SenSprout. 






Kazuhiro Nishioka, Technical Adviser Kazuhirois a project researcher at the University of Tokyo who has
contributed to both academics and the farming industry through scientific
agriculture. 


Ryutaro Okada, Business adviser Ryutaro joined us after founding
an Internet research business firm.

story:
Note: This CWB Indiegogo campaign has ended, but you can still donate on our website. Thanks for your support.

 

Remediation of arsenic contaminated water

Chemists Without Borders started a project in 2014 to educate high school students in Bangladesh about the health hazards of arsenic in drinking water.  In the process we found two schools, Sitakunda High School and Teriail High School whose school water was heavily contaminated with arsenic.

This past year, with the engineering help of the local Department of Public Health Engineering (DPHE) and funding from Rotary Club Khulshi in Bangladesh and  the Shallotte Rotary Club in North Carolina, we were able to replace both of the contaminated wells, and now about 4000 students at those schools are drinking water that is free of arsenic.

The DPHE engineer explained as follows:

The contaminated wells were tube wells drawing water from the deeper aquifers that were contaminated with arsenic.  The ring wells that we constructed draw water from the aquifer nearest the surface which is not contaminated with arsenic.

Ring Well Under Construction

So the solution to obtaining water free of arsenic was just to construct this shallow ring well.

What we’ll do in 2017

1. Contact 38 high schools and colleges in Sitakunda Upazila, discuss our project and test the  school water for arsenic

2. Construct up to ten ring wells to replace any tube wells that are contaminated with arsenic

3. Provide arsenic-free water for all the students and teachers at these schools.

4. Investigate the possibility of delivering water from the new school wells to homes in the neighborhoods of the schools.

5. Investigate other remediation options, such as community filters, in locations where ring wells are not possible.

6. Make our operating model in Sitakunda Upazila a template that can be replicated in other regions of Bangladesh.

Financial Goal:

Ring well construction: 10 wells x $3500 = $35,000

Benefits 7000 or more students at a cost of only about $5.00 per student

(This is higher than our past well projects, because we have budgeted more money for water testing, training the students to monitor and maintain the wells and money to publicize the need to eliminate arsenic.)

 

Health Education Course:

Earlier this year, a group of CWB volunteers developed two versions of this course to be given one lesson a week for 9 weeks.  One version is for high school students and the other for elementary schools.  The lesson titles are:

1. Water

2. Seeing the Doctor

3. Nutrition

4. Exercise

5. Hygiene

6. Mental Health

7. Meditation

8. Sleep

9. Conclusion and reception for parents

 

This project has been a joint project with the non-profit, Agami, Inc., and the first course was given earlier this year by CWB Program Manager for Bangladesh, Shahena Begum, at BSRM High School in Chittagong, which is one of the many schools supported by Agami.

 

The response to the course was very positive.  Students had not had a course before covering these topics, and the format was also appreciated very much.  The class was very interactive, with students asking and being asked questions, and participating in an exercise in every class. They also were asked to share the material and ask questions of their families at home and to report back to the class. So it was really a class for the family, not just the students.

 

Parents were invited for the last day of class, when students presented what they had learned in each of the lessons.

Conclusion of the Course with Parents

The elementary school version of the course will be started in January 2017 at one of Agami’s schools in Dhaka.

What we’ll do in 2017

Train 10 teachers to teach the course.  Follow up and give them support

Financial Goals:

Train 10 Health Education Course teachers x $500= $5000

Benefits hundreds or thousands of students in learning how their lifestyle affects their health

 

Summary of Financial Goals

Ring well construction: 10 wells x $3500 = $35,000

Train 10 Health Education Course teachers x $500= $5000

Total: $40,000

We don’t expect to raise this full budget for 2017 with this Indiegogo campaign, but please contribute whatever you can to help us improve the lives of students in Bangladesh.

Also, please help us spread the work about our work through your social media contacts. The Indiegogo share tools make that easy to do.

If you or your organization can contribute the full amount needed for a ring well ($3500) or to train a Bangladesh teacher to teach the Health Education Course ($500), we will be happy to name the well or the course after you and recognize your contribution in a plaque on the well or on the Health Education Course material.  Contact me, Ray Kronquist, at the phone or e-mail below if you would like to be a sponsor.

Or, if you have the time and the passion to volunteer to work on one of our teams, contact me about that also.

Thanks so much for your support.

Ray

Dr. Ray Kronquist

President

Chemists Without Borders

http://chemistswithoutborders.org/

Tel: +1-408-929-9066

Skype Name: Ray Kronquist

Skype ID: raykron

Chemists Without Borders is a tax exempt registered 501(c)(3) corporation with the Internal Revenue Service. Tax ID, EIN: 14-1984379

story:
Short Summary

The Climate Justice Programme is the world's only not for profit organisation dedicated solely to legal initiatives and climate change. We work to save forests, coral reefs, and endangered species and support indigenous peoples and local communities adapt to a changing climate. We work with lawyers and environmental and human rights organisations from around the world to develop legal initiatives including law reform and litigation options. 

We are currently developing the Climate Justice Fund which will be a dedicated small grants fund to provide finance to legal initiatives including finance for lawyers in developing countries. We will provide funding for local people to research illegal logging and forest crime, undertake legal research and reports to assist law reform in different countries and develop strategic legal options.

We seek funding to kick start the Climate Justice Fund. We need to develop fundraising applications, meet with organisations and donors and reach out to interested organisations to make applications for funding. We have developed international legal networks and now we hope to raise funds to provide funding to environmental lawyers in our networks in Asia. Africa and Latin America. 

Our work is aimed at world heritage protection, forest protection law and governance, human rights and biodiversity conservation. The Climate Justice Fund will assist legal initiatives and contribute to climate mitigation and adaptation through the use of law.

The Climate Justice Programme is working hard to make a difference and we need your help.

story:
the Kikýnethos Project

traditional House Restoration in Old Trikeri Island, Pelion, Greece


 The Project at a glance

In a tiny Greek island, Old Trikeri, in the Pagasetic (Pagasitikos) gulf, Pelion area, central Greece, I own an old traditional house. The building was build in 1927 and lies within an area of 1000m2 with olive trees, 50 mt distant from the sea. Actually it is abandoned almost forty years.

I would love to bring further and complete renewal of the house in order to use it as a hosting structure for people that love to stay in a really natural environment where vacation from everyday living makes sense!

The house will, in a further step, be part of a larger project that intends to exploit the naturalistic, historical and cultural characteristics of the island in an eco-sensitive approach.

 

   The Aim

Repair and, renovate  a one hundred year old traditional stone house* with a total respect of its typical features in a remote place requires a significant effort. I’m asking your support and participation to complete this step of the project.

My aim is to reach the €70.000,00 necessary to complete works.

Paving, grouting, roof repair, wooden floor replacement, plumbing, fixtures, surrounding wall, garden, etc, will ask about three to four month’s work.

Please have a look on the site www.kikynethos.com to see what it is about.  *house has been recognized as a local traditional building by the Architectural Committee.

*house has been recognized as a local traditional building by the Architectural Committee.

Once finished…

…the house (used to be called “kalývi”=cottage by the locals), having a total surface of approx. 110m2, will be able to host four people in two bedrooms in the upper floor and, occasionally, two more people in the large living room in the basement. Two bathrooms and a large kitchen will complete the building. The surrounding garden, approx. 900 m2, has 12 old olive trees and will offer peaceful hours under the Greek sun or under the olive trees, while the sweet whispering of the nearby bay will sing for you.

No traffic, no crowd, no pollution at all. Pheasants are the most probable “disturbers” just in case they will come out of the bush.


The Place

Old Trikeri island is a small, 4,5 square kilometres, island within the entrance of the Pagasetic (Pagasitikos) gulf, Mount Pelion area, central Greece. It is not fulsome to say it is a small forgotten paradise. Over 75 thousand olive trees, no cars at all, walking pathways, a clear sea, few and gentle inhabitants, 56 according the last census of 2011, two taverns an a -literally!- mini market, make it a little dream but still easy and worthwhile to reach. Old Trikeri is documented to be inhabited since the pre-historical times with the name of Kikýnethos (Greek Κικύνηθος). Swimming, fishing, snorkelling, walking, relaxing and dreaming are some of the things that you can do and that acquire a new meaning here, believe me. To have more information about Old Trikeri please visit the site www.kikynethos.com.

     

Your Contribution

Asking for contribution in a project, means we have something to share: a common goal, a common advantage, a common pleasure. I’m asking those of you that feel the value of simple and beautiful things and like to contribute to preserve and enjoy them to be part of this project.

You can make your donation and you will be recognized for it. By doing that you also open a window out to a magical place helping it to be preserved against time. You will also gain a chance to visit again and again that place as a friend, as someone that contributed to create it. Being part of a valid creation is a high quality pleasure!

For the specific recognition we offer for your contribution, please see the perks section and make your own choice. Perks include keeping memory of your contribution, naming a tree, tasting the exquisite genuine olive oil of Trikeri, spending a week time there, or spending time in an other little paradise: a house in Filicudi Island, one of the Aeolian islands, north side of Sicily, Italy. Aeolian islands are UNESCO World Heritage site.

Further information and details are given on the Project's site specific section: www.kikynethos.com/#!reward-plan/c1m3l.

You feel you can not contribute?

Hopefully, life is not only about money. You could help by spreading the info about this project, talk to a friend, link our web site, or, if you think you are able to work yourself, email me. I could host a limited number of people there for a part of the repairing works stage.

Any amount collected with your contribution will anyway be used for the projects purposes.

About me

I’m Yorgos. During my life I experienced the opportunity to create and also be involved in new initiatives and works due to my curiosity and love for fresh ideas. When I decided to downshift from manager of a multinational to my current profession of psychologist, I just followed the need to achieve a better Quality of life. I have met many people on the way. In sharing feelings and projects with the others I realized the beauty of life. I believe in the quality of living, time is what we make of It! At the present I spend my time between Italy and Greece. I would be happy to answer further questions if you should have any.

Thank you for taking time to read this Project.
