While the loss of wild bees can partially be mitigated by the presence of managed honey bees, wild populations remain major pollination contributors.EMF (Electric Magnetic Fields): Today's technologies, such as laptops, TVs, radios, microwave ovens, Wi-Fi routers, smart meters and cell-phones, all use electromagnetic waves to function. These frequencies are extremely harmful to our natural vibrations as well as the bees’ vibrations, disturbing their meridian clocks and navigational systems. This compromises their immunity and natural rejuvenation, making bees more susceptible to disease and pests.Mites and Viruses: The Varroa mite (Varroa destructor) is a lethal parasite that arrived from Asia, jumping from one species to another. This very small, round mite lays eggs that develop within the honeybee brood, eventually growing large enough to pierce an adult honeybee’s exoskeleton and feed off its internal fluid. This mite can destroy entire colonies and is one of the primary factors in CCD. In addition, these mites can act as vector for several damaging viruses and spread diseases between hives. SHUNGITEA broad range of scientific studies are confirming Shungite’s wide-ranging health and industrial benefits, stemming from its unique molecular structure. Studies are showing Shungite's protection against harmful effects of EMF radiation (Electromagnetic frequencies, emitted by cell phones, computers, cordless phones, microwave ovens, Wi-Fi routers, and other electronic devices) and its effectiveness in treating infections, inflammation, allergies, high blood pressure, osteoarthritis and digestive problems.Shungite has been used for medical treatment in Russia since the early 18th century, largely used to purify water and for the treatment of depression, and various mental/emotional problems. In the world of physical healing, Shungite is regarded as a “Miracle Stone” and is intensively used by crystal and energy healers around the world.  
FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS:
What is Shungite?Shungite is a natural mineral made of 98% carbon. It's found in Karelia, Russia near a small settlement called Shunga. Its atoms form fullerenes, which are made of 60 carbon atoms, resembling a soccer ball at the molecular scale. Shungite has been shown to attenuate toxins and radiation in its environment by reversing the electromagnetic fields to a bio-compatible rotation.How does Shungite help the bees?Numerous studies have shown how harmful an EMF (Electromagnetic Field) or WiFi field can be for bees. Studies have also shown that Shungite can attenuate EMF signals and environmental radiation. Our Shungite beehives have Shungite powder mixed into their exterior paint and we also place Shungite nuggets at their entrance. Once relieved of these harmful EMF burdens, bees can once again function at their natural peak efficiency.What are harmful frequencies?Everything on Earth has a specific vibration, or frequency: All humans, animals, plants and insects have a certain vibration field that has to be maintained at specific levels to remain healthy. Frequency, i.e. the way in which molecules or atoms of all matter “spin” around one another, can be seen under a high-powered microscope. NASA has been using frequency generators for decades to protect astronauts while they're away from the Earth's natural frequency source. Astronauts found their physical condition deteriorated while in outer space, away from the Schumann Resonance (Earth’s own frequency of about 7.8 Hz) and while being in the presence of the strong magnetic fields of the space shuttles. This problem was solved by introducing the "Schumann Simulator" into all space shuttles, a magnetic pulse generator that broadcast Earth’s natural frequency.How do frequencies harm the bees?Today's technologies, such as computer monitors, laptops, TVs, radios, microwave ovens, Wi-Fi routers, smart meters and cell-phones, all use electromagnetic waves in order to function.These frequencies are extremely harmful to our natural (human) as well as the bees vibrations. When the bees vibration field or frequency is disharmonious, their meridian clocks are disturbed, immunity is compromised, natural recovery and rejuvenation abilities are reduced, in turn making them more susceptible to diseases and pests. www.ShungiteHoney.com View Shungite Honey Information Flyer: Download.pdf

story:
Photo by Jason Woolgar

 

In Brazil, lives one of the four tapir species of the world, the lowland tapir (Tapirus terrestris), the largest land mammal of South America! Adults weigh between 180-300 kg. They are about 1.10 meters high and, in some cases, more than two meters long. Their home ranges are enormous, with an average of ca. 500 hectares or, in other words, 500 soccer fields!

Tapirs are forest animals. They prefer gallery/riparian forests along and around water bodies. Nevertheless, they use other habitat types to forage for food and/or travel between different parts of their home ranges. They have the ability to move through the landscape in between patches of forest thus connecting different habitat types. For this reason, tapirs are widely known as ecological detectives or landscape species - they help us understand the inter-relations between different components of the landscape mosaic. Furthermore, tapirs are herbivorous animals, feeding mostly on fruits, buds and leaves. The fruits eaten by tapirs are swallowed with their seeds. When the seeds pass through the digestive tract of the tapir, they have their germination ability enhanced. Thus, the tapir has a key role in seed dispersal, carrying seeds in their stomach for long distances within their home ranges. For this reason, tapirs are known as gardeners of the forest.

The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species lists the lowland tapir as VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION. Human activities – such as road-kill, poaching, pesticide contamination, habitat destruction and fragmentation, large scale agriculture, cattle ranching, mining and expansion of palm oil plantations – have been drastically affecting tapir populations in Brazil.

Lowland tapis have a low reproductive rate and a long generation time. Gestation lasts for approximately 13-14 months, and the female gives birth to only one calf. After giving birth, the female takes about 4-5 months to get into heat again. Thus, an adult female must produce only one calf every 18-24 months. In addition to that, tapirs are solitary animals and because of their large home ranges, the number of individuals in a given tapir population is naturally low. Due to these characteristics, the recovery of an affected tapir population is extremely slow. Any impact they suffer have drastic effects on the population, which makes them highly susceptible to threats. Population declines or local extinctions can trigger adverse effects on ecosystems, affecting ecological processes and eventually compromising the integrity and biodiversity of these ecosystems.

By establishing tapir research and conservation programs in different Brazilian biomes, the LTCI aims to create a comparative approach to the conservation of the species. Thus, we will have a clearer understanding of these animals in different biomes with different landscape contexts and under different levels of environmental disturbance. Thereby, we will be able to better understand the ecology of these animals and their needs, and to evaluate the importance and magnitude of the ecological factors affecting the different populations in the country. Finally, we will have all the necessary tools to promote the development and effective implementation of conservation and management strategies for specific lowland tapir populations throughout their distribution range.


Photo by INCAB-IPÊ

 

The LTCI is a long-term, nation-wide conservation effort led by Brazilian conservationist Patrícia Medici. The LTCI was first established in 1996 in the Atlantic Forest, one of the most threatened biomes on the planet. The Atlantic Forest Tapir Program was a pioneer, long-term project, which included studies in basic tapir ecology, health, genetics and effects of habitat fragmentation, as well as promotion of community involvement, environmental education and habitat restoration efforts.

In 2008, the LTCI expanded to the Pantanal, the largest continuous freshwater wetland on the planet. Several conventions have recognized the Pantanal as an important wetland (Ramsar, Convention on Biological Diversity, UN Convention on Climate Change, Convention on Migratory Species). Nevertheless, current intensification of traditional cattle ranching practices in use in the Pantanal for the past 200 years is threatening this biome. The main goal of the Pantanal Tapir Program has been to collect ecological, demographic, health and genetic data to assess the status and viability of tapir populations in the region.

In 2015, Dr Medici expanded to the Cerrado, the most extensive woodland/savannah region in South America. The second largest of Brazil's ecoregions, after the Amazon, this conservation hotspot accounts for 25% of the country's land area. This biome is the epicenter of economic development in Brazil, where most of the expansion of Brazil's agricultural frontier, which focuses primarily on sugar cane, soybean and corn, takes place. Cattle ranching is another threat to tapirs in the region, as it produces almost 40 million cattle a year. The main goal of the LTCI in the Cerrado has been to evaluate the impact of threats on tapir populations and design strategies to mitigate those threats, while finding ways to conserve and protect the remaining habitat. Threats in the Cerrado include deforestation and fragmentation, road-kill, poaching, the expansion of agriculture, and pesticide contamination.

Watch Patricia Medici's TED TALK and learn more about lowland tapirs and the work of the Lowland Tapir Conservation Initiative in Brazil.: 


Source: www.ted.com

 

The LTCI staff is now preparing to establish its FOURTH AND FINAL tapir conservation program in Brazil, the Amazon Tapir Program. The main goal in the Amazon will be to assess and mitigate threats affecting tapirs along the southern belt of deforestation (Rondônia, Mato Grosso and Pará states). Some of the threats we will be dealing with include current habitat destruction for the expansion of large-scale agriculture (mostly soybean) and cattle ranching, unsustainable hunting, mining, expansion of palm oil, road-kill and pesticides.

YOU CAN HELP US GET STARTED IN THE AMAZON!!!!

 


Photo by Freepik

 

With your help, we hope to raise the necessary funds to take our first and most important step towards the establishment of our FOURTH and FINAL tapir conservation effort in Brazil, the AMAZON TAPIR PROGRAM!  In June 2019, we will run a scouting expedition to the Amazon. For 30 days, we will be on the move, driving along the southern belt of deforestation for about 5,000 kilometers, crossing three Brazilian states (Rondônia, Mato Grosso, and Pará), and getting face to face with the destruction that is taking place in the region. Along the way, we will cross a mosaic of human activities, including large scale agriculture, cattle ranching, highways, indigenous communities, mining, palm oil plantations as well as sustainable management projects. We will visit dozens of different sites and meet with local conservation organizations and other stakeholders. The team will include six people (further information below). In terms of logistics, we will travel in two 4X4 trucks and bring all the necessary field equipment and supplies for 30 days of scouting, data and sample collection.  We will sleep in small road-side hotels and communities and eat our meals wherever we find food!  The funding goal of the campaign was set based on the necessary budget to run the expedition for 30 days, six people, ca. 5,000 kilometers, and includes: rental of two 4X4 trucks, fuel and vehicle maintenance costs, road tolls, ferry tolls, lodging and meals.

Upon completion of the expedition, we will have accumulated all the data and information to allow us to design our new program: 1- the questions we will address in the Amazon and the issues (threats) we will evaluate and work to mitigate, 2- selection of potential study areas, 3- identification of local stakeholders and potential partners, 4- discussions of local logistics and necessary infra-structure, 5- funding needed. We expect the Amazon Tapir Program to have a major focus on evaluating the impact of threats affecting tapirs along the southern belt of deforestation and finding ways to mitigate those threats.

Although the LTCI is mostly focused on the conservation of a single species, we are talking about a VERY IMPORTANT, KEY species! Tapirs play a critical role in shaping the structure and maintaining the functioning of ecosystems. Conserving tapirs in the Atlantic Forest, Pantanal, Cerrado, and Amazon will help guarantee the conservation of these important Brazilian biomes.

Your support is CRITICAL to allow us to run our scouting expedition to the Amazon, and later on design and implement our FOURTH and FINAL tapir conservation program in Brazil, the AMAZON TAPIR PROGRAM!

 

Any donation made is extremely important to us!  By donating, you will receive a special acknowledgement from our team – by e-mail – and we will make absolutely sure to keep you informed about the progress of our expedition.

If you want to acquire a specific Perk with your donation, please remember to select it and click on the “GET THIS PERK” option.

Here, some additional information about our perks and rewards:

  • Tapir Cheers: With a donation of U$10, we will send you a digital certificate recognizing your generous support to our cause.
  • Expedition Highlights: With a donation of U$100, we will send you the certificate and a special digital photobook with an overview of our expedition.
  • Tapir Namesake: With a donation of U$500, you will receive the certificate, digital photobook, and we will also name a tapir after you during our research activities in the Amazon, starting in 2020.
  • Wild Adventure: Donations above U$5,000, in addition to the items mentioned before, will grant you plus one guest a voucher for a 3-night/3-day stay at Baía das Pedras Ranch in the Brazilian Pantanal, including all meals, tours and 4X4 transfers from Campo Grande (Mato Grosso do Sul) to the ranch and back.

Baía das Pedras is a cattle ranch and ecotourism lodge in the heart of the Pantanal floodplain. This is our study area in the Pantanal biome!  The Pantanal is the largest continuous freshwater floodplain in the world and one of the most amazing places on the face of the Earth! During your stay, you will have the opportunity to experience this place's astonishing nature, abundant fauna and flora, where it is possible to enjoy some amazing wildlife sightings, including tapirs.

Your stay will be scheduled for some time in 2020 and hopefully during one of our Pantanal expeditions so that you can experience our fieldwork as well. If you get this perk, our team and the ranch's team will get in touch with you to make all the necessary arrangements for your visit.

Learn more about Baía das Pedras:

Video by Laurie Hedges, lauriehedges.com

If you have any questions regarding the perks or the rewards, please contact us: incabbrasil@gmail.com

If you can't contribute, that does not mean you cannot help! You will be helping us enormously if you share our campaign with your family, friends, work colleagues, neighbors or any other people in your community!

Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, so that our campaign can reach further and further!

 

Patrícia Medici is a Brazilian conservationist with a PhD Degree in Biodiversity Management from the Durrell Institute of Conservation and Ecology (DICE), University of Kent, United Kingdom. For the past 25 years, she has been working for the Brazilian non-profit IPÊ - Instituto de Pesquisas Ecológicas (Institute for Ecological Research) of which she was one of the founding members. Since 1996, Patrícia coordinates the Lowland Tapir Conservation Initiative (LTCI) and dedicates her life to the conservation of tapirs and their remaining habitats in Brazil.

 

José Maria de Aragão – or ZéPS – has well over 30 years of experience working as a field assistant for several wildlife research and conservation projects carried out by IPÊ. Since 1996, José Maria has been Patrícia Medici's right and left hand, helping her carry out the activities of the LTCI throughout the country.

 

Ariel Canena is a Brazilian wildlife veterinarian, whose main professional interests are wildlife medicine and ecology applied for the conservation of species. As part of his professional development, Ariel has participated in both in-situ and ex-situ projects with free-ranging terrestrial and marine animals, including research and rehabilitation programs. In 2017, Ariel joined the LTCI, of which he is now the head veterinarian.

 

Rodrigo Motta is a Brazilian communication expert graduated in Social Communication, Marketing and Advertising. While still a child, he fell in love with the internet and its incredible power to connect people, ideas, and information. Rodrigo's experience with the creation of online content, management of social networks and digital marketing strategic planning is the product of his work with large local and national brands, companies and projects. Communication is at the core of the LTCI work and Rodrigo was hired in 2018 to create and implement a long-term communication strategy to spread the word about the tapir conservation cause in Brazil.

 

Vinicius Gasparotto is a Brazilian wildlife veterinarian currently enrolled in a PhD program on Preventive Veterinary Medicine and Animal Health at the University of Sao Paulo, Brazil. Vinicius is a researcher with the Giant Anteater Project and Brazilian Institute for Conservation Medicine (TRÍADE). He works with the capture and chemical restraint of wild animals, through research collaborations and consultancies.

 

Laurie Hedges is an independent film maker specializing in producing film, animation, clips and digital media specifically for non-governmental organizations, conservation practitioners, researchers and universities to use in advancing efforts to protect wildlife, ecosystems and promote human rights and welfare. His films have been used in fundraising for projects and national parks, lobbying governments, exposing issues and engaging with communities in countries ranging from Rwanda, Indonesia, Brazil, Myanmar to Papua New Guinea. Laurie has previously worked in Brazil on films drawing attention to road development in the Amazon and for a petition to protect tapirs from collisions on highways.

 

 

THANK YOU SO, VERY MUCH FOR JOINING OUR CAUSE!

WE - AND THE TAPIRS - ARE IMMENSELY GRATEFUL!

 

Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions, comments, anything!

Please follow our news and updates through our website and social media profiles:

Website – www.tapirconservation.org.br

Facebook – www.facebook.com/INCAB.BRASIL

Instagram – www.instagram.com/INCAB_BRASIL

Twitter – www.twitter.com/INCAB_BRASIL

YouTube – www.youtube.com/c/INCABBrasil

Campaign Video by Laurie Hedges, lauriehedges.com

story:
Short Summary

  • We are the staff of The Pelee Island Bird Observatory- Sumiko, Sachiko, Patrick,  Sarah and Suzanne.
  • We are raising funds to replace our ageing septic system at our research cottage on Pelee Island. This cottage is where our research team lives for nine months of the year and where we host public events on the island.
  • The Pelee Island Bird Observatory (PIBO) is a non-profit charitable organisation devoted to the study and conservation of birds. The observatory conducts intensive migration-monitoring research and breeding bird studies on Pelee Island from April to November.  A proud member of the Canadian Migration Monitoring Network (CMMN) since 2005, PIBO’s purpose is to collect and disseminate data that will help the CMMN to understand changes taking place in the populations of migratory birds.
  • A new septic system will ensure that our researchers are not exposed to disease-causing bacteria, that our groundwater is not contaminated and that we will not be contributing to the growth of Blue Green Algae in Lake Erie.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We know a lot about birds, but not much about septics.  But some trusted experts have informed us that our current system comprises of a steel tank that is at least 30 years old. Well, steel eventually corrodes,  and corrosion means leakage.  And the leakage of sewage is just not a good idea, mainly when you are located near a large body of water- in our case Lake Erie. So we are raising money towards the installation of a new septic system. Specifically, a Waterloo Biofilter. This system is designed for environmentally sensitive lands and locations that would be challenging for more traditional methods. It will ensure that the water that is filtered through the two-stage system is so clean that we could drink it (but we won't)!
  • Although the full cost of the new system will be in the $20K + range, we are only asking for a portion of that through Indigogo. Various grants will make up the remainder of the cost.
  • As a reward for your generous donation, we have some  AMAZING PERKS! 
  •  An intimate dinner with Margaret Atwood and Graeme Gibson for you and three of your friends!! Wait what? Yes, you read that right.
  • A cartoon of yourself with wings drawn by Margaret Atwood. 
  • Two tickets to an exclusive dinner with famous Canadian authors and much more! Head over to the perks section and see what else is on offer.
  • If we do not meet our goal, the funds will be held in reserve until we can afford the new system. This project is not optional but a necessity.

The Impact

  • As an environmental organisation, it is essential that we minimise the negative impacts of our daily actions. Pelee Island is very special to us. It is where we conduct our research, where we live and where the thousands of migratory birds that pass through this region spend time for many months of the year.
  • Failing septic systems may leak excessive nutrients and bacteria into coastal waters, destroying aquatic plant and animal habitat. The many species of birds that call Pelee home depend on a clean water source for their survival.
  •  With up to five researchers living and working at the cottage for most of the year, it is vital that we are part of the solution to keeping our lake clean.
  • We have had two previous Indigogo campaigns that were very successful-Clean Water for PIBO  raised 104% for a new UV water filtration system, and Monarchs for Moms raised 81% for a new pollinator garden.

Risks & Challenges

  • The only risk in this campaign is if we do not complete the project.  By contributing to this initiative, you can help make our living and working environment safer, and we can help make Lake Erie "Great" again!
  • Once the funds are secured, we will hire a local contractor to start the work in the Spring of 2018.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cannot make a monetary donation that's okay. We understand. You can still help by spreading the word about our campaign and sharing it on social media by using the Indiegogo share tools. Thank you!!

https://www.ec.gc.ca/eau-water/default.asp?lang...

http://www.peleeislandwriting.com/
story_txt:
Short Summary

We are the staff of The Pelee Island Bird Observatory- Sumiko, Sachiko, Patrick,  Sarah and Suzanne.
We are raising funds to replace our ageing septic system at our research cottage on Pelee Island. This cottage is where our research team lives for nine months of the year and where we host public events on the island.
The Pelee Island Bird Observatory (PIBO) is a non-profit charitable organisation devoted to the study and conservation of birds. The observatory conducts intensive migration-monitoring research and breeding bird studies on Pelee Island from April to November.  A proud member of the Canadian Migration Monitoring Network (CMMN) since 2005, PIBO’s purpose is to collect and disseminate data that will help the CMMN to understand changes taking place in the populations of migratory birds.
A new septic system will ensure that our researchers are not exposed to disease-causing bacteria, that our groundwater is not contaminated and that we will not be contributing to the growth of Blue Green Algae in Lake Erie.


What We Need & What You Get

We know a lot about birds, but not much about septics.  But some trusted experts have informed us that our current system comprises of a steel tank that is at least 30 years old. Well, steel eventually corrodes,  and corrosion means leakage.  And the leakage of sewage is just not a good idea, mainly when you are located near a large body of water- in our case Lake Erie. So we are raising money towards the installation of a new septic system. Specifically, a Waterloo Biofilter. This system is designed for environmentally sensitive lands and locations that would be challenging for more traditional methods. It will ensure that the water that is filtered through the two-stage system is so clean that we could drink it (but we won't)!
Although the full cost of the new system will be in the $20K + range, we are only asking for a portion of that through Indigogo. Various grants will make up the remainder of the cost.
As a reward for your generous donation, we have some  AMAZING PERKS! 
 An intimate dinner with Margaret Atwood and Graeme Gibson for you and three of your friends!! Wait what? Yes, you read that right. 
A cartoon of yourself with wings drawn by Margaret Atwood. 
Two tickets to an exclusive dinner with famous Canadian authors and much more! Head over to the perks section and see what else is on offer. 
If we do not meet our goal, the funds will be held in reserve until we can afford the new system. This project is not optional but a necessity.


The Impact

As an environmental organisation, it is essential that we minimise the negative impacts of our daily actions. Pelee Island is very special to us. It is where we conduct our research, where we live and where the thousands of migratory birds that pass through this region spend time for many months of the year.
Failing septic systems may leak excessive nutrients and bacteria into coastal waters, destroying aquatic plant and animal habitat. The many species of birds that call Pelee home depend on a clean water source for their survival.
 With up to five researchers living and working at the cottage for most of the year, it is vital that we are part of the solution to keeping our lake clean.
We have had two previous Indigogo campaigns that were very successful-Clean Water for PIBO  raised 104% for a new UV water filtration system, and Monarchs for Moms raised 81% for a new pollinator garden.


Risks & Challenges

The only risk in this campaign is if we do not complete the project.  By contributing to this initiative, you can help make our living and working environment safer, and we can help make Lake Erie "Great" again!
Once the funds are secured, we will hire a local contractor to start the work in the Spring of 2018.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot make a monetary donation that's okay. We understand. You can still help by spreading the word about our campaign and sharing it on social media by using the Indiegogo share tools. Thank you!!
http://pibo.ca/en/http://pibo.ca/en/getting-involved/rent-the-pibo-birdhouse/http://www.watertoday.ca/ts-septic-systems-effe...https://www.ec.gc.ca/eau-water/default.asp?lang...http://www.peleeislandwriting.com/

story:
The storm may be approaching, but it looks like Saturday is still safe, so the Hemp Workshop will go on as planned so far.  The original venue UHMC will be closed all weekend, but we have secured another location nearby for the workshop!  Please join us at the Cameron Center Auditorium, 95 Mahalani Street, Wailuku 96793.  Organizers will be sending out direct emails to all who registered and also e-blasts to inform others who still want to sign up.  Check in later today for a posting of the conference/workshop agenda, and we'll see you on Saturday!


Hawaii is a place of incredible beauty, natural wonders, diverse flora & fauna, 

and is the most isolated landmass in the world. Located 3,750 miles from the 

California Coast in the Pacific Ocean, Hawaii heavily relies on imported goods & 

energy to sustain. In fact, Hawaii has the highest energy costs in all of the United 

States. 

In April of 2014, Hawaii passed Industrial Hemp Legislation permitting the growth 

and research of industrial hemp by the University of Hawaii. This legislation 

creates the exciting opportunity to grow a test crop of industrial hemp for

phytoremediation research and use as bio-fuel, but we know there is so much more,

namely building material, a food source, and an opportunity to bolster the Hawaiian 

economy. 

Hemp is Hope for a more self-sufficient Hawaiian future. By bringing nature’s 

most rapidly renewable resource back to Hawaii, the Islands will have a locally 

grown feedstock that can be applied in thousands of ways.

The Sustainable Biodiesel Alliance, the Hawaii Farmers Union United – Maui 

Chapter, Doug Fine, the author of Hemp Bound, and Hempitecture are bringing 

Hawaii its first industrial hemp workshop and we need your help to make this 

happen! Participants in the workshop will get hands on experience forming their

own hempcrete block. The educational workshop will be held Saturday, August 9,

from 8:30am to 3pm, with a 1.5 hours hempcrete building hands-on activity from

3-4:30, at the University of Hawaii Maui College Multi-Purpose room.

This event will be the first comprehensive educational and hands-on hemp 

workshop in Maui County. The excitement of creating products and materials 

locally from hemp to increase our sustainability is palpable. Now is the time to 

bring the knowledge to the islands and start developing the skills needed to 

create the multitude of products we currently ship in from around the world that 

could be produced locally -- food products, fiber for paper and clothing goods, 

building materials, fuel, health and beauty products. Rising fuel costs across the US

and internationally create a greater need for Hawaii's self sufficiency.

Hemp, the non-psychoactive relative of the Cannabis Sativa plant, grows in 4 

month cycles and there is incredible potential for year-round cultivation of hemp 

in our climate. The growth of the Industrial Hemp Industry here in Hawaii means 

that we can preserve the open space that is so important to our Island culture 

while also preserving the island paradise for our visitors who help bolster the 

Island economy. All across the US, states are beginning to reenact Industrial 

Hemp Legislation, now it is Hawaii’s turn to celebrate this new agricultural 

opportunity.

We have an opportunity to educate our agricultural sector, local building industry 

and all those interested in a sustainable future on the benefits of island hemp 

cultivation. Led by Doug Fine, author of Hemp Bound, we have assembled 

a team of experts to present at this important workshop to inspire activity and 

advocacy at all levels. A dvd of the workshop will be shot and professionally 

edited in hopes of providing a template that other communities can use to help 

create their own hemp workshops. If you live in Hawaii, or have ever visited the

islands you know how precious and precarious life in paradise has become. 

Please consider supporting this campaign to support not only the Hawaiian

hemp economy, but the hemp economy as a whole so we can do more than just

envision a more sustainable future!

story:
CLIQUE AQUI PARA LER A PROPOSTA EM PORTUGUÊS

The Brazilian government is embarking on a far-reaching plan to build a network of dams accross the Amazon, destroying biodiversity and disrupting the way of life of thousands of Amerindians and other local populations. Now that the work is well under way on the huge Belo Monte dam on the Xingu river, the government is pushing ahead with its next big project - a series of dams on the Tapajos river. But 12,000 Munduruku Indians, long feared as warriors, live here and are fighting back.

Currently, their main efforts are focussed on the autonomous process of mapping out their ancestral territory in the northern Brazilian Amazon, and prevent its destruction. This landmark mission was iniciated last Outubro 17, 2014, after 13 years waiting for official recognition from the Brazilian Government.

In a partnership among five groups that share and expand a discourse in favour of the Indigenous authonomy, this crowdfunding campaign was developed. Together, the Munduruku organizations "Iperêg Ayû", “Da’uk” and “Pahyhyp”, the production of the documentary "The Munduruku Indians: Weaving Resistance" (MiráPorã), and the collective "Amazônia em Chamas" can support the Munduruku people on their struggle for justice and peace on their sacred land.

What We Need 

This campaign aims to raise funds with main three objectives:

(Listed in order of priority)

1) To support the process of marking the boundaries of DAJE KAPAP EYPI – I`ECUG`AP KARODAYBI territory (transport and food for 30 Indians);

2) To legalize two Munduruku Associations: Dauk and Pahyhyp (legal costs, transport and acommodation for 6 Indians);

3) To translate and dub the documentary "Munduruku Indians: Weaving resistance" and a series of videos by "Amazônia em Chamas" to the Munduruku language, and to distribute them;

ADITIONAL OBJECTIVE

To build up a web-portal, in partnership with the Munduruku groups and their supporters mentioned above, to inform a broader public of the Munduruku process of struggle against the destructive and violating Brazilian government plans. The web portal project is designed for one year management, content and translations into Portuguese and English languages.

About the projects

__________________________________

1) Support in the process of demarcation (marking out the boundaries) of DAJE KAPAP EYPI – I`ECUG`AP KARODAYBI land

After 13 years waiting for the 'demarcation' of this land and never being listened to by any Brazilian government, the Munduruku Indians, inhabitants of DAJE KAPAP EYPI land, which serves the populations at Middle and Upper Tapajós River, have started the autonomous process of marking out their land, last October 17th, 2014. 

To learn more, please read: 1st OPEN LETTER ON THE SELF-PROCLAMATION OF DAJE KAPAP EYPI INDIGENOUS TERRITORY

However, the Munduruku Indians need support.

With this campaign, our FIRST OBJECTIVE is to assist 30 Munduruku Indians from the Movement "Iperêg Ayû" to reach the location of the vast DAJE KAPAP EYPI lands and help to mark out their boundaries.

__________________________________

2) To legalize the Munduruku Associations "DA'UK" and "PAHYHYP"

To work on their own campaigns, to deal directly with government, and so on, it is a must to have their associations legalized. 

The SECOND OBJECTIVE of this campaign is to raise funds to take some of their leaders to the nearest town and pay for the legal costs of obtaining legal status for their associations.

__________________________________

3) Translation, dubbing and distribution of "Munduruku Indians: Weaving Resistance" documentary and the filming material of "Amazônia em Chamas" collective.


It is important that "The Munduruku Indians: Weaving Resistance" documentary and the video material by the "Amazônia em Chamas" collective are translated and dubbed into the originary language of the Munduruku people. This is the only way the mayority of the Munduruku who do not speak or read Portuguese language can check the video projects and better understand what has been happening to other regions within the Munduruku territory.

Apart from that, the THIRD OBJECTIVE of this campaign is to raise funds to distribute the dubbed video material to all Munduruku communities,  as well as to send it to film festivals, social centres, schools and universities in other regions in Brazil and abroad.

Watch the documentary's full version in English and other works by "MiráPorã" in the region here.

Check the video material by "Amazônia em Chamas" here (in Portuguese).
__________________________________


EXTRA OBJECTIVE
An extra project was created for this campaign, to be achieved after the main objectives, above, are reached: A Web Portal

Because it is vital to inform a broader public of their present process of struggle against the destructive and violating Brazilian government plans along the Tapajós basin, a web portal both in Portuguese and in English will be designed in collaboration of the groups involved in this campaign. 

The web portal aims to provide a historical timeline, maps, legal documents, news and videos on the Munduruku people and their struggle. It will be created and its content managed in direct collaboration with some Munduruku leaders from the organizations mentioned above, and disseminated with the support of local groups and partners in Europe, such as Combate Racismo Ambiental and Latin America Bureau.

This EXTRA OBJECTIVE is intended to finance the construction of the portal, which will include a week visit of five (5) members of "MiráPorã" and "Amazônia em Chamas" to some of the Munduruku villages for the discussion of the structure and content, and also t o fund its management for a year.
_________________________________

PERKS
Supporters of this campaign will have the rare opportunity to get traditional Munduruku necklaces made by the Indians themselves, authenticated by members of the two associations supported by this campaign (check the video above with the message from the Munduruku warriors).


In addition, the rest of the team we'll also offer:

1. DVD copies of the 25min documentary "The Munduruku Indians: Weaving Resistance";

2. An "Amazônia em Chamas" collective packadge containing two publications, a collection of videos and a IPI IBUIXY IKUKAP map, built by "Laboratório de Cartografia" in conjunction with the Munduruku movement "Iperêg Ayû" in their II Assembly, in 2013;

3. A mp3 file of "Whispers" by the musicians Kushal Gaya ("Zun Zun Egui" & "Melt Youself Down") and Jennifer Sutton ("Pigeon Heroes");

4. An A3 copy of an image of the Munduruku protest at the "Public Consultation" event in Jacareacanga, September 29th, 2013. Image by Nayana Fernandez, taken during the shooting of "The Munduruku Indians: Weaving Resistance". In July 2014, this photo was exhibited at Amnesty International in London.

AND

The most generous donors will receive personalized perks, made in the Munduruku villages.
_________________________________


BUDGET BREAKDOWN

1) To support the process of demarcation of DAJE KAPAP EYPI - I'ECUG'AP KARODAYBI territory

Travel expenses (30 Indians): USD 4 200
Food during the travels (30 Índians): USD 1 200

Sub-total: USD 6 400

2)To legalise two Munduruku Associations: DAUK and PAHYHYP:

Including legal costs, transport and acommodation for 3 members of each association  to the nearest town for two days

DAUK: USD 1 200
Pahyhyp: USD 985

Sub-total: USD 2 185

3) To translate and dub the 25min documentary, and to distribute it

Travel expenses (3 people/week): USD 1 650
Accomodation + Food (3 people/week): USD 1 000
Translation and dubbing: USD 1 500
Editing, duplication, printing and postal expenses of 1000 DVDs: USD 3 200

Sub-total: USD 7 350

Perks and postal expenses: USD 1 200


General sub-total: USD 16 135

TOTAL + Indiegogo taxes: USD 18 072

__________________________________
EXTRA OBJECTIVE

- Portal Web

Visit of another 2 members of the groups above to some of the Munduruku villages (to be developed in the same period as in the third objective):

Travel expenses + accomodation to reach the nearest town : USD 1 195
Boat rental and fuel to reach the villages: USD 790

Tecnical development and management for a year:

Domain (year): USD 50
Design: USD 920
Internet and other communication expenses: USD 920
Content (year): USD 2 195
Social Media and communication (year): USD 2 195
Translations (24 pieces / year): USD 2 195

Total: USD 10 465

__________________________________

IMPORTANT:

If this campaign does not raise the full amount sought, we will only support the respective projects funded, listed above by priority. Any additional funds will be donated to the Munduruku associations.

story:
Trent Needs your help.

I am trying to raise around $15,000 to help offset lawyer fees and court fees to rewrite the parenting agreement in my favor. As it stands, Trent lives with his mother most of the time and she dictates his schooling and is the main parent in his life, just because of the time spent together.

She is abusive - both emotionally and physically - and left deep impact that will forever scar him. 

Every weekend he is at my house, he asks if he can stay here instead of going back. Every time, I start to cry a little when I turn my face. 

I do have two perks that you can take advantage of. Both are a collaboration between Trent and myself to help each other out with this project.

Besides these perks, we offer our sincere gratitude and appreciation for your contribution; your help; your ability helped spare this innocent child from further neglect, torment and pain.

Trent has visited with several professionals and they all say the same thing: get him out of his mother's control. With your help, we will.

Once and for all, everything will stop.

On behalf of my wife, myself and of course, Trent, thank you for reading this and for making a difference in my son's life.

A FEW FAQs:

Q: Who will have direct access to and oversee the distribution of funds donated?

A: Anthony has set up a bank account directly for use in this campaign. Because of the nature of online funding, he is the primary overseer of the funds.


Q: How was the $15,000 campaign goal determined for legal costs?

A: After talking to several lawyers and law professionals,  a ballpark figure of $10,000 was established. $5,000 was tacked on just because Anthony does not want to be surprised at the end of the litigation period.


Q: What happens to any funds accumulated that exceed the actual final legal costs?

A: All money collected is for Trent. Therefore, if anything is left over, It will primarily go towards any therapy bills (out of pocket) that he incurs, and ultimately, the account will transform into his college savings account. 


Q: What guarantee do we have that Anthony will pursue securing full custody to the end? 

A: Only the Word of a very frustrated parent that wants the best for his child. Updates on litigation will be published here and told to select people. Social Media will not be used for this case, as many of the ongoing portions of this will be sensitive and not suitable for social media.


Q: Were there other options that Anthony could ave explored to raise the needed funds?

A: Anthony currently works all hours of the day as a graphic designer. Besides his 6am - 4pm job, he has a home office and works from there. All paid moneys for his personal work go directly into this fund for Trent as well.

story:
PROJECT: SAVE THE MONKEY DEN

The Monkey Den has been an open house hold to adverntuers, parachutists, highliners, climbers, and active people in general. 

We have had a lot of people stop by, play in the net, sleep on the floor, cook in the kitchen, use the bathrooms, borrow gear, use it for rescues, highlines, climbs, get beta, and for the most part we never asked for anything in return except for respect of the house and chores while monkeys stayed here. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

What WE need is some help raising money to pay for the fines that have been brought upon us by what the city deemed "excessively high amounts of traffic,"  as well as fixing the probelms cause by this traffic in and around the Monkey Den.  

While we are paying the fines and refurbishing the house to a resonable standard, we are going to develop a plan of action to OPEN the DEN to Monkeys once more.  It will be a challenge but we will find a way to support our community of adventures in a way that our household can manage, as well as the city can deem as  appropriate.  

 

The Impact

Every donation made will go directly into paying the recent fines imposed on the Monkey Den as well as fixing the damage done to the Den over the last 3 years. 

The more help we get, the faster we can figure out a way to return to status quo. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, which we totolly understand, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please share this campaign, tell your friends, and especially if you have been to, heard about, seen our videos, or know someone involed with the DEN... please let them know we could use their help at this point in time! 

Thanks for your efforts.

story:
Summary:

A group of Dakota First Nations horsemen and their families will be riding from Manitoba in a symbolic action for the purpose of healing for all living beings and the earth herself at this critical time for our existence.  The riders will travel in the spirit of peace and reconciliation in a sacred fashion. They will journey to the East Coast, making stops throughout the Hudson Valley in NY and beyond, heading south along the Hudson, bringing healing to Sandy Hook, CT, presenting at the United Nations Day of Indigenous Peoples, and riding to the White House, inspiring so many people on the way.  Their home base during this epic trek will be Woodstock, NY, the iconic home of peace.   This is the longest ride undertaken by Gus High Eagle and his riders, but other important rides have been conducted, like the yearly ride to honor the Dakota 38 in Mankato, Minnesota. The purpose of this ride, in the Summer of Unity 2013, according to Gus, is for awakening, for healing.   

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funds are needed for care of the horses, expenses for traveling/ camping, food, fuel and fees to cross the border with horse trailers, permits for riding in various states, cities, and townships, including New York and Washington DC.The horses' needs must be maintained at all times.

Even if our goal is not met, every dollar will help support this unique and meaningful effort.

*ANY AMOUNT, even one dollar, is welcomed and appreciated!

* For each $30 donation we will thank you with a skillfully handmade Dakota craft. Each will be unique.

*For each $75 donation, you will be thanked with a beautiful framed print from this summer's ride. An eye-catching reminder of your valuable contribution.
 
*For any generous donation of $500 or above, one of our team members will contact you to discuss your special gift.

The Impact

Your assistance in this project will actually help improve the world. Whenever people gather with peaceful intent, for greater understanding and respect of culture and traditions, major inroads for positive change and right action are created. The sweeping power of this ride will be deep and lasting, truly something special to behold.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, please send out a positive wish for healing the world and all its creations. Please share the message of this ride to all your friends and networks to help  make it happen.

Use social media to change the world for the better!

story:
Hi my name is Jessie Wright, thank you for checking out our campaign!

As you may have heard, my family is on a mission to live sustainably in a tiny home.

Our family of three has decided that we will make a major lifestyle change. We are going to downsize our 900 sq ft home into a tiny 200 sq. ft. House on wheels. Our new "off grid" home will be built by us, and made from as many recycled materials as we can employ. We intend to use solar power, rain collection, composting, and other sustainable systems.

This lifestyle is becoming more and more popular as we seek stability in an unpredictable economy. Permaculture engineering shows us how comfortably we can live in an inexpensive, low impact way. Recent articles suggest it could be the cure for homelessness.

Our family's journey will show the world that simplifying is good for the environment, economy, and overall happiness. We will document our journey weekly on our blog, ThisTinyHouseFamily.typepad.com.

Your contribution is what will kick start this dream into a reality. Financial institutions don't do loans for tiny homes as they are not a recognized "home". Banks tend to provide for what is profitable, not sustainable. Being that we have no home to sell to help pay for the build, and our two year savings is not cutting it, we were advised to try crowd funding
(here we are!). You have the power to help one more family show the world that we can be sustainable and comfortable on a budget that won't require you to give up 5 days (or more) of your week to pay for it. Even the smallest donation makes you a big part of taking our culture one more step in the right direction.

Update:

We have procured a 25ft trailer from a friend who will have it stripped and ready for us to take home in a couple of months. Step one is the shell. The shell is a time sensitive step and the biggest investment. I has to be completed in a very short amount of time so that all of the materials retain their strength and shape. I have calculated materials for this step to cost around $7,800.

Why we are crowd funding

We have been denied for loans via financial institutions for a variety of reasons including lack of previous loan history (we like to afford the things we buy) and the fact that a tiny home is not an easy thing to describe in bank terms. You know what? We're better off without them. Our mission will now be financed entirely from contributions, sponsors, and our own pockets instead of the unpredictable banking system.

This is the beauty of crowd funding. The people of the community who want to contribute to a global cause can do so by giving a small amount to our mission.

If we do not reach our goal, funds obtained will be added to our "Tiny House Fund" account and only be used to move us closer to our dream.

Impact

"In a consumer culture of waste and stress there must be an alternative. To be able to live debt free, in a sustainable way. We need to see more families thrive on very little income while being healthy, comfortable, and, environmentally conscious."

You.

The impact of your donation is this, you have the ability to make our dream come true and allow our story to reach others who might also seek a simple life. The turnaround could be enormous if more families our age see this eco friendly life as a beautiful alternative to overconsumption and lifelong debt.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but still want to do something to help, spread the word! Let people know about our mission and how it can help to teach others to live more sustainably.

Thank you for reading!

(Photos by Virginia Harold)

story:
WHAT THE HECK ARE WE TRYING TO DO?

Solar power is a renewable source that requires a lot of initial investment, but the current offering provides a low ROI for individual Customers. 

3 Things we are doing:

  1. First, we would manufacture a new roof system that would support using many varieties of solar Flexible PV (Including Unisolar® 144W converter).  These films use the same technology of solar as seen in your basic calculator, but we would place it onto a stylish, more durable roof system, replacing typical plywood asphalt systems currently in everyday households across America.
  2. Second, we would install all the necessary components for making the system happen. 
  3. Third, we make peoples energy costs disappear!

Of all the renewable energy technologies available to the world, only Solar power presents an opportunity for Consumer use on residential and small commercial scales.  The problems with implementation are vast and the economics are skewed.  Power companies are trying to break the mold and find a way to get into the market instead of giving away their customers. 

Powertrenz is that company that has found value to the homeowner and made the possibility of home use solar realizable.  This model incorporates the use of cheaper yet still effective flexible PV and Solar film on a new roof type to bring value to the customer.  By implementing an aesthetically pleasing design to residential roofs, changing the useful life of the roof and implementing solar, we are able to not only add solar power to a rooftop, but can replace a roof.

We are a group of plastics and marketing guru’s who have long been interested in the value of Solar.  We have designed plastic rooftops in the past for sheds and barns and through our technical knowledge we know we are able to replicate the value on a home. 

What you will do as a contributor is give us the power to buy our first prototype house and make a real life-size hjouse come alive with solar power.  The money we raise will go towards the necessary materials and expert services to install the rooftop.  From that point, we are ready to make the real thing happen.  Your donation will prove to the world it can be done.

THE VISION:

Interlocking base panels that will replace the shingles on your roof




BENEFITS:

Space Utilization and Generation Capability

1.  The cost to replace a roof can now hide the cost of installing solar power.

2.  There would no longer be a need to add support to roof structures to hold the typical Photovoltaic systems.

Solar films/Flexible PV

1.  Can be cheaply manufactured and replaced as necessary.

2.  Most cost the same or less than conventional PV panels with slightly reduced (not concerning) drops in efficiency.

3.  Most films are durable to normal weather, and our current first choice of Unisolar Flexible PV 144W has a 20 Year Warranty. 

Benefit to the Customer

1.  Cheaper electrical rates

2.  Sustainable energy generation

3.  Increased value to the Home (Average of 10-20k value added to the house)

4.  Costs to the customer are spread over time

5.  Maintenance and Control of the system are transferred to the company

6.  Government Credits and Tax benefits are available in all states

THE TEAM

Management Team

Peter Crayton: I am a WEMBA 2013 MBA candidate with about 10 years experience as an Engineer and Innovation Manager with P&G and Unilever.  I have been in charge of starting up companies to work with P&G and Unilever as both Suppliers and Contract manufacturers.  I have built my own Business in the past starting from scratch and watched it succeed.  I am interested in energy due to the great Demand we have for this product around the world as well as the personal satisfaction it would bring to me to have created something beneficial to the world. 

 Anup Shah: I am a WEMBA 2013 candidate with about 10 years of experience in the engineering consulting. I have recently started with Metro Atlanta Chamber as the VP of Environmental Affairs. I have a bachelors and a master’s degree in Environmental Engineering. I have a keen interest in the energy and sustainability arena and I am deeply engaged in the water-energy nexus and policy issues surrounding it.

Ryan Smith:  After having spent the first nine plus years of my career in the Energy industry, specifically in Nuclear, I have witnessed first-hand the dynamic and dramatic shifts in the landscape for power generation.  My time with GE in the Power & Water business has seen the rise, fall, rise, and then fall of the Nuclear Renaissance, the rapid emergence and then downtown in Wind, and the recent explosion in gas turbines.  During that time I have been working with our Nuclear Services business delivering projects to major Utility customers across the US and in Asia, while also directing internal projects for technology development following GE’s New Product Introduction program.  I worked in mechanical design after graduating with my BSME from NC State, and hope to continue working around emerging technology in the Energy industry once I complete my MBA from Fuqua in 2013.  I see this area of solar energy as an exciting field with vast growth potential if the right product is brought to market.

Charlie Wright: I am a WEMBA 2013 candidate with seven years of experience in the consumer products and goods industry working for Newell Rubbermaid.  I have worked in a variety of supply chain roles and spent the last five years sourcing plastic and metal components and finished goods across the globe.  Prior to my work at Newell Rubbermaid, I spent 18 months founding a microfinance company in Peru. I have an strong interest in solar energy solutions and look forward to growing this company.

CROWDFUNDING NEEDS (WHAT WE ARE RAISING MONEY FOR)

  • We need $5K for materials to make our plastic based rooftop, buy some solar PV panels and place all of that on a rooftop. 
  • What you get is the first ever satisfaction of making solar affordable for everyone.  For the price of a normal asphalt shingle roof that lasts 15years, we can add a roof that lasts 50 and has solar.  That is our goal.
  • For a donation of $30 we will send you a fantastic t-shirt that says you are a supporter of solar. 
  • For a $200 donation we will get you your own demo of the plastic roof.

THE IMPACT

Electrical Energy Prices are increasing due to higher demand and less supply.  The US Residential households often pay the highest rates with averages running above 11 cents per KWH.  US residents consumed over 154,698 million KWH in 2012.  The price and market for residential power is over 17 Billion in the residential market.  Prices constantly get higher and higher based on demand.  Forecasts for Power Demand put US residential power at Double the KWH currently demanded by 2025.

.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they you can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Perk Descriptions...

T-Shirt is in...

solutions and look forward to growing this company.

CROWDFUNDING NEEDS (WHAT
WE ARE RAISING MONEY FOR)

We need $5K
     for materials to make our plastic based rooftop, buy some solar PV panels
     and place all of that on a rooftop. 
     
What you get
     is the first ever satisfaction of making solar affordable for
     everyone.  For the price of a normal
     asphalt shingle roof that lasts 15years, we can add a roof that lasts 50
     and has solar.  That is our goal.
For a
     donation of $30 we will send you a fantastic t-shirt that says you are a
     supporter of solar.  
For a $200
     donation we will get you your own demo of the plastic roof.
THE IMPACT
Electrical Energy Prices are increasing due to higher
demand and less supply.  The US
Residential households often pay the highest rates with averages running above
11 cents per KWH.  US residents consumed
over 154,698 million KWH in 2012.  The
price and market for residential power is over 17 Billion in the residential
market.  Prices constantly get higher
and higher based on demand.  Forecasts
for Power Demand put US residential power at Double the KWH currently demanded
by 2025.
.
Other Ways You Can Help
Some
people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they you can’t help:

Ask folks to
     get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them
     to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Perk Descriptions...T-Shirt is in...

story:
We did it before, let’s do it again--in Peru!

Last year, we ran a successful campaign here on Indiegogo. Our goal: conserve wild palm trees that provide high-quality nutrition to people in South American rain forests.

From Venezuela to Bolivia people are cutting down wild palms to take their fruit. This degrades both the forest and the diets of local people. We make common cause with those locals who support sustainable palm fruit harvests.

Having worked in backwater areas to test our approach, we are ready to take the project to the big leagues: IQUITOS, PERU. Its half-a-million people survive in large part by consuming from the bounty of the surrounding rain forest--including palm fruits.

To conserve wild palm trees, people can harvest their fruit by climbing for it, so that the trees can fruit again. This was the traditional way. How do we know? At our first workshop and competition, in 2002, older climbers bested younger climbers. They had the technique down, while the youngsters were not in climbing shape, and lacked technique-they were more experienced with using axes or machetes to cut palms down.

Last year, you gave, we bought equipment and supplies, made the climbing gear, took it to Venezuela, and held the event. Over 90 palm climbers participated and it was the most successful event yet. After 4 events over 10 years, young people have learned the technique—they are the top climbers now. This will translate into greater conservation of wild palms in rain forests.

Now: the next step

We are ready for Iquitos. And we have a special member of the team lined up: Italo Mesones, native Amazonian renaissance man. Italo knows the small communities in the forests around Iquitos. He knows where the fruit is harvested, knows where palms are being felled to collect their fruit to feed the big market in Iquitos. He navigates city and jungle equally well.

Italo’s skills and knowledge are key to making our event in Iquitos a success. We have the manufacturing equipment many of you funded last year. So that gives us a big leg up. What we need to do in the next 6 months is train two dozen instructors for a huge workshop and competition in mid-2013. So, we need to get busy making gear, and we need Italo out in the field organizing.

Remember, in general, the more funds we raise, the more gear we can make, the more people we can train, the greater our impact on wild palm conservation and the health of rain forest peoples!

Please join us and spread the word!

About us

Tarek Milleron, Ph.D., has run Caura Futures for 7 years, developing innovative solutions for rain forest conservation. Paul Fine, Ph.D., Assistant Professor at UC Berkeley, has studied tree diversity in Peru and beyond for a dozen years.

story:
A Botanical Garden is a place where plants are grown and displayed for the purpose to serve education, research and biodiversity conservation. They disseminate information to an increasingly eco-conscious public. It creates a solid biodiversity unit, as it’s estimated that there are around 30 million different species of plants and animals in the world, of which just under 1.7 million are known and have been classified scientifically.

The Botanical Garden will be part of the Palestinian Plant Biodiversity (PPB) unit of Birzeit University in Palestine; whereas the establishment of The Botanical Garden is currently at its beginnings and endeavors on collecting and maintaining indigenous plant species. Further to that, the Botanical Garden will provide teacher professional development in the field of plant biodiversity.

In Palestine, the richness in plant species represents a great genetic pool to develop and breed new varieties that tolerate drought and/or salinity, which are the major obstacles to the Palestinian agricultural sector. In addition to that, exploring new plant species/ subspecies will add a lot to human knowledge.

The proposed Botanical Garden will serve Palestinian society in various fields. Of particular importance is the dissemination of information to an increasingly eco-conscious public in addition to the entertainment value in the occupied Palestinian territories which lack such facilities.  While it’s regrettable that almost all schools in Palestinian Territories lack facilities that address biodiversity issues, we take pride in that the proposed Botanical Garden will utilize the rich natural resources to provide opportunities to enliven, entertain and enhance the learning of students.

story:
Ignorance of The LAW is No Excuse!

The LAW connects to the low pressure port of the regulator

Lionfish are becoming a monumental problem in the Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic and the Caribbean. They are consuming massive quantities of juvenile commercial fish and seafood such as grouper, snapper, shrimp, octopus, lobsters and many reef fish.  NOAA has said that this invasive species will have the largest impact on the Atlantic and Caribbean reefs in the last century, much greater than pollution and development. The links below are from leading scientific organizations and media and they depict very dire consequences if Lionfish cannot be controlled. A single Lionfish female can produce over 300,000 eggs per year and they have no natural predators! They can consume prey that are more than half of their own length. They have also been documented to decrease native fish populations by 79% in 5 weeks by a single lionfish.  Lionfish have 17 venomous spines that can cause extreme pain and swelling. They have been seen as deep as 300 feet and as shallow as 5 feet.

Studies have shown that culling, which is killing Lionfish in designated areas such as reefs, will work to control the ever-expanding population. But without vastly increasing the number of divers that are actively involved in hunting, control will not be attained. There must be a change in weaponry. The military does not normally use single shot rifles because it is not effective, nor will pole spears or standard spear guns be very effective in the long run.

My name is Michael Price with Pollution Solutions. I have been an avid diver and environmentalist for over 30 years. Last year, I traveled to Belize and was appalled at the number of Lionfish I saw there. After that trip we began work on new technology for Lionfish control.


The LAW pierces a thick skinned orange, much tougher than a Lionfish's skin

We developed The LAW™, which is an acronym for Lionfish Assault Weapon. The idea behind this device a simple. The LAW is a rapid-fire, retractable air driven device with a patent pending.  The LAW has important advantages over current methods of removal and represents a quantum leap in technology. We used research information concerning their biology and behavior in the design. We also reduced the impact of hunters on the reef.


Here are some of the design improvements we incorporated:

•  The spear does not leave the device, so it can fire rapidly and reduce damage to the reef from missed shots.

•  The LAW uses small amounts of low pressure air  from the diver’s regulator, so it can be fired many times without fatigue to the hunter from stretching bands on conventional weapons (the weapon can be fired 5 times after the valve to the tank has been shut off)

•  The LAW is extremely accurate, even for first time users

•  It is a simple device to manufacture and has few moving parts

•  The LAW has a simple lionfish removal capability option

•  The fish will be intact and may be collected for consumption

•  There are different spear tips for different functions that can be threaded on the spear shaft

We are facing many environmental problems and some of these cannot be changed by individual actions. Lionfish control and the demise of the reef habitats, is not one of those. You can make a difference! By helping us fund this project, you will be adding a new and more efficient method to control this menace that may very well damage our oceans and its inhabitants for all of us and for generations to come.

With your help we will make a difference!

How will the money be used?

Our intent is to bring The LAW from a 2nd generation prototype to a manufactured on-the-shelf product. This will require engineering to reduce costs and design parts, such as a handle and tube sealing. We will also need testing of at least 5 beta units in affected areas to determine what changes to implement. We will require liability insurance, packaging, legal help, a website and money to purchase awards. The following are our cost estimates:

Build up to 40 units as awards        $10,000 

Design work-handle and trigger      $10,000 

Travel for beta tests                             $8,000 

Beta Test Units (5)                                $2,500 

Insurance                                                  $5,000 

Awards                                                       $8,000 

Packaging                                                 $2,000 

Legal                                                           $2,000 

Website                                                      $3,000 

Subtotal                                                   $50,500 

Indiegogo/Paypal                                   $5,050 

Total                                                          $55,550 

If the goal is not attained the development of the betas will be the first priority.

Risks & Challenges

Getting permission for use of this device, in all other affected countries may be a challenge, but because The LAW is designed for Lionfish spearing only, we believe it will succeed.  There are several people in those countries that will champion our cause.

Attaining broad acceptance by the dive industry will take time, but the beta testing program will add credibility to the device and its use.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please promote our Indiegogo campaign and Facebook page to your friends and family.

Bios 


Michael Price, Inventor:  Michael has been an avid diver since 1976.  He dived many destinations from the Caribbean and South Pacific.  He has worked in the water industry for over 30 years and has a degree in chemistry and minored in marine biology.  His passion has always been for the environment and the wildlife that inhabits it.  He had two previous businesses involved in the environment and water and has received a patent for an air pollution control device.


Sheila Agahan-Price was the administrator at UCSD School of Medicine. Her management skills provide efficiency and oversight of the entire project of The LAW.  Her interest in Lionfish came from a trip with her husband, Michael, to Belize where she saw the damage being caused to the reefs inhabitants.


Anthony San Nicolas has a love for computers ever since he had to format his first Windows 3.1 computer.  He attended Platt College where he acquired his Associates Degree in Graphic Design.  He is the videographer and draft illustrator for the prototype of The LAW.  Anthony has become passionate about the Lionfish invasion and looks forward to further the cause of The LAW.


Kristi San Nicolas is a graduate of the Art Institute of San Diego, California, with a Bachelors Degree in Graphic Design.  She has brought to our team her unique creativity in the design logo for The LAW.


Fred Maki has 37 years of experience as a machinist, engineer, and programmer. He developed the prototype of The LAW in conjunction with Michael and will continue to manufacture the beta and pre-production series and possibly produce the finish product.


Chris Gross Avid diver and concerned marine life conservationist. BS degree, Journalism, University of Florida Writer, Producer, Director for all major TV networks. Musician with feature film credits as composer. Awards: The New York Festivals
