story:
What is a pangolin?
Qu'est-ce qu'un pangolin ?

 

 

ENG: Pangolins are truly fascinating, unique animals. They have existed on earth for over 80 million years and yet they could disappear before most people even know they exist. There are eight species in total - four in Asia and four in Africa - and sadly all are threatened with extinction. Poached for their meat and scales, which are mainly destined for Asia, pangolins are considered the most trafficked mammals in the world. These 'scaly anteaters' regulate ant and termite populations, playing an important role in maintaining balance in the ecosystems they inhabit, yet we still have much more to learn about them.

 

FR : Les pangolins sont des mammifères uniques. Présents depuis plus de 80 millions d'années sur la planète, ils pourraient disparaître avant même que la plupart des gens entende parler d'eux. Braconnés pour leur viande et leurs écailles, ils sont aujourd'hui menacés d'extinction. Il existe huit espèces de pangolins : quatre en Asie et quatre en Afrique. Tous se nourrissent de fourmis et de termites et jouent un rôle primordial dans l'équilibre des écosystèmes où ils vivent.

 

Why are pangolins under threat?
Pourquoi les pangolins sont-ils menacés ?

 

ENG: All eight species of pangolin are threatened by the illegal trade in their meat and scales. Pangolins are poached for their meat, which is consumed locally as bushmeat as well as a luxury dish in Asian countries, and scales, which are prized as an ingredient in traditional Asian medicines. It is estimated that more than 1 million pangolins have been taken from the wild in the last decade, making them one of the most trafficked mammals on the planet. In recognition of this overexploitation, CITES (the convention which regulates international trade in endangered species) transferred all eight species to Appendix I, the highest level of protection a species can receive which bans all international trade. Yet the onslaught continues. Now, with the four Asian species driven to near extinction, Africa's pangolins are facing increased pressure to feed the growing demand in Asia.

There is an urgent need to increase conservation action and improve international policy to protect these highly threatened animals. Part of this critical need is to improve our ecological knowledge of the eight species, particularly the less studied African species, to understand their population sizes and distribution in the wild. Learning more about pangolins through scientific research will help inform the right actions to ensure their survival.

 

FR : Les huit espèces de pangolins sont menacées par le commerce illégal de leurs écailles et de leur viande. Ces animaux sont braconnés pour leur viande, consommée comme viande de brousse en Afrique ou comme un plat de luxe en Asie, mais ils sont également recherchés pour leur écailles, utilisées dans la médecine traditionnelle asiatique. On estime que plus d'un million de pangolins ont été tués illégalement au cours de la dernière décennie et ces animaux sont devenus l'un des mammifères les plus braconnés au monde. En conséquence, toutes les espèces de pangolins figurent actuellement sur la liste rouge des espèces menacées de l'UICN (l'Union Internationale pour la Conservation de la Nature), et inscrits sur l'annexe I du traité international CITES (le plus haut niveau de protection internationale accordé par ce traité).  Pourtant, le trafic continue. Alors que les quatre espèces asiatiques sont au bord de l'extinction, les pangolins africains doivent affronter une demande en hausse pour répondre à la demande asiatique.

Il est urgent d'engager des actions en matières de conservation de ces espèces et d'améliorer les stratégies internationales pour protéger ces animaux hautement menacés. Pour ce faire, il est primordial d'améliorer notre connaissance de ces huit espèces, surtout des pangolins africains, qui sont les moins étudiés. Pour aider les pangolins, nous devons en savoir plus sur la taille de leur population ou encore leur répartition dans la nature. La recherche scientifique permettra d'établir les bonnes actions à mener pour la survie de ces espèces.

 

What is the Sangha Pangolin Project?
Qu'est-ce que le Sangha Pangolin Project ?

ENG: The Sangha Pangolin Project is a scientific research project based in the Central African Republic, which was founded in 2014 by South African couple Rod and Tamar Cassidy. The Project is situated in an area of lowland semi-evergreen forest within the Sangha Lodge concession, located in the Dzanga Sangha Protected Area. With their shared passion for conservation and love for pangolins, the couple has been collecting information on three of the four African pangolins since 2009, particularly on the elusive black-bellied pangolins. This species spends most of their lives high up in the dense canopy of trees, making them very difficult to find and monitor. As a result, black-bellied pangolins are the least studied and, therefore, the least understood of all the African pangolins. The Sangha Pangolin Project is trying to change that through ongoing research. Swiss veterinarian, Dr. Maja Gudehus, joined the team in 2017 and has since worked tirelessly to develop the project into what it is today.

 

Sangha Pangolin Project's efforts focus on three critical areas:

  • Research: Advancing ecological research on released black-bellied pangolins through daily monitoring and data collection.
  • Rehabilitation: The rehabilitation and release of injured pangolins (and other wildlife), mainly rescued from the bushmeat trade.
  • Communities/Awareness: Working to include the local community by employing six Ba'aka trackers, who use their keen knowledge of the forest to help the project. Also, promoting awareness and increasing knowledge about pangolins in nearby villages through a sensibilization campaign and local radio broadcasts.

 

In late 2017, through generous donations, the Sangha Pangolin Project was able to build a 'pangolarium' and a small veterinary clinic in order to treat and rehabilitate rescued pangolins and other wildlife in the surrounding area. With the help of dedicated volunteers and locals, the Sangha Pangolin Project has received and treated a total of 95 pangolins to date! We are committed to continuing our mission of saving as many as possible.

 

 

FR : Le Sangha Pangolin Project est un programme de recherche scientifique créé en 2014 par Rod et Tamar Cassidy. Installés en République Centrafricaine depuis 2009, ce couple de passionnés de la nature a commencé à collecter des données sur les espèces de pangolins présents dans la zone de Bayanga, plus spécifiquement sur le pangolin à longue queue, le plus rare des quatre pangolins d'Afrique et l'espèce la moins connue à ce jour. Cette espèce passe la plupart de son temps en hauteur, dans la danse canopée, ce qui la rend plus difficile à trouver et à surveille. Ainsi  les pangolins a longue queue sont les pangolins les moins étudiés et les moins connus des quatre espèces africaines. Le Sangha Pangolin Project souhaite remédier à cette situation en poursuivant ses recherches. Le docteur Maja Gudehus a rejoint l'équipe en 2017 et travaille depuis sans relâche au développement de ce projet.

Le Sangha Pangolin Project se consentre sur trois axes principaux :

  • La collecte d'informations écologiques sur le pangolin à longue queue ;
  • Le soin et la réintroduction dans la forêt d'animaux blessés, des pangolins en premier lieu mais aussi de perroquet, porc-épic, civette, genette, céphalophe, écureuil et autres animaux de la zone ;
  • La collaboration avec les communautés locales en employant six pisteurs Ba'aka mais aussi via un programme de sensibilisation comprenant la réalisation d'émissions de radio ou la tenur de réunions d'informations à travers les villages des environs.

 

Fin 2017, grâce à des dons, le Sangha Pangolin Project a pu ouvrir un 'pangolarium' et une petite clinique vétérinaire. Avec l'aide de volontaires et des locaux, le programme a déjà pu venir en aide à 95 pangolins et souhaite en protéger autant que possible à l'avenir.

 

Meet our team
Découvrez notre équipe

 

Our research and what we need
Notre projet et ce que nous avons besoin

 

ENG: Sangha Pangolin Project is looking to finance new scientific research. We want to assess the population of pangolins and which species are living in the surrounding concession area (640 km²), so that we can better protect them. The baseline information collected from this survey will be critical to informing our work, as it will help us monitor any changes in the pangolin populations over time. In order to conduct this study, our trackers need the right field equipment, such as shoes for trekking, raincoats, waterbottles and tents, so that they can work in good conditions. Also needed are proper tech equipment, things like GPS devices, walkie-talkies, a computer, an external hard drive, and writing materials so that we can collect, store and analyse data effectively.

 

FR : Le Sangha Pangolin Project souhaite financer un nouveau projet de recherche scientifique afin de recenser la population de pangolins vivant dans la zone protégée autour de l'écolodge (640 km²). Pour pouvoir mener cette étude, nous avons besoin d'équipement tels des chaussures, des imperméables et des tentes pour que les pisteurs puissent travailler dans de bonnes conditions, ainsi que des GPS, un ordinateur, un disque dur externe, des talkie-walkies, du matériel pour prendre des notes, etc., afin que nous puissions collecter, stocker et étudier les données recueillies sur les pangolins.

 

How will we use your donations?
Comment seront utilisés vos dons ?

 

ENG: Your donations will help us finance all the equipment we need in order to conduct the survey. You can consult the listing of the equipment as well as pricing in the following chart:

FR : Vos dons serviront à financer l’équipement nécessaire au recensement de la population de pangolin. Vous pouvez consulter la liste des équipements, ainsi que les prix dans le tableau suivant:

 

What you get
Ce que vous recevez

ENG: Here’s a detailed chart on all perks available on this campaign. Please note that since our project is located in a remote part of the tropical forest, shipping is a challenge and also costly. As a result, most of our perks, such as the Ba'aka drawings, are digital and physical gifts can only be offered for the larger donations:

FR : Voici un tableau détaillant les récompenses proposées pour cette campagne - veuillez noter que, compte tenu de notre localisation, au milieu de la forêt tropicale, l’envoi de récompenses est compliqué. En conséquence, quelques récompenses sont au format numérique, comme ces dessins faits par les Ba'aka, et les récompenses physiques ne sont proposées qu’à partir des paliers les plus importants :

 

Other ways you can help
D'autres manières de nous soutenir

 

ENG: First and foremost, you can support us by sharing this project with others in your network. This will help us reach a wider audience - people we might not otherwise access - which would make an enormous difference for us. Most people have never heard of pangolins, and we want to change that. So, even the simple act of talking about pangolins with your friends and family, especially you've learned through our campaign, would have a positive impact. Small ripples can change the tide!

 

FR : En premier lieu, vous pouvez nous soutenir en partageant ce projet avec votre réseau. En partageant notre projet, vous nous aidez à atteindre une audience à laquelle nous n'aurions pas accès autrement. Cela fait toute la différence pour nous !
Vous pouvez également parler des pangolins à vos amis et à votre famille, pour nous aider à faire connaître cet animal. Une grande partie de la population mondiale n'a simplement jamais entendu parler des pangolins et nous voulons changer ça. Plus ils seront connus, et plus nous serons capable de les sauver.

 

They're talking about us!
Ils parlent de nous!

 

South China Morning Post article: their article / leur article (eng)

'Eye of the Pangolin' documentary: their documentary / leur documentaire (eng)

 

Stay in touch and follow us
Restez connectés et suivez-nous

 

Our website / Notre site : http://sanghalodge.com/sangha-pangolin-project/the-project

Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/PangolinProject/

Instagram : https://www.instagram.com/sanghapangolinproject/

Twitter : https://twitter.com/SanghaPangolin

 

Thank you and see you soon! Merci et À bientôt !
story_txt:
What is a pangolin?Qu'est-ce qu'un pangolin ?

 

 
ENG: Pangolins are truly fascinating, unique animals. They have existed on earth for over 80 million years and yet they could disappear before most people even know they exist. There are eight species in total - four in Asia and four in Africa - and sadly all are threatened with extinction. Poached for their meat and scales, which are mainly destined for Asia, pangolins are considered the most trafficked mammals in the world. These 'scaly anteaters' regulate ant and termite populations, playing an important role in maintaining balance in the ecosystems they inhabit, yet we still have much more to learn about them.
 
FR : Les pangolins sont des mammifères uniques. Présents depuis plus de 80 millions d'années sur la planète, ils pourraient disparaître avant même que la plupart des gens entende parler d'eux. Braconnés pour leur viande et leurs écailles, ils sont aujourd'hui menacés d'extinction. Il existe huit espèces de pangolins : quatre en Asie et quatre en Afrique. Tous se nourrissent de fourmis et de termites et jouent un rôle primordial dans l'équilibre des écosystèmes où ils vivent.
 
Why are pangolins under threat?Pourquoi les pangolins sont-ils menacés ?
 ENG: All eight species of pangolin are threatened by the illegal trade in their meat and scales. Pangolins are poached for their meat, which is consumed locally as bushmeat as well as a luxury dish in Asian countries, and scales, which are prized as an ingredient in traditional Asian medicines. It is estimated that more than 1 million pangolins have been taken from the wild in the last decade, making them one of the most trafficked mammals on the planet. In recognition of this overexploitation, CITES (the convention which regulates international trade in endangered species) transferred all eight species to Appendix I, the highest level of protection a species can receive which bans all international trade. Yet the onslaught continues. Now, with the four Asian species driven to near extinction, Africa's pangolins are facing increased pressure to feed the growing demand in Asia.There is an urgent need to increase conservation action and improve international policy to protect these highly threatened animals. Part of this critical need is to improve our ecological knowledge of the eight species, particularly the less studied African species, to understand their population sizes and distribution in the wild. Learning more about pangolins through scientific research will help inform the right actions to ensure their survival. FR : Les huit espèces de pangolins sont menacées par le commerce illégal de leurs écailles et de leur viande. Ces animaux sont braconnés pour leur viande, consommée comme viande de brousse en Afrique ou comme un plat de luxe en Asie, mais ils sont également recherchés pour leur écailles, utilisées dans la médecine traditionnelle asiatique. On estime que plus d'un million de pangolins ont été tués illégalement au cours de la dernière décennie et ces animaux sont devenus l'un des mammifères les plus braconnés au monde. En conséquence, toutes les espèces de pangolins figurent actuellement sur la liste rouge des espèces menacées de l'UICN (l'Union Internationale pour la Conservation de la Nature), et inscrits sur l'annexe I du traité international CITES (le plus haut niveau de protection internationale accordé par ce traité).  Pourtant, le trafic continue. Alors que les quatre espèces asiatiques sont au bord de l'extinction, les pangolins africains doivent affronter une demande en hausse pour répondre à la demande asiatique.Il est urgent d'engager des actions en matières de conservation de ces espèces et d'améliorer les stratégies internationales pour protéger ces animaux hautement menacés. Pour ce faire, il est primordial d'améliorer notre connaissance de ces huit espèces, surtout des pangolins africains, qui sont les moins étudiés. Pour aider les pangolins, nous devons en savoir plus sur la taille de leur population ou encore leur répartition dans la nature. La recherche scientifique permettra d'établir les bonnes actions à mener pour la survie de ces espèces. 
What is the Sangha Pangolin Project?Qu'est-ce que le Sangha Pangolin Project ?
ENG: The Sangha Pangolin Project is a scientific research project based in the Central African Republic, which was founded in 2014 by South African couple Rod and Tamar Cassidy. The Project is situated in an area of lowland semi-evergreen forest within the Sangha Lodge concession, located in the Dzanga Sangha Protected Area. With their shared passion for conservation and love for pangolins, the couple has been collecting information on three of the four African pangolins since 2009, particularly on the elusive black-bellied pangolins. This species spends most of their lives high up in the dense canopy of trees, making them very difficult to find and monitor. As a result, black-bellied pangolins are the least studied and, therefore, the least understood of all the African pangolins. The Sangha Pangolin Project is trying to change that through ongoing research. Swiss veterinarian, Dr. Maja Gudehus, joined the team in 2017 and has since worked tirelessly to develop the project into what it is today. Sangha Pangolin Project's efforts focus on three critical areas:

Research: Advancing ecological research on released black-bellied pangolins through daily monitoring and data collection.

Rehabilitation: The rehabilitation and release of injured pangolins (and other wildlife), mainly rescued from the bushmeat trade.

Communities/Awareness: Working to include the local community by employing six Ba'aka trackers, who use their keen knowledge of the forest to help the project. Also, promoting awareness and increasing knowledge about pangolins in nearby villages through a sensibilization campaign and local radio broadcasts.
 In late 2017, through generous donations, the Sangha Pangolin Project was able to build a 'pangolarium' and a small veterinary clinic in order to treat and rehabilitate rescued pangolins and other wildlife in the surrounding area. With the help of dedicated volunteers and locals, the Sangha Pangolin Project has received and treated a total of 95 pangolins to date! We are committed to continuing our mission of saving as many as possible.  FR : Le Sangha Pangolin Project est un programme de recherche scientifique créé en 2014 par Rod et Tamar Cassidy. Installés en République Centrafricaine depuis 2009, ce couple de passionnés de la nature a commencé à collecter des données sur les espèces de pangolins présents dans la zone de Bayanga, plus spécifiquement sur le pangolin à longue queue, le plus rare des quatre pangolins d'Afrique et l'espèce la moins connue à ce jour. Cette espèce passe la plupart de son temps en hauteur, dans la danse canopée, ce qui la rend plus difficile à trouver et à surveille. Ainsi  les pangolins a longue queue sont les pangolins les moins étudiés et les moins connus des quatre espèces africaines. Le Sangha Pangolin Project souhaite remédier à cette situation en poursuivant ses recherches. Le docteur Maja Gudehus a rejoint l'équipe en 2017 et travaille depuis sans relâche au développement de ce projet.Le Sangha Pangolin Project se consentre sur trois axes principaux :
La collecte d'informations écologiques sur le pangolin à longue queue ;
Le soin et la réintroduction dans la forêt d'animaux blessés, des pangolins en premier lieu mais aussi de perroquet, porc-épic, civette, genette, céphalophe, écureuil et autres animaux de la zone ;
La collaboration avec les communautés locales en employant six pisteurs Ba'aka mais aussi via un programme de sensibilisation comprenant la réalisation d'émissions de radio ou la tenur de réunions d'informations à travers les villages des environs.
 Fin 2017, grâce à des dons, le Sangha Pangolin Project a pu ouvrir un 'pangolarium' et une petite clinique vétérinaire. Avec l'aide de volontaires et des locaux, le programme a déjà pu venir en aide à 95 pangolins et souhaite en protéger autant que possible à l'avenir. 
Meet our teamDécouvrez notre équipe

 ENG: Sangha Pangolin Project is looking to finance new scientific research. We want to assess the population of pangolins and which species are living in the surrounding concession area (640 km²), so that we can better protect them. The baseline information collected from this survey will be critical to informing our work, as it will help us monitor any changes in the pangolin populations over time. In order to conduct this study, our trackers need the right field equipment, such as shoes for trekking, raincoats, waterbottles and tents, so that they can work in good conditions. Also needed are proper tech equipment, things like GPS devices, walkie-talkies, a computer, an external hard drive, and writing materials so that we can collect, store and analyse data effectively. FR : Le Sangha Pangolin Project souhaite financer un nouveau projet de recherche scientifique afin de recenser la population de pangolins vivant dans la zone protégée autour de l'écolodge (640 km²). Pour pouvoir mener cette étude, nous avons besoin d'équipement tels des chaussures, des imperméables et des tentes pour que les pisteurs puissent travailler dans de bonnes conditions, ainsi que des GPS, un ordinateur, un disque dur externe, des talkie-walkies, du matériel pour prendre des notes, etc., afin que nous puissions collecter, stocker et étudier les données recueillies sur les pangolins. 
How will we use your donations?Comment seront utilisés vos dons ?
 ENG: Your donations will help us finance all the equipment we need in order to conduct the survey. You can consult the listing of the equipment as well as pricing in the following chart:FR : Vos dons serviront à financer l’équipement nécessaire au recensement de la population de pangolin. Vous pouvez consulter la liste des équipements, ainsi que les prix dans le tableau suivant: 
What you getCe que vous recevez
ENG: Here’s a detailed chart on all perks available on this campaign. Please note that since our project is located in a remote part of the tropical forest, shipping is a challenge and also costly. As a result, most of our perks, such as the Ba'aka drawings, are digital and physical gifts can only be offered for the larger donations:FR : Voici un tableau détaillant les récompenses proposées pour cette campagne - veuillez noter que, compte tenu de notre localisation, au milieu de la forêt tropicale, l’envoi de récompenses est compliqué. En conséquence, quelques récompenses sont au format numérique, comme ces dessins faits par les Ba'aka, et les récompenses physiques ne sont proposées qu’à partir des paliers les plus importants : 
Other ways you can helpD'autres manières de nous soutenir
 ENG: First and foremost, you can support us by sharing this project with others in your network. This will help us reach a wider audience - people we might not otherwise access - which would make an enormous difference for us. Most people have never heard of pangolins, and we want to change that. So, even the simple act of talking about pangolins with your friends and family, especially you've learned through our campaign, would have a positive impact. Small ripples can change the tide! FR : En premier lieu, vous pouvez nous soutenir en partageant ce projet avec votre réseau. En partageant notre projet, vous nous aidez à atteindre une audience à laquelle nous n'aurions pas accès autrement. Cela fait toute la différence pour nous !Vous pouvez également parler des pangolins à vos amis et à votre famille, pour nous aider à faire connaître cet animal. Une grande partie de la population mondiale n'a simplement jamais entendu parler des pangolins et nous voulons changer ça. Plus ils seront connus, et plus nous serons capable de les sauver.

story:
The Situation

In sub-Saharan Africa, it is estimated that 70% of the population does not have access to reliable grid power (UN 2013).  This means that in many cases the doors to learning, healthcare, business and agriculture are closed, resulting in economic hardship and dependence on first world support.  In addition, the reliance on fossil fuels becomes enormous, as fossil fuels are used for power generation, heating, lighting and cooking.  Apart from the environmental and health damage caused by the use of these fossil fuels, the rising costs and lack of availability of these fuels further inhibit the development of basic services and community self-reliance.  Why this reliance on fossil fuels in the part of the world that has the highest average daily sunshine in the world?


The Solution

The Greenerator Solar Generators!  These generators use the latest in solar technology to capture that abundant sunshine, convert it to electricity, store it in batteries and make it available as mains power via inverters.  The units are completely scalable meaning that there will be the right sized solar generator for any application.  The Greenerator generators can be semi-permanent, container based units or, for total flexibility, can be vehicle or trailer based enabling access to even the darkest corners of Southern Africa.  Whether you need to run sensitive medical equipment for a mobile clinic, power a small business or community, run a pump for water supply or irrigation or just need to keep your computer server room running during power outages, the Greenerator solar generator is your ideal partner.


The Benefits

Due to the fact that the solar generators are harnessing the sun’s energy, it is a completely clean and environmentally friendly power source.  Apart from the sun, there are no consumables, so having to source expensive fuels in remote locations is a thing of the past. Greenerator solar generators can be mobile, vehicle mounted units or placed in a fixed location.

The Greenerator generators:

·  Have no moving parts, so maintenance and running costs are minimal

·  Have components guaranteed for up to 10 years, so users are ensured of many      years of trouble free power. 

·  Are completely silent

·  Emit no fumes, and

·  The power produced is 100% clean power enabling the most sensitive equipment to be run with no fear of voltage drops or brown-outs!


The Status

For three years the Greenerator team has been extensively researching this concept to assess its viability and practicality in the Southern African environment.  Our engineers have researched the latest solar power technology and its compatibility with the harsh African environment and have come up with a winning combination of PV panels, chargers, batteries and inverters.  In addition, our launch is perfectly timed to coincide with the arrival of Tesla power products in South Africa which are game-changers for our target applications. 

We have also extensively canvassed our potential user base and, across the board, have had an overwhelmingly positive response.  In such diverse markets as healthcare, education, agriculture, small to medium businesses, municipal entities, events, film, extreme sports and emergency and rescue services, the response to the concept has been unanimously positive!

Now we need your support to build a range of prototypes to demonstrate the life changing benefits of the Greenerator to the people of Southern Africa.  Because this technology is so unknown in this part of the world, people naturally want to see it in action.  Your contribution can make this a reality and change the lives of thousands of people in Africa!


The Perks

1.   For supporters based in Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe:

·  Any contribution greater than $1000.00 will give you use of a Greenerator Solar Powered Generator for a day (excluding travel costs, carnet costs and subject to availability), a stylish, limited edition Greenerator t-shirt in recognition of your support and recognition on our supporters’ wall.

·  Any contribution of $150.00 or more will receive a stylish, limited edition Greenerator t-shirt in recognition of your support and recognition on our supporters’ wall.

2.  For supporters elsewhere in the world…….:

·  Any contribution of $150.00 or more will receive a stylish, limited edition Greenerator t-shirt in recognition of your support and recognition on our supporters’ wall.

In addition, if we reach our Stretch Goal with your support, we commit to donate  Greenerator Solar Powered Generators to needy communities of our choice.

Bring power to the people of Africa and change thousands of lives! 

Support Greenerator!

story:
Send Shua to the Finger Lakes Permaculture Institute

Hey there interwebs, Shua here. You might know me from my blog, Poor Backyard Beddie's Almanac: Experiments in Low-Cost Suburban MicroFarming, or from the farmer's market, or maybe we garden together or might in the future.

I've been offered a Work-Study at the Finger Lakes Permaculture Institute where, in exchange for helping with camp build-out and take-down, I can earn my Permaculture Design Certificate at a reduced cost.

I've been a student of permaculture for several years and have used what I've learned so far to help members of my community establish affordable, low-maintenance organic gardens.  The Work-Study will immerse me in permaculture, allow me to learn from more experienced teachers & other students all while camping out in the midst of an established off-grid permaculture homestead.  

With your help I can travel up to New York state and learn valuable skills that I can bring back home.  I believe this experience will help me to crystallize that knowledge into a teachable form that I can offer to our community, thus furthering my quest to foster cooperative local food systems.

What I Need To Get There

I'd say that I'm dirt poor, but my soil's too rich. The life of an itinerant yard farmer isn't the most lucrative profession though so I need help to get there. The reduced tuition cost for the Permaculture Design Certificate course is $700, plus I'll need to get myself up to Ithaca, NY, feed myself for the 2 weeks before the course begins, arrange for someone to tend my garden & lil flock of hens, and cover my rent and bills while I''m not earning income for a month.

If I reach my goal, I'll be golden for the trip.  If I exceed the goal, then I'll put the excess funds towards one of Backyard Beddie's upcoming projects: either a potting mix made entirely from renewable resources (no peat or vermiculite/perlite) or the solar-powered compost tea brewer. If I don't reach the goal, all the funds I do receive will go towards getting me up there, and I'll make it work somehow.

I don't expect something for nothing though, so I'm offering several perks for help from my local community (see www.backyardbeddies.com for my local radius map).

$25: An assortment of plants for your fall/winter garden. There will be a good mix of veggies, herbs & perennial medicinals.

$75: An hour-long education session from my upcoming Gardening From Scratch curriculum: you can choose either Understanding Microclimates to Help Your Garden Grow, Discovering Dirt: Soil-Stewardship & No-Till Techniques, or Home-Scale Composting.

$100: A site visit and a visioning session where we can address how to use the space in your yard to optimize the production of food, medicine & habitat.

$200: when I return with my Permaculture Design Certificate, we'll get together and develop a design for your home to suit your needs. We'll create a master plan & a project timeline and you'll get a 10% discount on any products or services I offer: plants, compost/mulch delivery, installation, etc.
story_txt:
Send Shua to the Finger Lakes Permaculture Institute
Hey there interwebs, Shua here. You might know me from my blog, Poor Backyard Beddie's Almanac: Experiments in Low-Cost Suburban MicroFarming, or from the farmer's market, or maybe we garden together or might in the future.
I've been offered a Work-Study at the Finger Lakes Permaculture Institute where, in exchange for helping with camp build-out and take-down, I can earn my Permaculture Design Certificate at a reduced cost.
I've been a student of permaculture for several years and have used what I've learned so far to help members of my community establish affordable, low-maintenance organic gardens.  The Work-Study will immerse me in permaculture, allow me to learn from more experienced teachers & other students all while camping out in the midst of an established off-grid permaculture homestead.  
With your help I can travel up to New York state and learn valuable skills that I can bring back home.  I believe this experience will help me to crystallize that knowledge into a teachable form that I can offer to our community, thus furthering my quest to foster cooperative local food systems.
What I Need To Get There
I'd say that I'm dirt poor, but my soil's too rich. The life of an itinerant yard farmer isn't the most lucrative profession though so I need help to get there. The reduced tuition cost for the Permaculture Design Certificate course is $700, plus I'll need to get myself up to Ithaca, NY, feed myself for the 2 weeks before the course begins, arrange for someone to tend my garden & lil flock of hens, and cover my rent and bills while I''m not earning income for a month.
If I reach my goal, I'll be golden for the trip.  If I exceed the goal, then I'll put the excess funds towards one of Backyard Beddie's upcoming projects: either a potting mix made entirely from renewable resources (no peat or vermiculite/perlite) or the solar-powered compost tea brewer. If I don't reach the goal, all the funds I do receive will go towards getting me up there, and I'll make it work somehow.
I don't expect something for nothing though, so I'm offering several perks for help from my local community (see www.backyardbeddies.com for my local radius map).
$25: An assortment of plants for your fall/winter garden. There will be a good mix of veggies, herbs & perennial medicinals.
$75: An hour-long education session from my upcoming Gardening From Scratch curriculum: you can choose either Understanding Microclimates to Help Your Garden Grow, Discovering Dirt: Soil-Stewardship & No-Till Techniques, or Home-Scale Composting.
$100: A site visit and a visioning session where we can address how to use the space in your yard to optimize the production of food, medicine & habitat.
$200: when I return with my Permaculture Design Certificate, we'll get together and develop a design for your home to suit your needs. We'll create a master plan & a project timeline and you'll get a 10% discount on any products or services I offer: plants, compost/mulch delivery, installation, etc.

story:
Earthship Biotecture is teaming up with a local NGO, Empower Malawi, to build a self-sustainable "Flower Design" building as a community center this October... AND I’M TRYING TO BE THERE!! 

My name is Emily and I work for Earthship Biotecture in Taos, New Mexico.  I’ve known about this event since March but have remained undecided, until now.  I’m a little scared of getting vaccination shots and I know it won’t be easy getting my shifts covered, but the pros have outweighed those two little cons.  Having never yet left the country at 23 years old, I’ve realized how great it’ll be for me to visit a developing country as my first excursion outside the States.  I feel such an experience will give me a greater appreciation for what I have here. 

The Earthship Flower Design is similar to a structure built in Sierra Leone, Africa by the Earthship crew in 2011.  Two of the eight rooms (petals of the flower) will be constructed in the days we are on site.  In that time we'll also be teaching the 38 local tribes how to finish their community center.  The building site is in southeast Mzimba, an area that is sparsely populated and surrounded by agricultural fields.  The construction will start on October 7th and end on the 19th.  We will be flying in and out of Lilongwe, which is about a 4 hour drive from the job site.

Each volunteer going must raise their own $1,000 for the project (which funds the providing/shipping of building materials, and tools which we'll leave with them) along with paying their own plane ticket (roundtrip to Africa is roughly between $1,500 to $2,000), which explains my goal amount. 

Earthship's previous nonprofit out-of-country builds--the Andaman Islands, Guatemala, Haiti, and many more--are inspiring to say the least.  Watching the videos of my coworkers' emotional experiences with these people who are so grateful for their knowledge, and need their help so desperately, is intensely memorable.  Viewers can easily notice the bond between the crew and community members, regardless of the language barrier and endless other societal differences.  I aspire to create my own touching film, capturing the Malawi build on my Sony Handycam and using Final Cut X.

The below video is of the Haiti build:

 Here is Guatemala:


The Andaman Islands:


And in this last video you'll meet the people of Malawi and how their current buildings look...


PLEASE HELP ME HELP THEM !!

story:
My name is Cameron, and I am soon to embark on an adventure of a lifetime. I have been practicing yoga for 10 years. For me, yoga is mindful engagement with myself and others, it is a practice that connects me to my innate wisdom. Following my dreams to live my yoga practice at a yoga institute has given me the courage to undertake an epic adventure to challenge and expand myself. April through October 2014, I will hike the entire Appalachian Trail!

Why would I want to hike 2,186 miles through 14 states?

To see if I can! I am doing this because it's what my intuition is telling me to do. Yoga has taught me that the more deeply I see myself, the more deeply I see the world. Hiking the Appalachian Trail is a meditation to expand and empower myself. I am a spiritual seeker. I long to take my practice deep into the forests and learn from nature as yogis have done for thousands of years. 

This is my dream. My (one way!) plane ticket to the southern start of the trail in Georgia is purchased. I am doing this. However I won't be able to finish without support. 

I need your help

Although the hike is a long walk in the woods, it takes money.
Through Hikers (people who hike the whole trail at one time) spend between $5,000-$8,000 on gear, food, and town visits.

I have saved up by teaching over 1,500 yoga classes but not
enough to make this dream come true.

Your donations will help pay for supplies, food, hostels and other
essentials that wilderness travel requires. The average hiker wears through 3 pairs of boots!

Perks of Donating to my trail-

For $10: I will write you a post card while on the trail

For $25: I will send you a personalized letter and photo from
the trail.

For $50: I will send you a transcription of part my trail journal
after I've completed the hike.

For $75:  Reiki is the ancient Japanese healing technique of channeling energy for emotional and physical well being. This practice can be done from any distance. I am a certified level two Reiki practitioner, soon to be Reiki Master (getting my final attunement March 6th) with 3 years of experience. Effects of receiving Reiki are vast, most prominent is a feeling of relaxation and contentedness. I will schedule a time with you or someone of your choosing to receive 30 minutes of Reiki. You can continue on with your day while I send you Reiki or it be schedule for when you are in yoga or meditation practice. 

For $100: I will send you a personalized letter with stories from the trail and 3 photos
from my adventure.

How my hiking the Appalachian Trail will serve others

I started practicing yoga when I was 13 and took my first yoga teacher training at 18. Through the teacher training I found my purpose is to be of service to others. Change starts from within, when I change myself, I change the world. My epic journey through the Appalachian Trail is about getting to know my authentic self, uncovering my resiliency, learning from the woods and mountains, and growing into my most free expression. As I become more empowered, I can better serve those around me. 

I will be sharing my journey via blog to take you along with me! (Link coming soon).

Also, I will absolutely be leading some yoga classes in the wilderness to my fellow hikers. :) 

Other Ways You Can Help

I deeply appreciate all of the support I have already been
given. Please share this page with others!  I am open to all prayers of encouragement and protection. Thank You!

story:
Dec. 2016: We have recently made significant headway in the legal battle thanks to the assistance of the Animal Legal Defense Fund and a law firm in New York  (Winston & Strawn) who have provided pro bono legal assistance.  After two years of legal process in the appellate Court in Rochester, the case is now heading back to the Holley-area Orleans County Supreme Court for re-consideration.

Most likely we will seek a Temporary Restraining Order to stop the hunt while the matter is considered. If it's denied we can re-appeal that denial. So there is a chance to stop the hunt this year. 

Some new funding is needed to get Richard Brummel, the organizer of this effort, from his home on Long Island to Holley to monitor the court process, possibly organize supplemental legal efforts, and to provide a media presence in case the hunt actually occurs again.

 Richard has already spent a few thousand dollars of his own money on this over the past three years -- car rental, gas, tolls, lodging, legal filings and printing -- to supplement generous contributions given in the past as well. His website is Planet-in-Peril.org.

Thanks. 

-- Richard Brummel, (516) 238-1646, rxbrummel (AT) gmail (DOT) com.

story:
This is the banner I designed for COP23 to showcase the power of collaboration. Each logo you see represents a company that has sponsored us, or an organization that shares our willingness to collaborate on solutions. We focused on Project Drawdown this year because of their powerful body of work that leads the way to genuine hope at a time when we need it most.

And, I took on the role of producing an event for Drawdown at COP23, that opened new eyes – organizational eyes – to the many solutions we have available.

OUR BACKSTORY...

The iGiveTrees campaign has been supported by global citizens spanning 5 continents since 2009. We are responsible for 6,000 trees being planted at a size, and in a manner, that is conducive to their growth, rather than just being statistics that die off within months due to lack of care. We have respected the dignity, wisdom and value of every person involved in the process, from seed harvesters, to nurserymen, to organizational partners, to subsistence farmers.

 

In 2016, iGiveTrees was recognized as one of “100 Projects for the Climate” by the French Ministry of the Environment, and was invited to participate in the climate change conference, COP22. Since then we have been scaling our future reach with support from the French organization, OpenTeam.

In 2017, when the research of Project Drawdown was released, I discovered that we were already engaged with 3 of the Top 15 solutions to global warming.

To increase our capacity to plant native species tropical staple tree crops in 2018, we are collaborating with a Brazilian agroforestry training center to help a new generation of environmental entrepreneurs learn how to effectively plant urban food forests in the city of São Paulo.

  

Your support allows us to continue planting and maintaining native species trees organically, while supporting local communities. The trees we gift back to the Earth are maintained by local people for two years, to insure their survival in the field.

My name is Alana Lea, creator of the iGiveTrees project. Through trial and error, over the last eight years, we've discovered a way to restore real hope. With your funding partership, I've been able to give trees to small Brazilian communities through their local NGOs. In turn, they are improving the soil, replanting an endangered rainforest to restore biodiversity, produce more oxygen, rebalance water systems,  and sink more carbon for the benefit of the whole planet.

 

 

These days, I'm confident that we've made a positive impact by directly supporting small local, organic, rural organizations, instead of the Big International NGOs (BINGOs) that accept funding from agrochemical companies, then teach people to use toxic chemicals to keep their donors happy. These BINGOs also fund environmental education, while requiring the use of herbicides when their projects replant the forest. Nature's balance is once again being destroyed, by those methods.

Small local NGOs are in the ideal position to distribute saplings to farmers who want to revitalize land and water, without being obligated to apply herbicides to the new forests, by benefactors who accept funding from multinational agrochemical companies.

Since 2009 the iGiveTrees campaign has crowdfunded 6,000 trees that were given to the people of the Atlantic Rainforest just by sharing our story on a few blogs and videos. That was R&D - research and development - to discover what works. And even more important, what doesn't work. Informed by experience, we're now motivated to do hundreds of times more with new field partners who have proven commitment to the process, while needing help to achieve their planting goals.
 

Most of the trees we've given back to the Atlantic Forest since 2010 have been planted in  the Vale do Paraiba, São Paulo state. Have a look at this historic photo to see the area, as it appeared in the 1882. We see slaves working in a coffee plantation. Descendants of some of these people are now subsistence farm families,  receiving trees to heal the spirit of both people and the land, while renewing their water sources.

 

 

Here's how the project began...

 
When I learned that 93% of the Brazilian rainforest where I was born had disappeared in my lifetime, I was shocked into action. So I found people who knew more about the land than I did, and together we started a reforestation project. 

 


Over several years, I teamed up with a network of sustainable seed harvesters, small NGOs and subsistence farm families who now live on barren land that was once a lush rainforest. They want to replant their land, without adding toxic chemicals to their groundwater, as they're being taught to do by certain entities.
 

 

In some of the areas we've helped plant in the past years, residents are challenged by the eucalyptus plantations (for paper pulp) that work with agrochemical companies, and their green gloved NGO partners who approve of planting genetically engineered trees, sprayed with toxic herbicides. 

 

 

Once abundant water sources were sucked dry by thirsty, fast-growing, eucalyptus trees, contributing to epic droughts, while pollinators die, and remaining water supplies are contaminated by glyphosate, now recognized as a carcinogen by the World Health Organization.

By contrast, when we give rural families a gift of organically grown, native species trees, they renew the life of the rainforest to benefit us all.

Together, we are renewing the planet's precious natural resources for our kids.

 

And, we're proud of our results! Most tree planting projects are planting seedlings in fields then walking away, hoping they'll grow without further care. Unfortunately, quite often the baby trees die from lack of water, being overgrown by grasses or trampling within months, while the planting project claims BIG NUMBERS of the trees they planted. Not us.

Have a look at just a few pictures of two year growth reports for trees planted through our project in 2011. OUR TREES GROW!!!

 

 

Since our beginning, the project has attracted a global community of supporters: Michael Bernard Beckwith (featured in "The Secret" and founder of Agape International Spiritual Center), Rickie Byars Beckwith (founder of the Agape International Choir), Caroline MacDougall (Teecino founder), DC Cordova (CEO of Money and You), Deborah Koff-Chapin (founder of the Touch Drawing Center), Katherine Woodward Thomas (author of "Calling in The One" and "Conscious Uncoupling"), Marie Diamond (featured in "The Secret"), Martin Dunkerton (author of "Awakening Your Riches"), Ryan Eliason (creator of the Social Entrepreneur Empowerment series), George Kao (creator of the Enlightened Business Bootcamp), Steve Bhaerman (a.k.a. Swami Beyondananda, co-author of "Spontaneous Evolution: Our Positive Future"), Vicki Robin (author of "Your Money or Your Life"), Natalie Ledwell (co-creator of Mind Movies), Sylvie Rokab (director of "Love Thy Nature") Daniel Nahmod (of Humanity Music Co.) and Nimo (Empty Hands Music), Nutiva, Dr. Bronner's and the French Ministry of the Environment, Energy and the Sea  are among them.

 

NOW we invite YOU to join us...
 

Our reforestation project supports global cooling, the return of wildlife and Nature's biodiversity. And our hundreds of species of tropical trees have a better chance of growing to maturity, faster, able to sink more carbon than trees planted in the backyards of the Northern Hemisphere OR Genetically Modified trees.
 

Your non-tax-deductible "crowdfunding" donations here on Indiegogo make the purchase and distribution of these trees possible, at no cost to the recipients, through social enterprise and non-profit partnerships. If you'd prefer to make a US tax-deductible contribution, please do so through our fiscal sponsor. We work directly with small, local NGO partners in the community who are focused on teaching organic agroforestry methods in targeted areas of need.
 

 

 

 

Our new goal is to start an urban landscaping service in the city of São Paulo, planting small food forests, using the proven models of Afforestt, to help sustain tree donations to subsistence farm families. 

Native species trees replanted in Brazil benefit the entire planet. 
 

 

Welcome to the iGiveTrees global community!

Swami Beyondananda, co-author of "Spontaneous Evolution: Our Positive Future"), Vicki Robin (author of "Your Money or Your Life"), Natalie Ledwell (co-creator of Mind Movies), Sylvie Rokab (director of "Love Thy Nature") Daniel Nahmod (of Humanity Music Co.) and Nimo (Empty Hands Music), Nutiva, Dr. Bronner's and the French Ministry of the Environment, Energy and the Sea  are among them. 
NOW we invite YOU to join us...  Our reforestation project supports global cooling, the return of wildlife and Nature's biodiversity. And our hundreds of species of tropical trees have a better chance of growing to maturity, faster, able to sink more carbon than trees planted in the backyards of the Northern Hemisphere OR Genetically Modified trees. 
Your non-tax-deductible "crowdfunding" donations here on Indiegogo make the purchase and distribution of these trees possible, at no cost to the recipients, through social enterprise and non-profit partnerships. If you'd prefer to make a US tax-deductible contribution, please do so through our fiscal sponsor. We work directly with small, local NGO partners in the community who are focused on teaching organic agroforestry methods in targeted areas of need. 
  

 
Our new goal is to start an urban landscaping service in the city of São Paulo, planting small food forests, using the proven models of Afforestt, to help sustain tree donations to subsistence farm families. 



Native species trees replanted in Brazil benefit the entire planet. 
 


 
Welcome to the iGiveTrees global community!

story:
The Challenge

WE Bike NYC, with the support of Transportation Alternatives, Bicycle Times magazine, Woman Tours, Pearl Izumi, Velojoy and Bike New York is raising funds to sponsor ten female bicycle activists to ride 262 miles from New York City to Washington, DC to represent their communities at the nation’s largest annual bicycle advocacy event: the National Bike Summit.

WE Bike NYC is a group based in New York City open to all women, female identifying, and gender nonconforming people who enjoy biking or think they might. WE Bike NYC aims to break down barriers to cycling by offering social rides, training rides, mechanics workshops and ride scholarships. Representatives from Gearing-Up, Black Women Bike DC, Washington Area Bicyclist Association: Women and Bicycles, and Philadelphia Bicycle Coalition: Women Bike PHL will join WE Bike NYC on this adventure!

While in DC, WE will advocate for women of all backgrounds to have a seat at the table that sets national transportation policy. Despite being woefully under-represented in decision-making, the number of women who commute to work has increased 56% in the last year. Lower income individuals (earning less than $30,000) accounted for 28% of bike trips in 2009 — more than 1.1 billion bike trips overall. Our goal is to support the League of American Bicyclists’ efforts to include underrepresented cyclists at the decision making table through the inclusion of ten voices that would not be able to attend the summit without the financial support generated by this ride.

This trip will be the kickoff event for continued work in 2014 to create more opportunities for women to have a voice in the national cycling and transportation conversation.

On Tuesday, December 17, WE Bike NYC will launch #webiketodc to highlight the importance of increased inclusivity in the cycling community through rider stories, web videos, cycling tips, and sponsored content. Check out our daily updated content here.


The Impact

More women in these crucial conversations call attention to universal issues such as:

  • safer streets and economically inclusive infrastructure

  • more affordable commutes and increased local economic impact

  • girls’ athletic programs

  • leadership development within the cycling community

Our efforts will bring ten new female voices to the table full of new, diverse opinions, ideas and concerns for our transportation future. WE understand that women will soon make up half of the cyclists in the US and that while WE have common goals, WE also represent a myriad of other groups including people of color, low income people, transgender people, new riders, and others often not represented in the national conversation. WE hope to inspire more to come forward with their own priorities and we hope the attention we generate will help them be heard.


What We Need & What You Get

Over half of the $11,000 cost for this purposeful adventure will go towards the registration fees for the summit. After we surmount that substantial barrier, the rest of the money raised will go towards a fully-equipped SAG van (plus gas and tolls) and accommodations for the riders.

To thank you for your contribution and to encourage you to keep riding, we offer a wide range of donor perks:

$15 – Ride Participant

  • Your name on our virtual #webiketodc donor wall.

  • High-five from a member of our ride team. 

$25 – The Sweep  

  • Collection of 5 WE Bike NYC stickers and temporary tattoos

  • Your name on our virtual #webiketodc donor wall.

  • High-five from a member of our ride team.

$50 – Ride Leader Package  

  • Membership fee for a year (stickers, T-shirt, tattoo, membership info/card)

  • 1 year digital subscription to Bicycle Times magazine

  • All the goodies from The Sweep package

$100 – Mechanic Package

  • Thank you shout out on the #webiketoDC blog

  • WE Super Backer Pack (stickers, tattoo, t-shirt, flat-fix kit, bike-repair zine, bike map)

  • The Ride Leader package

$250 – Beryl Burton Package  

  • VIP admission for you and a guest for our annual party

  • WE Bike NYC Thank You video dedicated to you and posted on our #webiketodc blog.

  • The Marianna Vos Package, choice of an additional membership to gift or WE Backer Pack

$500 – Juli Furtado Package  

  • Dedicated/or branded WE Bike NYC happy hour complete with a shiny crown and delicious cake.

  • WE Bike NYC personal ride (you choose the people and the place within the five boroughs, WE plan the route) or specialized mechanics workshop for you and five of your friends (WE will provide beverages and snacks)

  • Beryl Burton Package with two memberships AND one WE Backer Pack 

$750 – Jeannie Longo Package  

  • Personal three-hour bike consulting from our founder, Liz Jose, on matters such as fitting, shopping on Craigslist, basic mechanical upgrades on your bike (parts extra). Some activities are limited by your location, but not all.

  • Partial branding privileges on the van and/or rider.

$1000 – Annie Londonderry Package

  • Branding privileges on the van and/or rider. Please email Email events at webikenyc dot org so we can work it out.

  • Adopt a Rider Pack: Photo of your adopted rider, handwritten postcards from each stop on the ride, series of dedicated video messages filmed at rest stops.

$2500+ -- Janette Sadik-Khan Package  

  • All of the above and more. Email events at webikenyc dot org. Let’s make a deal! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Money definitely opens doors, but there are a ton of other ways you can support us through our ride:

  • Tell your family and friends about our campaign and why biking is important to you.

  • Record that message on an Instagram video or photo, type it into a tweet or status message, and hashtag it #webiketodc.

  • Make us a playlist for the ride! (WE may even make you a dance video if it’s really good!)

  • Come ride with us! Follow our progress through our website and meet up with us when we hit your town.

story:
We plan to undertake an indigenous tree planting project that should result in the existence of 10,000 indigenous trees.


Your contribution to this project will also result in the creation of 50 tempoarary jobs that should last for about a year.


Your contribution will be highly appreciated.


$1=1 Tree


Pls contribute any amount of $1 and above.


Mutinda Kisio
Kwa Vilivo Kisio Indigenous Tree Project
Kwa Mukembi Village
Mitaboni
Machakos - Kenya

story:
This is my loving family

 

We grow olive trees together with love, truly natural.

   

In our laboratory , we create amazingly pure, natural and lovely  organic skin care products, all handmade and based on our purest extra-vergin olive oil. 

 

 

 

We discovered how to turn olive residue into pure natural, eco friendly house hold cleaning products!

Join us in our environmental revolution, let's green clean the world together with our newest and truly organic product.

Join our campaign and together we'll make "Eco Olea" Green Cleaning possible and internationally available!

Thanks for visiting and trusting us,

Avner
CEO - Olea Essence

 

 

For more specific information about the campaign, scroll down a bit more...

 

 

To thank you we created amazing "Perk-Presents" for you, including our pure, natural and lovely organic skin care products! 

$21 - Eco Olea Green 50% Off!


You'll be the first to receive all 3 bottles of the first bio-treated olive vinegar "Eco Olea" Green Cleaning Series, created from the by-product of olive oil production and through the practice of sustainable, organic farming! Safe for children, pets and environment! 50% off the price! $3 instead of $6 a bottle! 3x $3= $9 + $ 12 shipping costs = $21!

   

 

 

$25 - Our Olive Soap Bestseller!

It's our Bestseller! Try our Olea Essence "Olive Wash & Exfoliate", a 3-in-1 face and body wash, scrub, and toner. Gentle enough for everyday use. 500 ml

 

$50 - Sample of our newest cleaning product! (+ $15 Voucher & Olive Soap Bestseller!

Try our newest product as one of the first! We send you a 500 ml sample of our revolutionary, natural, eco friendly house hold cleaning product! You'll receive our Olive Soap Bestseller & a $15 Voucher to spend on the Skin Care products in our Online Shop!

     &    &     

 

 

$ 65 - Mommy & Baby Skin Care

A real treat for mother & baby!
You'll receive the "Soothing Relief" - Rash and Irritation Cream to protect the baby's skin and to calm itch & rash immediately. And you'll get the "Massage & Moisture Oil" to keep both your skin moisturized and flexible. Great for stretchmarks. 

 & 

 

 

$ 95 - Our Skin Care "GoodyBag" 

 

Our Skin Care "GoodyBag", full of our amazing natural, olive oil based skin care products!

- Lip balm with avocado oil
- Hand cream with coconut and tea tree oil
- Body Milk; for a smooth and soft skin
- Our Olive Soap Wash & Scrub 500 ml
- Rejuvenating Face Mask Treatment

    

 

 

$125 Olive Tree Donation & Newest Sample!

Your contribution will help plant one olive tree around the Sea of Galilee, supervised and maintained by the Israeli JNF, Israel's National Forestry Foundation. We will send you an official certification of your olive tree donation and shall email you information about your tree and its location in the field when it is planted!

BONUS: A 500 ml sample of our 100% natural, safe, chemical free house hold cleaning product

 

   &   

 

 

$200 - Voucher of $250 & Newest Sample!

Receive a $250 voucher to spend on our Olea Essence 100% Natural Skin Care products, available online!

BONUS: A 500 ml sample of our 100% natural, safe, chemical free house hold cleaning product!

     &      

 

  

$700 - All our Skin Care Products:

- rehabilitation face/body skin balm
- therapeutic lip balm
- daily hand balm
- 2x body milk (skin conditioner); 120 & 220 ml
- 2x olive wash & exfoliate face & body; 50 &500 ml
- 2x face cream (normal & dry skin)
- therapeutic cream for hair & scalp
- enriched foot cream
- soothing relief baby & mom
- 2x olive face mask (normal & dry skin)
- massage oil baby & mom
- body butter
- eye cream with silk protein 
- day cream for normal skin
- day cream with silk protein
- day cream for dry skin
- night cream with silk protein
- night cream for dry skin
- a 5 liter bucket of our Olive Hand Soap Scrub

 

BONUS: 500 ml sample of our 100% natural, safe, chemical free house hold cleaning product!

 

&

 

&

  

&

   

 

      

 

 

$2500 - 3 Day Workshop Visit

We invite you to visit our project! We guide you on a tour through the facility and groves. The visit includes 3 days, 2-nights at the farm's premises (full board for one person) and the planting of an olive tree around the Sea of Galilee. You'll receive an official planting certification.(excluding flight, including local transport)

BONUS:  ALL of our Skin Care Products & a 500 ml sample of our 100% natural, safe, chemical free house hold product!

   

&

 

&

 

&

  

 

 

More information:

 

What is our campaign about?

We biologically treat the residue of olive oil pressing, a serious environmental hazard, turning it into 100% natural, safe, cleaning products.

Many of the olive growing countries focus on olive farming due to the fact that olive trees are drought resistant. Unfortunately bulks of olive residue are being dumped down the creeks, harming their own, extremely limited, drinking water reservoirs.

In a whole different field, the world creates house hold cleaning products, using precious drinking water and loads of poisonous chemicals. Last year alone 1.4 million Americans were hospitalized as a result of house hold cleaning products injuries, out of them 800.000 were children younger than 6 years old. As a result of using chemical loaded houshold cleaning products each one of us, in average, holds in his body 250 poisonous chemicals, out of which 50 are suspected as potential to cause cancer. 

After we sustainably and organically press the olive oil, we collect the olives' residue; this is most of the olive, and overwhelmed with antioxidant. Thus, when spilled in the environment it pollutes the water table and sterilizes the soil. We biologically treat the residue and turn it first into olive vinegar. This is a brand-new and patented process. We then add plant extracts and essentials, turning it into 100% natural, safe, chemical free house hold cleaning products.

 

We need $ 300,000 to Finalize the development of the chemicals free cleaning products   - dishwasher, dishes, windows and glass, grease remover, surfaces, toilet bowls, floors, kitchen & bathroom.

 

Join us in our environmental revolution. We will make house hold cleaning products by developing the technology to reuse lost residue water making our environment cleaner and Safer for children and pets, eliminating  the need to incorporate good precious drinking water using only biologically treated olive water, eliminating the use of chemicals, and ready to be sewage treated easily, once flushed down the drain, and, how lovely, reused for agricultural irrigation.

 

  • Spread the word about green cleaning!

  • Share this information with your family, friends, collegues, neighbours and even your nanny.

  • Tell all the mothers (to-be) you know they don't have to hide their cleaning products from their kids anymore. Soon they will be able to clean safely. 

  • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools!

 

 

   

 

What the magazines wrote about us:

"Ready with a Dream and the Plow"

 By Kalindi O’Brien

"Many have wondered how a dream, with all its longing and desire can culminate into a reality. For Avner Talmon the charismatic founder and CEO of Capernaum Vista Olive Farm there are four key ingredients: destiny, passion, character and genes. Avner offers these adjectives more to inspire than to self reflect but it is all too clear that the gentleman sitting across from me posses all four and more.....Nine years after arrival to the North the property that is now Capernaum Vista Olive Farm was purchased. In the short five years that have elapsed since that purchase Avner’s company has much to be proud of. Boasting two patents, both of grave environmental significance and a total of over 100 products including the all natural olive based skincare line which alone has 26 products!..."

" Me and my family are totally obligated to a sustainable way of life in which we do whatever we can to re-use rather than recycle, to downsize/ eliminate the use of chemicals in our household/fields and to bring the world high quality, environmental friendly, safe to use, product. " 
- Avner Talmon

We would like to thank everyone who participated in this ecological revolution campaign; our family members - Smadar, Omri, Guri, Mati, Neta Lee, Doron, AR Creative- Dror, Ynon Vardy, Eran yarom, Alon yaacobi , Jacki John Shai  John Guy ,John, Yaron Ben-Nun, Harel Ben-Nun , Yoav Harel, Shachar  Zefania, Barry Berman and Milou Peperkamp.    

 

We will green & clean the world together!

story: I am raising money to buy a tree for the restaurants in Palo Alto that agree to trying my idea. Instead of throwing a customer's leftover water down the drain, the restaurant can use the water to water their tree. This idea will help save water in California, as well as grow trees to fight global warming.

Instead of throwing a customer's leftover water down the drain, the restaurant can use the water to water their tree. This idea will help save water in California, as well as grow trees to fight global warming.

story:
About Us

We are Team Fireflies, a group of youth aspirants from Youth Corps Singapore; a programme under the National Youth Council that encourages lifelong volunteerism by matching youth volunteers with critical community needs. Although our group is diverse with varying backgrounds, we have a common goal – to create positive change in the community.

We will be embarking on an overseas service-learning project at Kim Bang, a county in the Ha Nam province of Vietnam from 23 May 2015 to 4 June 2015. Environmental issues in Vietnam has been an area of concern for the locals. There, we will be working with the local orphanage (Kim Bang Social Welfare Center) as well as Thi Son Secondary School to co-create sustainable solutions with them to address the environmental issues they are facing.

These solutions would include helping them to improve their waste management system, raising awareness among the beneficiaries and educating them through programmes in a bid to improve the situation.

Waste disposed of within the compound of Kim Bang Social Welfare Centre. Waste management is one of the issues the team will be working on.

Furthermore, there is the possibility of scaling up the project to other schools and orphanages all over Vietnam if this pilot project goes well. All these will be done with the support of our community partner, Hemispheres Foundation, a social enterprise committed to playing an active role in environmental education and social affairs.


Our Needs, Plans and Its Impact (where the funding will go to)

As mentioned, we will be embarking on the implementation trip between 23 May 2015 and 4 June 2015. After our recce trip, we have designed an integrated programme done day-camp style and the following will all involve costs:
  • Farming (The orphans love farming as there are many advantages to it; providing shade in the summer, providing food and fresh air etc.)
  • Community Trail (To bring about different thoughts and perspectives on their daily surroundings)
  • Recycling Bins (For the sorting of waste into organic and toxic waste; where they are able to reuse or sell the recyclables to earn cash for the lower-income students.)
  • Art Materials (For decoration of the recycle bins and handicraft; this instills a sense of ownership while letting them have fun and unleash their creativity!)
  • Life Skills Workshop (We want to teach them to make handicraft out of recyclables for sale. The orphanage would then be able to raise funds on their own.)

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the means to help us in monetary donations, but we would gladly appreciate if you could help to spread the word by sharing our crowdfunding campaign!

Also, if you have any art materials/stationery (such as colour pencils, paint, glue, etc.) or new water bottles/lunch boxes lying around that you do not need and wish to donate, we would love to collect them from you! Please contact us at youthcorpssg.fireflies@gmail.com for more details.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sarah Peck and I am the founder of Mother Nature’s Army.
Mother Nature’s Army’s goal is to deepen awareness surrounding the importance of green living by implementing responsible behaviors into everyday life.

A few friends and I are going to drive across country as Mother Nature’s Army and clean up America, while educating and raising awareness on the importance of going green and recycling!!

We have found a school bus that has been converted to run on vegetable oil.
We are going to drive from Upstate NY to California and back within 2 months time. We will leave the 3rd week in October 2012 and come back at the end of December 2012.

 

The Impact

Our goals (based on having 4-6 people present on the bus):

  • · Pick up 1 bag of trash a day per person, with a goal of 350 trash bags
  • · Recycle 20 items per person a day with a goal of recycling over 7,000 items
  • · Upcycle 1 item per day per person with a goal of upcycling over 300 items
  • · To reach out to as many people as we can and have them take the knowledge we share and make greener decisions everyday.

Items we cannot recycle or upcycle will go in our Free Cycle Box. It will be outside our bus when we’re stopped for anyone to take from.

(Upcycling is the process of converting waste materials or useless products into new materials or products of better quality or a higher environmental value.)

We are also planning on being a zero-waste bus.

We will have a power point presentation wherever we go to educate people. We will set up a sheet on the side of the bus with a small projector. We are going to show this presentation almost every day even if there is only 1 person present to watch.
The power point will be teach people about our veggie bus, how it works and why its better for the environment then gas. We will talk about how to go about switching your car over. We will discuss our trip, what we plan to achieve, what we have already achieved, what zero-waste means, how to go about becoming a zero-waste household,  how to recycle and the impact it actually makes on the environment. We will cover what upcycling means, how to upcycle simple items in your homes and show the ways we have upcycled. We will talk about small and simple ways to go green and how to use them in everyday life, while showing you how those small behaviors will impact the world in a good way.

This summer Mother Nature’s Army will have a booth at 6 music festivals. We will be holding a cigarette butt picking up contest with stellar prizes and educating anyone who crosses our path. We have already successfully done 3 festivals this year, including Rock N’ Roll Resort, Damns Sam’s Get Together, & Ziontific Summer Solstice Festival.

We were able to collect over 1,100 cigarette butts for the butt contest at Ziontifc Summer Solstice, and sifted through almost a dozen garbage bags to save all that could be recycled.
As much as we love to go from festival to festival raising awareness, we want to take this mission countrywide. That is why we are starting this campaign.

 

What We Need

We need enough money to fund the trip and to buy some of the most important items which include but not limited to:

  • · The Veggie School Bus, which will cost roughly $5,000
  • · A full tune-up for the bus
  • · New school bus tires, which will cost roughly around $1,200
  • · Filters to filter the vegetable oil
  • · 2-4, 5 Gallon buckets for filtering and storing the vegetable oil
  • · Trash picking up supplies, such as biodegradable trash bags, gloves, free cycle bin
  • · A projector, so we can educate wherever we go with sheet on the bus and a power point presentation
  • · Small rechargeable battery (to power the projector)
  • · Portable Solar Panel, to power small appliances inside the bus and to recharge the battery.

We plan to keep you updated on the trip making posts almost every day on Mother Nature’s Army’s facebook. We will keep track of everything we are doing, where we’re headed next and posting photos to show you what we’ve done. We will keep you updated on the progress of our goals and let you know how you can help along our travels. We will post new ideas on how to upcycle products and many other ways other ways to be greener!

Start keeping track of us now!
www.facebook.com/mothernaturesarmy1

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t donate? That’s ok! You can start helping us out in your own neighborhood. See that piece of trash on the ground while your walking to work or school? Pick it up! If everyone picked up 1 piece of trash a day that would amount to a significant impact on the amount of trash in our environment. If we all start to make conscious green decisions every day we can start to make a difference. Remember all the small things add up!!

Get the word out for us! Tell all your friends what we are doing and make some noise about our campaign!! We need as much support as we can get.

Want to help in other ways? Feel free to contact us at: MotherNaturesArmy1@gmail.com

Keep updated with us at: www.facebook.com/MotherNaturesArmy1
We might be coming to a town near you!

Mother Nature’s Army is in the process of becoming a non-profit organization. At the moment we cannot afford the paperwork. At the end of the trip if there is any money left over it is going towards the paperwork fees for Mother Nature’s Army to legally become a non-profit. I feel it is more important at the moment to put the money we are raising to doing good, rather then to put it towards paperwork.

story:
Short Summary

After receiving my BS degree in Business Administration from Cal State University Northridge I worked in the agriculture industry / vegetable processing for most of my career, currently I work with government grants.

Since bathrooms account for most of our indoor water use I started to find ways to save water. I did all the usual things like installing low flow shower heads, taking shorter showers etc. It just seemed so wasteful how we just let water go down the drain without a second thought, particularly when we all use potable water to flush
our toilets. Through constant tinkering I found a simple way to recycle shower water; I scoop up shower water (using a dust pan) into a gallon bucket and store it in a couple of larger buckets next to the toilet. This really works except for the
heavy porcelain tank cover. The only option was to remove it at every flush or to leave it off which was not acceptable. DUDWTFT™ was my solution.

This project is important to me because it empowers everyone to include household water in the recycle movement. California is the first state to ban plastic bags, we recycle various beverage containers, why not household water? I think the severe drought is a wake up call that we need to recycle our most precious resource at home in order to protect it. DUDWTFT™ is a simple tool that gives each household the ability to save a lot of water.

I do not have the resources to get this tool to the market place therefore I’m asking for your support to get this project off the ground so everyone can use recycled water to flush toilets. All the donations will go to this effort. Expenditures include plastic molds, manufacturing of DUDWTFT, marketing, packaging/shipping, upgrading the current provisional patent to a utility patent, etc.

Finally the water we recycle during normal rainfall years will go a long way in replenishing severely depleted ground water. I believe recycling is the only way we can sustain our way of life. Thank you.
