story:
I need your help. I have just embarked on the journey of a lifetime, a plastic pollution expedition through the Atlantic Ocean from Bermuda to Iceland. I have volunteered my time to work as part of the 5 Gyres.org team to help bring understanding and solutions to one of our planet’s biggest challenges. PLASTIC! I have documented my discoveries with photos and video. An example, did you know that 500 million straws are thrown away every day in the US alone. Much of our plastic unfortunately does not get recycled. What are the impacts on our oceans and in turn...us? I want to help raise awareness, help change policy and inspire people to use less. I will show you what I have discovered.

Please help me undertake this challenge!! 

The ocean plays an integral role on sustaining life on earth, protecting this important resource is vital. Humans produce 100% of the plastic pollution in our oceans. Hundreds of millions of metric tons of plastic debris currently float in the ocean. In 2012, 288 million tons of new plastics were created which tells us that recycling is not enough. The plastic breaks down into small pieces, (micro plastics) scattered throughout the water. This impacts our oceans, marine life and in turn, us.  We need to be able to show the impacts of plastic in our oceans to create change.  To help people understand why this is dangerous both for our eco-system and us and what changes we can make by refusing single-use plastics like plastic bags and water bottles, getting government officials involved to create policy and making industry look for new sustainable ideas. We took 31 surface trawls while at sea and found plastic in all of them. This scientific data we are out at sea collecting is invaluable. The first step to solutions is public awareness and engagement and that's where I come in and why this voyage is so important to me.  So many people don't even know how urgent our plastic pollution problem is.  Maybe as you read this you are just  now learning as well. Let's be part of the solution!!!

Summary

My name is Tiffany Paige and I have been selected to team up with the verified non-profit 5 Gyres Institute (www.5gyres.org) for their Viking Gyre Expedition, a plastic pollution research expedition from Bermuda to Iceland.  There will be 14 of us on board.  We will be at sea on a 72-foot sailing vessel named the Sea Dragon for 20 days, covering 2500 miles in total, to understand microplastic distribution and impacts from the subtropical gyre across the subpolar gyre.  This research helps determine the global estimate and impact of plastic pollution in our oceans as well as help change policy.

Plastic creates toxic pollution at every stage of its existence: manufacture, use, and disposal. Plastic is a material that the Earth cannot digest. Every bit of plastic that has ever been created still exists, including the small amount that has been incinerated and has become toxic particulate matter. 

As you can see from the dates listed above I am back. I just got back having spent some time in Iceland doing research on their beaches.  What an incredible trip with many firsts for me.  I have taken lots of photos and videos to share (check out the gallery). There were hi's and low's and special friendships made. Most of all there was plastic. Lots of plastic.  Not as much big plastic ,although there was, but it was mostly little plastic pieces which is much more dangerous. Think about what happens if every big piece of plastic breaks down into hundreds of thousands of little pieces of plastic yet never goes away.  That's what is happening.

What is Needed and Where Your Support Goes

Ideally I would like to raise $12,000 to cover my costs associated with joining the 5 Gyres expedition.  It is an expensive trip and more money than I've spent on any trip ever, but well worth it. I'm asking for $4,500. I'd rather make my goal than not and if I go over than it only helps my cause. I have chosen to run this Indiegogo campaign as a "flexible funding" campaign, so please know that any contribution will be graciously accepted. In other words, my hope is to go over the $4500 for a $12,000 target, I will be accepting all donations made to help pay for the trip.

My costs break down as follows:  

$8,500 berth - The largest portion needed is for my seat on the Sea Dragon sailing vessel.  This amount charters the boat for 20 days, with a captain and 1st mate, fuel, food, gear and research.  I took out a revolving credit line for 3 months at my bank to pay for my seat in cash/check.

$1,500 for airfare to Bermuda and from Iceland, home. Paid by credit card

$300 flight & travel insurance. Paid by credit card

$500 - Hotels for 3 days in Bermuda before boarding vessel and 3 days after landing in Iceland for beach studies and surveys and any delays due to weather. Hotels are expensive in both Bermuda & Iceland, so we stayed at the BIOS (Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences) and Kex Hostel in Iceland. Paid by credit card

$850 for proper gear - I don’t have any of the proper gear needed to be at sea for 12 days on a 72-ft boat (this ain’t glamping!)  I have only been on a day-boat.  I need everything for the trip from a waterproof back-pack and duffle to proper boots, work gloves and waterproof/repellent windbraker and layers of wool under-layers. I'd like to thank Helly Hansen for the generous discount to help pay for my gear. Paid by credit card.

Let's just say I'm in credit card debt, but I still know it was the right thing to do.

Any extra made would help with Indiegogo expenses and anything unforeseen that I have missed as well as well as to start the next phase, which is taking what I have seen and learned to help raise awareness and help create changes in policy.

The Details

WHAT IS A GYRE, YOU ASK?

• A gyre in oceanography is a naturally occurring vortex of wind and currents that rotate in a clockwise direction in the northern hemisphere and counter-clockwise in the southern hemisphere. These create a whirlpool effect, whose vortex moves more slowly at the center and that is where marine plastic debris collects.

• There are 5 major gyres (hence the name of the non-profit) in the oceans worldwide: 1.North Pacific, also known as the North Pacific Garbage Patch (said to be twice the size of Texas); 2.South Pacific; 3.North Atlantic; 4.South Atlantic; and 5.Indian Ocean.

Discarded plastics have formed a toxic “plastic soup” that is gathering in the 5 massive ocean gyres around the world. As the plastic breaks down, it is eaten by sea animals, causing illness and death. It eventually enters our diets, too.

WHO AM I?

I am an actress and host who is passionate about the health and wellness of us and our environment.  I have decided to focus all my energy on this. Since I was a little girl, EVERYTHING had feelings to me, from plants to snails to real animals and stuffed, right down to an M&M.  What I really loved as a little girl is our ocean. Growing up in Southern California, I grew up going to the beach on weekends. I’d spend hours in the ocean. I feel a deep connection to it and everything in it. A handful of years ago I heard about the Gyres. What? A garbage patch twice the size of Texas? I have to see this, I thought. It can’t be!  Can you see it from above?  It was taking off from the LAX airport and looking out the window down at the beautiful Pacific ocean glistening from above, but wondering what lies beneath that prompted me to create a “green” blog and online series of videos. “GreenWithTiffany” (www.greenwithtiffany.com) is a social media connected site about all things “green” to raise awareness and bring truth to the green movement by sharing ideas of sustainability, wellness, environmental impacts and living as one with our planet and why it is important.  From products and services, to how-to’s and environmental challenges.  I want to share and highlight people who want to make a difference. I learn as I go as well and want to share my findings to make sure we move towards a more sustainable way of living, so that our beautiful Mother Earth can thrive and so can we. 

My goal is to bring awareness and light to plastic pollution and how it is affecting us and the world we live in.  I want people to be informed and  “choose to care”.  It is a serious situation that is wreaking havoc on our environment.  There are many people out there that just don’t know.  Maybe they recycle and they think that’s enough.  Sadly, it’s not.  I will be documenting the entire trip.  I am going geared-up with a gaggle of technology, from my phone to a GoPro, traditional video and point-and-shoot.  I will not miss capturing a second of this trip.  I will post videos and write blogs throughout.  Most of all I will see firsthand and show people that our oceans are in trouble and we need to act now.  I will continue the conversation and educate when I get back, including making a short film to document our discoveries a little deeper (pun intended).

5 Gyres is a non-profit that conducts research and communicates about the global impact of plastic pollution in the world’s oceans and employs strategies to eliminate the accumulation of plastic pollution in the 5 subtropical gyres.  They have been on numerous panels such as SXSW Eco, CNN during the search for the missing Malaysian airline flight 370, and in the documentary Trashed, to name a few. To understand the impact of plastic pollution they study the 5 subtropical gyres by sailing through them (www.5gyres.org). 

The 5 Gyres model is to engage citizens in a global movement working to end the flow of plastics into our shared oceans.  The 5 Gyres team will take our crew to witness firsthand how plastics are impacting the marine environment.

SCIENTIFIC WORK

It is the intention of 5 Gyres staff to have us participate in every aspect of the scientific work on the expedition. This means that we’ll be hauling trawls, filling in data sheets, picking plastic and fish out of the net, cleaning gear, etc.... Their intent is to have us become comfortable with the equipment and protocols so that we can do this on our own as a citizen scientist. 

Research Objectives 

What we will be doing:

-Beach Survey: At each port along our sailing route 5 Gyres staff, crew and local volunteers will survey beaches for micro and macro plastics in order to assess the impact of gyre plastic on local communities.

Exhibitions - In each of the islands, we will create a temporary exhibit with debris found on local shores, featuring actual samples from the voyage.

-Manta and hi-speed trawls:

These three nets sample the sea in different ways, measuring surface volume slowly, surface abundance quickly, and multiple levels below the surface simultaneously. The end result is a plethora of data like no other voyage in the past. This will provide an expected 50-75 sea surface samples.

-Vertical distribution and trawling:

Little is known about the vertical distribution of plastic marine pollution, especially during varied sea states. We’ll deploy a prototype trawl that collects 11 samples at one time, hopefully showing variation in the depth of microplastics based on how rough the seas are.

-Visual observations:

Since we can’t catch the big stuff in our nets, we sit on deck while the manta trawl is out and look for it. This creates a 4th size range of macroplastic data to go with our microplastic data.

-iGyre:

Using data from all expedition trawls, we will recalibrate our current global model to determine a new estimate of the total weight and particle count of plastic pollution in the N. Atlantic. These data, along with other data from recent expeditions, together will provide a new global estimate.

In general, we will be expected to help steer the ship, raise and lower sails, coil lines, clean the deck, and other duties prescribed by the skipper, first-mate or our team leader. In addition to sailing work there will be chores to keep the vessel clean and comfortable. These include cleaning the kitchen, galley, organizing the forepeak, sweeping the floors or vacuuming the bilge. Yes, I will be “swabbing the deck, matie!”

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?

The ocean is Earth’s life support

- The ocean covers 71% of the earth’s surface

- 50 to 70 % of our oxygen comes from the ocean. That’s more than all of the world’s rainforests combined.

- The ocean is the #1 source of protein for more than a billion people.

- The ocean regulates our climate, absorbs carbon dioxide, holds 97% of Earth’s water, and supports the greatest abundance of life on our planet.

- More than 60% of the world’s population lives on or near the coast.

- The ocean provides a livelihood, recreation, beauty, wonder, and untapped scientific discovery, leading to new medications, foods, and advanced technologies.

- Our oceans account for 71% of the planet, but less than 2% of our oceans are protected. We have protections in place for nearly 12% of all land (through areas like national parks).

Everyone, everywhere depends on a healthy sea 

What we know…

- Plastics pollution accumulate in oceanic gyres.

- Plastic pollution dominates marine debris.

- Plastic degrades at sea and breaks down into tiny microplastics.

- Plastics absorb and release chemicals.

- Animals eat and entangle in plastic pollution.

By most estimates, hundreds of millions of metric tons of plastic debris currently float in the ocean.  The plastic is fragmented into small pieces, scattered throughout the water column. There are no visible islands of trash anywhere, but rather an “ocean soup” laced with plastic.

Disposable plastics are the main source of plastic pollution

Consumption of disposable plastics—bags, bottles, straws and so forth—has spiraled out of control. These items are used for seconds, hours or days, but their remains last forever.

Plastic recycling is not a sustainable solution to the crisis

Most of our plastic waste is landfilled, downcycled, incinerated or exported to other countries. Recycling of plastic is costly and does not stem the production of virgin plastic product.

We consume BILLIONS of bags and bottles per year in the US alone.

We currently recover only 5% of the plastics we produce for recycling.  Roughly 50% is buried in landfills, some is remade into durable goods, and much of it remains “unaccounted for”, lost in the environment where it ultimately washes out to sea.

WHEN?

I am leaving in June.  We are at sea from June 7- June 29th.  I will be gone by the time this closes but will still be active in keeping up, so anything you can do would be greatly appreciated!

The ocean plays an integral role on sustaining life on earth, protecting this important resource is vital.  Please be a part of the solution and help me go. 

PERKS…

The perks range from a grateful thank you, to social media shout outs, photos, plastic pollution solutions and more.

- First I will create a thank you page on my website and list every backer’s name (with your approval of course).

- If you would like a shout-out in one of my short videos I produce, I will give you a warm thank you at the beginning or open of my video and your own nameplate at the end.

- If you would like a shout-out on one of my videos during the voyage, I will give you a warm thank you at the beginning as well as place your name at the end. 

- An additional longer format video being made will then have multiple names of backers to thank from the voyage section.

-An A-Mason glass drinking jar that will also fit your glass straw.  Both have the 5 Gyres logo etched in.

- The digital look-book and photo album will be this adventure through my eyes and findings along the way of images depicting the reality of our oceans as they currently are, both good and bad.

 - 

LifeFactory, www.lifefactory.com is a reusable glass bottle wrapped in a silicone sleeve.  It takes the place of a plastic water bottle, is BPA free and does not leach chemicals. I really do love and use mine everyday. They have generously donated to my campaign. Thank you LifeFactory!

- 

The film screening is a documentary called Plastic Paradise: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch. It focuses on the North Pacific Gyre and how plastic pollution is affecting our marine life, especially the albatross at Midway Atoll. It took Angela Sun, a friend, 7 years to make this film and covers many aspects of plastic.  She is donating a screening of her award-winning film for my campaign.  It will be held in the Los Angeles area with the date and time to be determined. A Q&A will include a panel of experts in this field.

 - 

The ultimate “green” party will be at a to-be-announced location in the Los Angeles area.  We will have music, food, drinks, vendors and a whole lotta fun.  I hope you can join us.

 - 

To be a Co-Host with me will be a blast.  I cover many events in the “green” world.  From The Natural Products Expo to the Green Festivals and Eco Emmy’s.  You can accompany me to an event in Los Angeles and put your banter and fun interview skills to work.  Barbara WaWa has retired, ya know… :)

 - 

The eco gift bag will be filled with goodies from food, beauty, cleaning, health, and solutions to our plastic pollution epidemic.  Good for you & the environment.  It will definitely not disappoint.  Stay tuned for more information. Expect a LifeFactory reusable bottle; a straw from Simply Straws, a glass straw helping to offset the 500 million plastic starws thrown away every day (www.simplystraws.com); cleaning products from Earth Friendly Products (www.ecos.com), products that I use personally and trust. Thank you LifeFactory, Simply Straws and Earth Friendly Products! 

- 

Would you like your very own video to promote your product or service on your website and / or YouTube Channel, as well as on my website and YouTube channel?  If what you want to promote is something that is good for the planet and for us, I would be thrilled to help promote it.  We will come to you and do a 3-5 minute video of an interview with you as we learn about your product or service.  We will edit it and include screen shots of your site graphics and music to create your own promotional piece to use wherever you choose.  If you are not located in the greater LA area, travel expenses will need to be provided for me and my camera operator.

 - 

If you are a business and would like to help sponsor me, I would be over the moon.  I will use your logo/decal and gear myself up like an IndyCar racer.  I will only accept up to 5 brands.  You will be visible in all photos and videos taken, and with 13 people on board documenting for multiple media outlets, including social media, you will be seen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute please, please help me get the word out.  Share this anywhere you can and leave a comment. Our oceans & I thank you!  Sharing is caring... Choose to care :)
story_txt:
I need your help. I have just embarked on the journey of a lifetime, a plastic pollution expedition through the
Atlantic Ocean from Bermuda to Iceland. I have volunteered my time to work as
part of the 5 Gyres.org team to help bring understanding and solutions to one
of our planet’s biggest challenges. PLASTIC! I have documented my discoveries with photos and video. An example, did you know that 500 million straws are thrown away every day in the
US alone. Much of our plastic unfortunately does not get recycled. What are the
impacts on our oceans and in turn...us? I want to help raise awareness, help change policy and inspire people to use less. I will show you what I have discovered.

Please help me undertake this challenge!! The ocean plays an integral role on sustaining life on earth, protecting this important resource is vital. Humans produce 100% of the plastic pollution in our oceans. Hundreds of millions of metric tons of plastic debris currently float in the ocean. In 2012, 288 million tons of new plastics were created which tells us that recycling is not enough. The plastic breaks down into small pieces, (micro plastics) scattered throughout the water. This impacts our oceans, marine life and in turn, us.  We need to be able to show the impacts of plastic in our oceans to create change.  To help people understand why this is dangerous both for our eco-system and us and what changes we can make by refusing single-use plastics like plastic bags and water bottles, getting government officials involved to create policy and making industry look for new sustainable ideas. We took 31 surface trawls while at sea and found plastic in all of them. This scientific data we are out at sea collecting is invaluable. The first step to solutions is public awareness and engagement and that's where I come in and why this voyage is so important to me.  So many people don't even know how urgent our plastic pollution problem is.  Maybe as you read this you are just  now learning as well. Let's be part of the solution!!!SummaryMy name is Tiffany Paige and I have been selected to team up with the verified non-profit 5 Gyres Institute (www.5gyres.org) for their Viking Gyre Expedition, a plastic pollution research expedition from Bermuda to Iceland.  There will be 14 of us on board.  We will be at sea on a 72-foot sailing vessel named the Sea Dragon for 20 days, covering 2500 miles in total, to understand microplastic distribution and impacts from the subtropical gyre across the subpolar gyre.  This research helps determine the global estimate and impact of plastic pollution in our oceans as well as help change policy.Plastic creates toxic pollution at every stage of its existence: manufacture, use, and disposal. Plastic is a material that the Earth cannot digest. Every bit of plastic that has ever been created still exists, including the small amount that has been incinerated and has become toxic particulate matter. As you can see from the dates listed above I am back. I just got back having spent some time in Iceland doing research on their beaches.  What an incredible trip with many firsts for me.  I have taken lots of photos and videos to share (check out the gallery). There were hi's and low's and special friendships made. Most of all there was plastic. Lots of plastic.  Not as much big plastic ,although there was, but it was mostly little plastic pieces which is much more dangerous. Think about what happens if every big piece of plastic breaks down into hundreds of thousands of little pieces of plastic yet never goes away.  That's what is happening.
What is Needed and Where Your Support Goes

Ideally I would like to raise $12,000 to cover my costs associated with joining the 5 Gyres expedition.  It is an expensive trip and more money than I've spent on any trip ever, but well worth it. I'm asking for $4,500. I'd rather make my goal than not and if I go over than it only helps my cause. I have chosen to run this Indiegogo campaign as a "flexible funding" campaign, so please know that any contribution will be graciously accepted. In other words, my hope is to go over the $4500 for a $12,000 target, I will be accepting all donations made to help pay for the trip.My costs break down as follows:  
$8,500 berth - The largest
portion needed is for my seat on the Sea
Dragon sailing vessel.  This
amount charters the boat for 20 days, with a captain and 1st mate, fuel, food, gear and research.  I took out a revolving credit line for 3 months at my bank to pay for my seat in cash/check.
$1,500 for airfare to
Bermuda and from Iceland, home. Paid by credit card
$300 flight & travel
insurance. Paid by credit card
$500 - Hotels for 3 days in
Bermuda before boarding vessel and 3 days after landing in Iceland for beach
studies and surveys and any delays due to weather. Hotels are expensive in both Bermuda & Iceland, so we stayed at the BIOS (Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences) and Kex Hostel in Iceland. Paid by credit card
$850 for proper gear - I
don’t have any of the proper gear needed to be at sea for 12 days on a 72-ft
boat (this ain’t glamping!)  I have
only been on a day-boat.  I need
everything for the trip from a waterproof back-pack and duffle to proper boots,
work gloves and waterproof/repellent windbraker and layers of wool under-layers. I'd like to thank Helly Hansen for the generous discount to help pay for my gear. Paid by credit card.Let's just say I'm in credit card debt, but I still know it was the right thing to do.
Any extra made would help
with Indiegogo expenses and anything unforeseen that I have missed as well as well as to start the next phase, which is taking what I have seen and learned to help raise awareness and
help create changes in policy.
The Details
WHAT IS A GYRE, YOU ASK?
• A gyre in oceanography is a naturally
occurring vortex of wind and currents that rotate in a clockwise direction in
the northern hemisphere and counter-clockwise in the southern hemisphere. These
create a whirlpool effect, whose vortex moves more slowly at the center and
that is where marine plastic debris collects.
• There are 5 major gyres (hence the name of
the non-profit) in the oceans worldwide: 1.North Pacific, also known as the
North Pacific Garbage Patch (said to be twice the size of Texas); 2.South
Pacific; 3.North Atlantic; 4.South Atlantic; and 5.Indian Ocean.
Discarded plastics have formed a toxic “plastic soup” that is
gathering in the 5 massive ocean gyres around the world. As the plastic breaks
down, it is eaten by sea animals, causing illness and death. It eventually
enters our diets, too.
WHO AM I?I am an actress and host who
is passionate about the health and wellness of us and our environment.  I have decided to focus all my energy on
this. Since I was a little girl, EVERYTHING had feelings to me, from plants to
snails to real animals and stuffed, right down to an M&M.  What I really loved as a little girl is
our ocean. Growing up in Southern California, I grew up going to the beach on weekends.
I’d spend hours in the ocean. I feel a deep connection to it and everything in
it. A handful of years ago I heard about the Gyres. What? A garbage patch twice
the size of Texas? I have to see this, I thought. It can’t be!  Can you see it from above?  It was taking off from the LAX airport
and looking out the window down at the beautiful Pacific ocean glistening from
above, but wondering what lies beneath that prompted me to create a “green”
blog and online series of videos. “GreenWithTiffany” (www.greenwithtiffany.com) is a
social media connected site about all things “green” to raise awareness and bring
truth to the green movement by sharing ideas of sustainability, wellness,
environmental impacts and living as one with our planet and why it is
important.  From products and
services, to how-to’s and environmental challenges.  I want to share and highlight people who want to make a
difference. I learn as I go as well and want to share my findings to make sure
we move towards a more sustainable way of living, so that our beautiful Mother
Earth can thrive and so can we. 
My goal is to bring
awareness and light to plastic pollution and how it is affecting us and the
world we live in.  I want people to
be informed and  “choose to care”.  It is a serious situation that is
wreaking havoc on our environment. 
There are many people out there that just don’t know.  Maybe they recycle and they think that’s
enough.  Sadly, it’s not.  I will be documenting the entire trip.  I am going geared-up with a gaggle of
technology, from my phone to a GoPro, traditional video and point-and-shoot.  I will not miss capturing a second of
this trip.  I will post videos and
write blogs throughout.  Most of
all I will see firsthand and show people that our oceans are in trouble and we
need to act now.  I will continue
the conversation and educate when I get back, including making a short film to
document our discoveries a little deeper (pun intended).
5 Gyres is a non-profit that
conducts research and communicates about the global impact of plastic pollution
in the world’s oceans and employs strategies to eliminate the accumulation of
plastic pollution in the 5 subtropical gyres.  They have been on numerous panels such as SXSW Eco, CNN
during the search for the missing Malaysian airline flight 370, and in the
documentary Trashed, to name a few. To understand the impact of plastic
pollution they study the 5 subtropical gyres by sailing through them (www.5gyres.org). 
The 5 Gyres model is to
engage citizens in a global movement working to end the flow of plastics into
our shared oceans.  The 5 Gyres
team will take our crew to witness firsthand how plastics are impacting the
marine environment.SCIENTIFIC WORK
It
is the intention of 5 Gyres staff to have us participate in every aspect of the scientific
work on the expedition. This means that we’ll be hauling trawls, filling in
data sheets, picking plastic and fish out of the net, cleaning gear, etc....
Their intent is to have us become comfortable with the equipment and protocols
so that we can do this on our own as a citizen scientist. 
Research Objectives 
What we will be doing:
-Beach Survey: At each port along our sailing route 5 Gyres staff, crew
and local volunteers will survey beaches for micro and macro plastics in order
to assess the impact of gyre plastic on local communities.
Exhibitions -
In each of the islands, we will create a temporary exhibit with debris found on
local shores, featuring actual samples from the voyage. 
-Manta and hi-speed trawls:
These
three nets sample the sea in different ways, measuring surface volume slowly,
surface abundance quickly, and multiple levels below the surface simultaneously.
The end result is a plethora of data like no other voyage in the past.
This will provide an expected 50-75 sea surface samples.
-Vertical distribution and trawling:
Little
is known about the vertical distribution of plastic marine pollution,
especially during
varied sea states. We’ll deploy a prototype trawl that collects 11 samples at
one time, hopefully showing variation in the depth of microplastics based on how
rough the seas are.
-Visual observations:
Since
we can’t catch the big stuff in our nets, we sit on deck while the manta trawl
is out and look for it. This creates a 4th size range of
macroplastic data to go
with our microplastic data.
-iGyre:
Using
data from all expedition trawls, we will recalibrate our current global model to
determine a new estimate of the total weight and particle count of plastic pollution
in the N. Atlantic. These data, along with other data from recent expeditions,
together will provide a new global estimate.
In
general, we will be expected to help steer the ship, raise and lower sails,
coil lines, clean the deck, and other duties prescribed by the skipper, first-mate
or our team leader. In addition to sailing work there will be chores to keep the
vessel clean and comfortable. These include cleaning the kitchen, galley, organizing
the forepeak, sweeping the floors or vacuuming the bilge. Yes, I will be
“swabbing the deck, matie!”
WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?
The ocean is Earth’s life support- The ocean covers
71% of the earth’s surface
- 50 to 70 % of our oxygen
comes from the ocean. That’s more than all of the world’s rainforests combined.
- The ocean is the #1 source of protein
for more than a billion people.
- The ocean regulates our climate, absorbs
carbon dioxide, holds 97% of Earth’s water,
and supports the greatest abundance of life on our planet.- More than 60% of the world’s population lives on or near the coast.
- The ocean provides a livelihood,
recreation, beauty, wonder, and untapped scientific discovery, leading to new
medications, foods, and advanced technologies.
- Our oceans account for 71% of the planet,
but less than 2% of our oceans are protected. We have protections in
place for nearly 12% of all land (through areas like national parks).
Everyone, everywhere depends on a healthy
sea 
What we know…
- Plastics pollution
accumulate in oceanic gyres.
- Plastic pollution dominates
marine debris.
- Plastic degrades at sea and
breaks down into tiny microplastics.
- Plastics absorb and release
chemicals.
- Animals eat and entangle in
plastic pollution.
By most estimates, hundreds of millions of metric
tons of plastic debris currently float in the ocean.  The plastic is
fragmented into small pieces, scattered throughout the water column. There
are no visible islands of trash anywhere, but rather an “ocean soup” laced with
plastic.Disposable plastics are the main source of
plastic pollution
Consumption of disposable plastics—bags, bottles,
straws and so forth—has spiraled out of control. These items are used for
seconds, hours or days, but their remains last forever.Plastic recycling is not a sustainable
solution to the crisis
Most of our plastic waste is landfilled,
downcycled, incinerated or exported to other countries. Recycling of plastic is
costly and does not stem the production of virgin plastic product.
We consume BILLIONS of bags
and bottles per year in the US alone.
We currently recover only 5% of the plastics we
produce for recycling.  Roughly 50%
is buried in landfills, some is remade into durable goods, and much of it
remains “unaccounted for”, lost in the environment where it ultimately washes
out to sea.WHEN?
I am leaving in June.  We are at sea from June 7- June 29th.  I will be gone by the time this closes but will still be active in keeping up,
so anything you can do would be greatly appreciated!
The ocean plays an integral
role on sustaining life on earth, protecting this important resource is vital.  Please be a part of the solution and
help me go. 
PERKS…
The perks range from a
grateful thank you, to social media shout outs, photos, plastic pollution
solutions and more.
- First I will create a thank
you page on my website and list every backer’s name (with your approval of
course).
- If you would like a shout-out
in one of my short videos I produce, I will give you a warm thank you at the
beginning or open of my video and your own nameplate at the end.
- If you would like a shout-out
on one of my videos during the voyage, I will give you a warm thank you at the
beginning as well as place your name at the end.  
- An additional longer format
video being made will then have multiple names of backers to thank from the
voyage section.-An A-Mason glass drinking jar that will also fit your glass straw.  Both have the 5 Gyres logo etched in.- The digital look-book and
photo album will be this adventure through my eyes and findings along the way
of images depicting the reality of our oceans as they currently are, both good
and bad.
 - LifeFactory, www.lifefactory.com is a reusable glass
bottle wrapped in a silicone sleeve. 
It takes the place of a plastic water bottle, is BPA free and does not
leach chemicals. I really do love and use mine everyday. They have generously
donated to my campaign. Thank you LifeFactory!- The film screening is a
documentary called Plastic Paradise: The
Great Pacific Garbage Patch. It focuses on the North Pacific Gyre and how
plastic pollution is affecting our marine life, especially the albatross at
Midway Atoll. It took Angela Sun, a friend, 7 years to make this film and
covers many aspects of plastic. 
She is donating a screening of her award-winning film for my campaign.  It will be held in the Los Angeles area
with the date and time to be determined. A Q&A will include a panel of
experts in this field. - The ultimate “green” party
will be at a to-be-announced location in the Los Angeles area.  We will have music, food, drinks,
vendors and a whole lotta fun.  I
hope you can join us.
 - To be a Co-Host with me will
be a blast.  I cover many events in
the “green” world.  From The
Natural Products Expo to the Green Festivals and Eco Emmy’s.  You can accompany me to an event in Los
Angeles and put your banter and fun interview skills to work.  Barbara WaWa has retired, ya know… :) - The eco gift bag will be filled
with goodies from food, beauty, cleaning, health, and solutions to our plastic
pollution epidemic.  Good for you

definitely not disappoint.  Stay

reusable bottle; a straw from Simply Straws, a glass straw helping to offset the 500 million plastic starws thrown away every day (www.simplystraws.com); cleaning products from Earth Friendly Products (www.ecos.com), products that I use personally
and trust. Thank you LifeFactory, Simply Straws and Earth Friendly Products! - Would you like your very own

story:
About the Internship

After receiving my B.A. in Environmental Science from Naropa University in 2011, I began my search for an outstanding permaculture internship. Over this past summer, I visited the Bullock Brothers Homestead on Orcas Island, Washington.  I heard about the Bullock Brother's from one of my professors at Naropa University as well as from many permaculture books I have read.  They are known as being one of the first permaculture sites in the U.S. and their courses and programs are well acclaimed in the permaculture world.  I discovered that the Bullock Brother's Homestead is exactly the place for me.  I know this internship will be the catalyst to a whole new insight in my life and journey as a environmentalist, permaculturalist, activist and educator. 

I applied to the internship as soon as they opened the application and was selected out of many to join 11 other interns for their skill building program.  This program is 8 months long, where I will be living, working and learning on the homestead.  Things I will be learning about include: organic farming, composting, composting toilets, solar energy, fruit tree maintenance, aquaculture, chinampas, ecology, and so much more.

For those who curious about what is permaculture: I see it as a goal to create regenerative and adaptive livelihoods through ecological and cultural studies. The approach to permaculture is deeply based on observing ecosystems, patterns, systems and cycles in nature and in our culture.  Using these observations we can design efficient and sustainable means for our human existence. Permaculture opened a new door of fascination and insight in my life.  It gave my life an abundant surplus of liveliness, excitement, knowledge, and brought me to realize the power of my own personal studies. 

This opportunity is such a blessing for me and I feel beyond excited.  This internship will give me the experience I need to become an educator and advocate of permaculture in my community.  I hope to practice permaculture as long as I live and inspire many throughout my life.  

Check out the Bullock Brothers Website Here!

Funds

  • $2,000 covers expense of the internship for eight months, March - October 2014
  • $350 minimum to cover transportation (plane ticket, ferry, bus) 
  • $250 to help pay for working gear (raincoat, boots, etc)
$2,600 is my absolute minimum for this internship, anything contributed over will most appreciated! 

Other Ways You Can Help

In case you are unable to help contribute, there are still ways you can help!  You can share my link on facebook or through email to your friends.

story:
Project Tree Victory!

Committed to the welfare of trees and urban forests

http://boundarytrees.com/

  Last summer, a Toronto resident sued her neighbors because they objected to her cutting down a beautiful, healthy, shared maple tree growing on the property line. Hilary Cunningham and Stephen Scharper, both professors at the University of Toronto, were not consulted by their neighbor and expressed concern about the ecological impacts of felling healthy trees.  They hired expert certified arborists who determined that the tree was healthy and recommended that it be preserved. They were shocked to learn that their situation was not unusual: every year in cities across Ontario, thousands of healthy, mature trees growing on property lines are arbitrarily cut down—often while neighbors are away on vacation or against their objections.

Despite the Scharpers' efforts to resolve the situation amicably (including an offer to fully pay for the maintenance of the tree), the neighbour rejected the opinion of expert certified arborists and took the couple to court. The Scharpers retained celebrated human rights and environmental lawyer, Clayton Ruby, and saved their maple tree. Their case also achieved a strong, unprecedented protection for ALL shared trees in Ontario. According to the landmark ruling by the Ontario Superior Court, it is now a criminal act to destroy a shared tree without the consent of a co-owner. Prior to this ruling, thousands of mature trees were arbitrarily cut down by one owner, leaving the other owner with little recourse and generating very harmful impacts on the shrinking urban canopies of many cities.

The Scharpers’s neighbor has recently filed an Appeal to overturn the Ruling. A reversal of the Ruling would be devastating for mature, healthy trees. But support of the Ruling at the Appeal level would create an even stronger legal precedent for trees not only in Ontario, but also Canada as a whole. The Scharpers have spent a substantial amount of their own money in court fees. They are asking for help to defend this unprecedented pro-Tree Ruling.

The Ruling is so important for trees in Ontario and Canada, and will impact the future and health of Canadians for generations to come. Please help raise funds to pay for the costs of defending the Ruling. 

For mailing address please contact Hilary Cunningham Scharper: hilary.cunningham@utoronto.ca  or 

hilary.scharper@gmail.com

Thank you for your contribution and/or words of support!

For more information on the Scharpers’ case visit

http://boundarytrees.com

against their objections.
Despite the Scharpers' efforts to resolve the situation amicably
(including an offer to fully pay for the maintenance of the tree), the
neighbour rejected the opinion of expert certified arborists and took the
couple to court. The Scharpers retained celebrated human rights and
environmental lawyer, Clayton Ruby, and saved their maple tree. Their case also
achieved a strong, unprecedented protection for ALL shared trees in
Ontario. According to the landmark ruling by the Ontario Superior Court, it is
now a criminal act to destroy a shared tree without the consent of a co-owner.
Prior to this ruling, thousands of mature trees were arbitrarily cut down by
one owner, leaving the other owner with little recourse and generating very
harmful impacts on the shrinking urban canopies of many cities.
The Scharpers’s neighbor has recently filed an Appeal to
overturn the Ruling. A reversal of the Ruling would be devastating for mature,
healthy trees. But support of the Ruling at the Appeal level would create an even
stronger legal precedent for trees not only in Ontario, but also Canada
as a whole. The Scharpers have spent a substantial amount of their own
money in court fees. They are asking for help to defend this unprecedented
pro-Tree Ruling.
The Ruling is so important for trees in Ontario and Canada, and
will impact the future and health of Canadians for generations to come. Please help raise funds to pay for
the costs of defending the Ruling. 
For
mailing address please contact Hilary Cunningham Scharper: hilary.cunningham@utoronto.ca  or hilary.scharper@gmail.com

Thank
you for your contribution and/or words of support!
For
more information on the Scharpers’ case visit
http://boundarytrees.com

story:
Each year, approximately 300 Million liters of fuel drips from fuel nozzles worldwide. Hazardous Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC's) fall to the ground and enter into the water we drink and the air we breath. These VOC's contribute to the formation of ground level ozone and smog, leading to respiratory illnesses such as asthma and emphysema. Join us in our campaign to eliminate the waste in refuelling. Lets do our part, together!

The ND-1 will help to make the world a little...

Healthier by protecting our fresh air and water supplies.

Greener by reducing our impact on the environment.

Cleaner by eliminating messy spills on car, clothes, and shoes.

More Economical by using every last drop of fuel that you've paid for.


A HUGE thanks to our supporters McMaster University, The RIC Center and FedDev who have all played an integral role in supporting the ND-1's development by providing crucial resources and funding. 

Becoming a Backer is easy! Simply choose the perk(s) which best suit you from the table below and we'll send everything right to your door! We have some awesome giveaways which will help save fuel and in turn save you money, and preserve our natural resources! DRAM thanks you and our planet thanks you! 

Not sure what SuperSpout is? Click here to learn more.

Interesting Fact: Spillage from fuel cans is a major issue! Each year in the US alone approximately 3.4 Million Liters of fuel are spilled as a result of fuel can spillage! SuperSpout will seriously reduce this spillage!

Click here to see images of some of our perks.

The contributions you make today will go a long way in supporting the development of the ND-1 and seeing dripless tech to it's full potential.  

Contributions will be put towards... 

  • Product development

  • Third party testing

  • Support pending patents 

  • Business Development and explore new market potential

We are a group of close-knit, young educated professionals with a true entrepreneurial spirit. We are motivated purely by making the world a cleaner, healthier place for future generations to come.

DEVIN RAMPHAL (Lead Entrepreneur and CEO)
"Success isn't a measure of your monetary value, but rather a measure of the positive change you bring to the world in the time that you are given."

 

NAV SAINI (Operations Lead)
"I believe that leading by example will allow others to follow in our footsteps and create the change this world requires for many generations to come. We do not inherit the Earth from our ancestors; we borrow it from our children, with this mentality we must constantly remind ourselves of our responsibilities."

SIMON OOMEN-HURST (Chief Innovations Engineer)
"I'm an engineer; and I see the world differently than most. Where one sees the wasted drops of fuel fall to the ground, I see a problem begging for a solution. Working with DRAM gives me an opportunity to combine my passion for practical and elegant problem solving with my desire to affect positive change within society; and inspire others to do the same."

JASON HARRISON (Innovations Engineer)
"Our society needs leaders to initiate changes to make our world better for ourselves and future generations. People like us, at DRAM, are those leaders." 

 

MICHAEL PETGRAVE (Marketing and Sales Specialist)
"After working at DRAM I have truly realized that impossible is nothing, especially when you mix hard work with perseverance. At DRAM I am able to utilize my creative mind to seek out real world environmental solutions for society and future generations to benefit from."

UMAIR SHAIKH (Information Systems and Legal Analyst)
"I joined DRAM Innovations for one reason. To change the world. All things start small, and the changes come incrementally, but the potential that we have is endless."

OSCAR LIU (Mechanical Intern)
"The reason I like to work at DRAM Innovations is that all of the people here are so motivated and inspiring. Everyone is trying to do their best at every moment. In this company, we all really enjoy our work and truly submerse ourselves in every stage of the project."


Want to help but just can't contribute? Not a problem! Your kind words are enough. Go ahead, Share us on facebook by clicking the facebook icon. Follow us on Twitter! Tell your friends and family about the cause! The more awareness we raise the more fuel we save!

story:
Introduction

Four Season Foraging is a Minneapolis-based business founded by me, Maria Wesserle. I have been harvesting wild foods and medicines for about 13 years, and I love to share this skill with others! Since 2008 I have been regularly teaching wild edible and other nature-based workshops. This project is the manifestation of my desire to help other people develop meaningful and sustainable relationships with the non-human world.

Four Season Foraging connects people with the resources necessary to start harvesting and preparing wild foods and medicines. By recommending sources, writing blog posts, and offering classes, I will establish new foragers and inspire experienced ones. Currently, I update the blog weekly with information about identifying, harvesting, and preparing wild foods and medicines. I plan to organize two workshops monthly during the peak harvest season from May through October, and have a few available during the off-season as well. But I need your help to get started!

 

Extra Stretch Goal

Thanks so much for all your support! I have reached my original goal of $650 and my original stretch goal of $800 in only one and a half days! Hot dang! I never imagined I would receive such an outpouring of support!

In light of this, I think it's important to list more concrete things I will spend the money on. At the present time, I have $860 in contributions. Minus the $43 in platform fees and the $29.70 in credit card fees, I have $787.30 in actual funds coming toward me. The money will be spent as follows:

  • $350 for general liability insurance, needed to teach public classes
  • $235 for reference books to enhance workshop curriculum 
  • $150 for a printer to produce workshop materials
  • $25 for a tripod to improve plant identification videos
  • $20 for a battery pack to keep my phone charged while shooting video and taking photos for blog posts

In addition to blogging, I plan to produce short plant identification videos and make them free to stream. This way, even more people can get a taste of the Four Season Foraging workshop experience!

And I have a new stretch goal of $1200! 

If you help me reach this goal, $60 will go toward platform fees and approximately $40 will go toward credit card fees, leaving me $1100 in spendable funds. In addition to the items listed above, the money will be used as follows:

  • $320 for a wild edibles workshop scholarship fund

At $20 a workshop, this will allow 16 people to attend my workshops for free! Scholarship funds will be reserved for people with low income, people of color, and indigenous people.

If I don't reach $1200, whatever additional money is raised will go toward the scholarship fund. 

 

Budget- Goal met!

As a small, community-based business, Four Season Foraging doesn't need much to kickoff. The goal is set at $650 to fulfill two main needs:

  • $350 for general liability insurance, needed to teach public classes
  • $235 for reference books to enhance workshop curriculum 

General liability insurance is necessary to begin teaching classes. I've already received a quote, and $350 is the estimated amount for a year's worth of insurance. 

Not all information sources are created equal; having books from trusted authors is essential to foraging! Books will be made available to students at workshops, and will help me fact-check when writing blog posts or teaching. Also, when it comes to foraging you never stop learning, and the more that I know, the more that I can teach!

In addition to the two items listed above, there are fees to take into account when running an Indiegogo campaign:

  • $32.50 in platform fees (5% of total)
  • $32.50 in credit card fees (estimate, 3% plus $0.30 of each donation)

 

Stretch Goal- Goal met!

If my campaign raises more than $650 (and I sincerely hope it does!) I will spend up to an additional $100 on books. However, if I raise an additional $150 and reach my stretch goal of $800, I will be able to use that money to buy a printer to produce workshop materials! Any money raised beyond that will go directly toward workshop costs.
 

Perks!

Donate to my campaign and receive the following:

 

 

Why It Matters

There are no regularly scheduled foraging workshops in the Twin Cities. I have seen parks, restaurants, and organizations offer workshops here and there, but nothing to meet the current demand. Furthermore, not all of these workshops are affordable or otherwise accessible. Four Season Foraging will keep events as affordable as possible by offering classes at different price levels. Furthermore, I welcome people of all backgrounds, and will make an effort to hold workshops that are family-friendly and wheelchair-accessible. 

In my role as a program coordinator and educator at various non-profits, I have witnessed first-hand the positive impact of picking ones own foods and medicines. Children, adults, and elders are equally delighted when they discover edible plants that grow right in their own backyard! Furthermore, food has the power to connect people with each other. And if that food is harvested from the wild, there's a connection with the landbase as well. In this increasingly detached culture, I feel it is of utmost importance to cultivate these relationships.

 

Credentials

In addition to my nearly 10 years of teaching experience, I have worked closely with nonprofits for approximately 15 years. (See a few articles that speak to my previous work!) In my various roles I have learned essential organizational skills, including fundraising, event planning, web design, and database management. In 2013 founded a 501(c)3 nonprofit with five associates. There I earned administrative proficiency by team managing the organization, coordinating programs, tracking finances, and ensuring compliance with state and federal governments. North Country Food Alliance is still going strong, but I resigned in 2016 to pursue other projects; which is what brings me here today. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's okay! Please inform family, friends, and acquaintances of my campaign. Tell them in person or use the share buttons above!

You can also follow my Instagram, Facebook, or subscribe to updates. 

Thank you!

 

Credits

Music by (in order of appearance):

  • Jim Rooster / "Come Away" / CC BY 3.0 US
  • Lee Rosevere / "Love Wins" / CC BY 4.0
  • Mystery Mammal / "Starchild" / CC BY-SA 4.0

story:
The Glashan Schoolyard Greening Project

Intro

Grey today, green tomorrow! We're transforming the schoolyard of Ottawa's Glashan Public School and need your help.

Our schoolyard in the Centretown neighbourhood of Ottawa has been described as bleak, grey and uninspiring.

The Glashan Schoolyard Greening Project is about positive transformations: from grey to green; from passive to active; from ordinary to extraordinary.


What We Need

The $9,000 we hope to raise through this Indiegogo campaign will go directly to the critical first phase of our greening plan:

  • breaking up the asphalt in our schoolyard (a huge undertaking);
  • preparing the ground for tree planting; and
  • with any funds left, purchasing more trees!

 

 

Additional fundraising efforts are happening right now to finance other important components of our project. We have received and continue to seek grants from a range of funders. We enjoy help from the City of Ottawa and the Ottawa-Carleton District School Board. And generous support from organizations, businesses, sponsor, and individual contributors continues to grow.

How You Can Help

  • Make a generous contribution right here on this page and join our Tree of Thanks (for contributions of $100 and up)!
  • Spread the word about our campaign using Indiegogo's handy sharing tools!
  • Like our Facebook page to engage with other project supporters and stay in the loop!

 

For the past year, consultations have been on-going with students, the school community, the school board, the city and others to develop a site concept plan, detailed budget and timelines.

We are fundraising through events big and small, grants from a wide variety of organizations and sponsors. Money raised will go towards the different project components.

Money from this Indiegogo campaign - we're hoping to raise $9,000CAD - will go towards the breaking up of the asphalt and preparing the ground for planting trees. If we make more than we have requested, the money will go towards more trees!

 

Glashan Greening: Who, What & Why

One of Ottawa's oldest schools, Glashan is situated in the inner-city, next to the city's main bus terminal and a gas station, surrounded by busy streets and the city's main highway. Glashan's 400 grade 7 and 8 students come from economically, socially and culturally diverse backgrounds.

An initiative of the Glashan School Council "Green Team", the Glashan Schoolyard Greening Project has developed through consultations with students, the school community, the school board, the City and others.

Proposed outcomes of our greening plan include:

  • re-definition of active and quiet areas;
  • depaving a number of sections of the yard;
  • creation of naturalized spaces with rocks and logs for seating;
  • small, raised stage for performances;
  • three semi-circular seating areas for use as social spaces and outdoor teaching;
  • newly planted trees on the street allowances part of the space;
  • rehabilitation of the octagon space.

Learn more about what we're doing at:

  • our Facebook page
  • our Glashan Schoolyard Greening Project website
  • Glashan May Newsletter

 

Why Schoolyard Greening is Important

Lack of green in schoolyards is not just an aesthetic problem. Research shows significant correlations between children's outdoor play and green schoolyards and positive educational and health outcomes. "Nature deficit," as some call it, is linked to attention deficit disorder (ADD)/attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), behavioural problems, aggression and poor mental health. What's more, there are obvious physical and health benefits of active play outdoors.

Learn more at: http://glashangreening.ca/schoolyard-greening/

story:
We all know that most children have worries.  You child may have a fear of the dark or of sleeping alone - or even maybe sometimes they feel just a little different and left out.

This has promoted me to produce a series of APP stories for parents and children that deal simply and sensitively with these childhood issues.

What better way to put my two passions together than by creating Vegetable Islands, each with a friendly vegetable who finds a positive way to resolve a personal puzzle?

I believe that happy hearts are healthy hearts, so the interactive links in the e-stories also reveal fun facts about the featured vegetable and it's special contribution to your child's physical development.

Today's children, raised in a fast food culture are falling victim to obesity, diabetes, early heart disease and have poor protection from common coughs and colds.  Lack of exercise is also a factor.  

All the vegetables in these stories actively explore their island, where each discovers something more precious than gold.  

Each Vegetable Islands e-story includes a recipe for tasty, easy to cook vegetable dish. This dish is just a suggestion and not the be all and end all of the perfect vegetable dish for your child.

These 10 self-contained stories are designed to be downloaded and read individually on an IPad or tablet with my downloadable APP.

By entering in the details of the reader, makes the APP SPECIAL to them alone!

Imagine having a book written JUST FOR YOU! Remember too, that you can change the name of the person that it is written for as well, so that it can potentially be shared around the one family as well...

Set out today on your family's adventure to a happier and healthier future!

Make A Carrot Character!

Funny facts about Carrots!

Snippets from the Carrot Story -

  • Delete

story:
What is it about?

110 geography-related students from all over Europe will learn and discuss about the topic "Green City - Sustainable | Urban | Development" in Marburg, Germany. 

The leading questions of the congress are

       - What defines a green city?

       - How to identify "the way to go" for a city to become green?

       - How to to mobilize cities for the upcoming changes?


What do you support?

 Through our participants fee we are able to cover most of the costs for accommodation and food. 

The 10,000€ will cover the scientific program of our congress which includes expenses for:

+ 7 Workshops + field trips 

+ 5 - 7 Excursions 

+ Inviting 3 external professional speakers 

+ covering the cost for all material expenses (papers, flip charts etc.)

All supporters will get the congress-report as pdf.

During the congress we will offer 7 workshops connected with field trips, 3 lectures with professional guest speakers from all over Germany and 5 - 7 excursions in the surrounding area of Frankfurt a.M.. - all related to the topic of our congress. The participants will gain extended knowledge in all three dimensions of sustainability - environmental, social and economic. We're also working on sustainable Wise Up's to improve the daily life awareness of our participants and organize challenges about sustainable traveling and garbage recycling.


Who are we?

The "European Geography Association for students and young geographers" was founded in 1988 and has its headquarter in Utrecht, The Nederlands. The main aim was from the beginning to have an intercultural exchange about scientific knowledge as well as social and cultural life for geography students from all over Europe.
Nowadays our organisation has over 90 entities in all over Europe and far over the EU boarders, reaching from Israel to Norway and from Georgia to UK. We are strictly organized from students for students and offer several events during the year for our members as well as the chance to engage in Scientific projects like our very own scientific paper the "Euopean Geographer".
As geographers we have a brought field of studies stretching from geology, climate, biodiversity over spatial planing, cultural dynamics, tourism and of course Geographical Information System just to name a few of them. It is our aim to exchange and combine the knowledge and methods of our members to extend the knowledge about the space we are all sharing and living in together.

Why Green Cities matter!

Cities are shaping our daily life significantly, as already today every second person lives in an urban environment! Over the last decades, humans made cities their “natural habitat” and still tend to exclude nature out of it.

By the year 2050 more than two-third of the world population will be living in cities. This represents a number of 6.4 billion people. Worldwide people immigrate to cities, hoping to find a better place to live. Urban development creates new and unknown problems. The question of space in urban areas, access to clean water, intensive traffic and increase of environmental pollution are just a few examples of the challenges that cities are facing all over the world.

As we are facing global problems we have to rethink our behavior to create conditions on earth worth living, also for future generations.

For this reason we are trying to spread and extend the knowledge about sustainable projects in cities and to find new ways to improve those methods used and create new ones to work together for a more worth-living-environment in our cities. 


Risks & Challenges

As a non-profit student organisation it is already a hard challenge to find enough funding for such a large event over 6 days as we have no source of income.
Through our own ambitions to offer an exceeding program including to invite external guest speakers, offering field trips as well as excursions and serve high quality food we intensified our need for support to realize our ideas and be able to offer our participants the best learning experience they can receive. 

Other ways to help us

If you like our event and you want to help us please spread the word and share our event and point it directly out to persons or organisations who might be interested in helping us to realize our event either by funding, scientific or spiritual support. 

Thank you very much,

The Orgateam of the WRC 2015
story_txt:
What is it about? 
110 geography-related students from all over Europe will learn and discuss about the topic "Green City - Sustainable | Urban | Development" in Marburg, Germany. 
The leading questions of the congress are
       - What defines a green city?
       - How to identify "the way to go" for a city to become green?
       - How to to mobilize cities for the upcoming changes?

story:
The Joliet Franciscan sisters have always been committed to peace, hospitality, and regard for the poor and oppressed.  At our time in history, we are surrounded by critical and massive injustices: devastation of natural resources, human trafficking, sex slavery, racism, pollution.

How can we be part of healing the crisis of today?  Bluestem Earth Festival: Living with Justice and Care is an effort of the Joliet Franciscan Sisters and Associates.

  • This free event will feature a variety of earth friendly activities such as workshops, eco-conscious exhibits and vendors, entertainment and children's activities. There will also be speakers addressing contemporary social concerns such as human trafficking and water issues.  A tour of the historic Motherhouse building on the grounds of the USF campus, food and music performances from a few local bands will round out the day. 


The funding we are seeking would cover the costs of producing this event and keeping it free for the local community:

  • Some funds will be used to rent tables, chairs, curtains and tents.
  • Some funds will be used for advertising.
  • All of the funds received will help the Earth Festival.


Help improve the world, one small change at a time:

  • If each person who attends the festival makes one change in his/her life, it will make a difference in the world.
  • Our first Bluestem Earth Festival was held in 2014 and offered about 60 vendors, exhibitors, speakers and attracted about 300 guests.


The Bluestem Earth Festival is an exciting challenge. We bring together vendors, exhibitors, and speakers in both indoor and outdoor venues.

  • We can overcome any challenges since we have a dedicated team of volunteers and the full support of the University of St. Francis.
  • The only thing out of our control is rain!!!
  • Each year, we challenge our team to recruit more exhibitors and vendors in hopes of increasing festival attendance and promote more businesses.


If you cannot contribute:

  • Follow us on Facebook and share our page with your friends.

    • Attend the festival! Bring your family and friends.

    • Use the Indiegogo share tools found below our video at the top of this page to help spread the word about our campaign!

story:
Short Summary

The students at École KLO Middle School are working tirelessly, against all odds, to try to restore the lost turtle habitat on their school grounds which has been covered by concrete pads. But this re-naturalization doesn’t just give the blue-listed Western Painted Turtles a safe place to grow up away from the school’s long jump sandpits. It will create a mutually beneficial learning and growing environment for the human and more-than-human inhabitants in the natural world at École KLO Middle School.

What We Need & What You Get

These students need your help to get there. Your donation will give these students the outdoor learning environment they need to succeed, and the habitat the more-than-human students of École KLO Middle School, like the baby Western Painted Turtles that hatch in its sandpits every year, need to live. 

And for every donation of $10 or more, these students have volunteered to make a wooden turtle with your name on it to be installed in their outdoor classroom and turtle habitat, forever showing our gratitude for your support of their education.

The Impact

The students at École KLO Middle School have been working on a now seven-year struggle to restore the often flooded concrete-covered wetland habitat that once ran through their school grounds. Initiated by students’ discovery of blue-listed Western Painted Turtle eggs in their long jump sand pits, this school’s community began to restore the species’ disappearing habitat. Originally challenged to raise $100,000 their school board for this habitat’s restoration, multiple “generations” of students remarkably raised $86,000 Unfortunately, in an updated quote, these students recently discovered their project will now cost half a million dollars. Although dismayed and disappointed, through work on this issue, the students and teachers involved ended up creating a process of discovery- how the natural world is an educational resource gold mine.

Risks & Challenges

This project will be starting the first phase of its development this summer. This means a small section of the re-naturalization will take place but no more than that and the rest will have to be implemented over a longer period of time in subsequent phases. Although it is a good thing that this is actually beginning to happen, it is more intrusive and not as beneficial to the human and more-than-human natural community on the school grounds. The reason this has to be started is because it has taken so long to raise just a 5th of the funds for this project some of the grants these students have received are about to time-out. Unfortunately, going 7 years for every $86,000 is just not a feasible option for these students, the first "generation" of whom are now starting University. With your support, this doesn't have to take the next 30 YEARS to happen, in a world of disappearing funds for the natural in education and a disappearing presence of the environment in the lives of young people, these students need their natural learning environment just as much as those baby turtles need this living environment, 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You can also buy the book these students have published to raise funds for this project which shares each of their unique experiences learning from and caring for the natural world.

    eBook: http://www.amazon.ca/This-My-Classroom-Created-Leaders-ebook/dp/B00KTUZG9G/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1402207111&sr=1-1&keywords=this+is+my+classroom+shimshon+obadia

    Print book: https://www.createspace.com/4845799 

    For more on the Daylighting the Classroom project, visit: www.ShimshonObadia.com  & www.EcoArtIncubator.com
