story:
THE CHALLENGE

URKU, with its seven hectares of rainforest, is situated within the buffer zone of the Cordillera Escalera Protected Area, a few kilometres from the city of Tarapoto, Peru. We are a community centre that promotes life in harmony with nature and the responsible management of its resources. We work together as a team of professionals, interns, scientists and volunteers to rescue animals from illegal wildlife trade and strengthen conservation efforts in Amazonia. Our fundraising campaign, “RESCUE TO RELEASE”, seeks to raise urgently needed funds to scale up our activities of wildlife rescue and release. We aim to release 500 animals back to their original habitats per year and build awareness on wildlife conservation by sharing our important message with 15,000 annual visitors at the centre.

    Current inhabitants of Urku Centre: channel-billed toucan and the large rodent "picuro mama". Picuro mama likes to sit back and grab on to food with its paws while eating. (Photo: M. Helve)

 

ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE, AN ISSUE THAT CONCERNS US ALL

Illegal wildlife trade is a global issue that has a destabilising effect on both our ecosystems, as well as our society, and hinders sustainable development. It is the fourth largest illegal trade in the world and continues to operate at such vast scale due to the lack of control and weak government enforcement. Illegal traders exploit loopholes and wild-caught animals are extensively laundered, i.e. declared and sold as legal captive-bred animals. 

Peru’s rainforests harbour an immensely rich fauna, which is sadly disappearing at an alarming rate. Illegal wildlife trade is the second main cause of defaunation after habitat destruction. Hundreds of species are exploited; parrots, parakeets, macaws and turtles are particularly targeted for pet trade and their use as tourist attractions. Other animals, regrettably, have high value as skins, furs and leathers. 

A pair of scarlet macaws that live freely in our centre and its surrounding forest enjoying the fresh rain. (Photo: M. Helve)

 

In Peru, it is estimated that 20 animals are captured illegally from the wild every minute. According to the environmental authorities, more than 5000 specimens were confiscated between 2013 and 2017 just in our province, San Martín. The most common animals were various species of parakeets, parrots, and macaws, primates such as capuchins and Andean saddle-back tamarins, South-American coati, yellow-footed tortoises (vulnerable according to the IUCN Redlist), yellow-spotted Amazon river turtles (vulnerable according to the IUCN Redlist), and sloths.

Yellow-spotted Amazon river turtle basking in the early morning sun. The species is threatened with extinction, mainly due to illegal trafficking. (Photo: M. Helve)

Unfortunately, due to the poor taxonomic understanding and species identification skills of intercepting authorities, the existing data suffers from major inaccuracy and gaps. For example, smaller animals such as poisonous frogs and exotic butterflies are conspicuously absent from these registries, yet they are extremely prevalent in wildlife trade. To make matters worse, once an animal is rescued by the authorities, it is rarely guaranteed a safe journey back to its habitat. Unfortunately, more than 90% of all rescued animals in Peru have to be put down or die because of inadequate facilities, and lack of professional care and critical resources. Moreover, animals rescued from the networks of illegal trade can carry a series of parasites and diseases that will put wild populations at risk. Appropriate rescue and release programme must apply bio-security protocols to avoid the introduction of a potential threat to the species.

 

URKU’S CONTRIBUTION TO CONSERVATION

   

Interns Thalía and Rodolfo in the daily activity of feeding our animals. (Photo: M. Helve)

 

Since 2006, Urku Centre has sheltered over a thousand wild animals representing 61 species, of which approximately 30% were returned to the wild. A great majority of them have been wild animals rescued from illegal wildlife trade. Wild animals are confiscated by the authorities from people’s homes, where they are kept as pets in often inhumane conditions; or are intercepted along the trade routes heading for international markets.

We at Urku work tirelessly, yet despite our greatest efforts and all that we have accomplished to date, we consider our impact small in comparison with the magnitude of illegal wildlife trade in Peru. The running of Urku Centre and its animal inhabitants requires a highly dedicated team of professionals, interns and volunteers throughout the year. Each animal requires feeding twice a day, water, veterinary care, and appropriate shelter, as well as an enriched environment with stimulation to ensure its overall welfare. To sustain our operating costs, Urku Centre receives 12,000 visitors annually from all over the world. We put great emphasis on environmental education to create behavioural shift in the society and reduce the demand and offer for illicitly sold wild animals, as well as the number of persons that take to poaching as a livelihood.

Alfredo teaching visitors about the complex life cycle of butterflies and the work carried out at the butterfly nursery. (Photo: M. Helve)

 

SCALING UP OUR IMPACT

Our alternative vision counts on your participation. We firmly believe that a greater mass of people supporting our mission can be the decisive force to make a change. Be part of the movement to stop the illegal activities that destroy our rainforests and wetlands and deplete populations of wild animals. As Amazonians and guardians of the forest, we seek to restore the lost connection with our natural home. We’ve therefore turned to crowdfunding, as we believe that our voices in concert can act against illegal networks and political apathy. Urku receives no state or regional funding and proudly self-sustains its operations.

However, we now make a special appeal to take our activities to the next level. Our existing enclosures and aviaries need improvement and renovation, we need to systematise our work to become more efficient and thus be able to shelter more animals. Most importantly, we want to rescue to release them. The fundamental goal is always that the animals rescued from illegal trade are released back into the wild and according to correct protocol. Unfortunately, this is often unfeasible because the animals no longer have the skills to survive on their own due to their trafficking experience. 

We currently release, on average, 50 animals to their natural habitat per year. We want the number of animals released per year to rise to 500, focusing our efforts on the following groups: parrots, small reptiles and amphibians. Furthermore, there is a pressing need for the monitoring of released animals in the wild, an activity which currently does not exist in Peru.

USE THIS MINUTE TO HELP URKU

Your donations will enable us to improve our facilities, enrich the animals’ environment, purchase vaccinations and medication, animal manipulation equipment (workwear, leather gloves, nets, sedation kits, transfer cages), high-quality laboratory tests, as well as radiotracking equipment and camera traps for post-release monitoring.

We hope that the global community will hear our appeal and show support for our work and mission. Your participation and help, in all corners of the world, is indispensable. Our goal is to raise US$ 25,000 to scale up our impact. We are eternally grateful for your time, donations and interest, and want you to know that all the money will go directly to the welfare of animals and raising awareness about rainforest conservation. Make sure that Urku is just a phase on the life journey of these wild animals, not the final stop. Help us RESCUE TO RELEASE.

 

 

For your donations, we offer the following gifts:

$ 10 Virtual postcard (Receive a virtual postcard from one of our animals)

$ 30 Virtual postcard + updates (Receive a virtual postcard from one of our animals and monthly updates on our work to your email)

$ 50 Handwoven chumbi (Traditional belt handwoven by the Quechua women from the Huallaga communities. Chumbi brings ancestral energy and strength to its user)

$ 100 Three options, choose a favourite (Choose your favourite out of three options: A Story Book (Kutumachakuy, the story of the first Quechua peoples and the Mother of the Woods. Text in English, Spanish, French, Italian and German), Urku T-shirt or set of 4 small “Urku” glasses.

$ 200 Sponsor a day at Urku for children (In gratitude to your donation, we will organise a full day of activities at Urku centre for 15 children from a local community. They will learn about wild animals, forest conservation and enjoy a healthy lunch with us.)

$ 500 Adopt and name an animal (You get to name one of the animals that we receive at Urku centre and follow its journey up to its release. You will receive updates, photos and videos of the animal’s progress)

$ 1000 Lifetime pass to Urku for the whole family (You and your family have a lifetime free pass to visit Urku centre. The pass includes a Nocturnal Wildlife Walk to get a peek at the diversity of forest animals that come out at night! If you cannot come to Urku, we offer… instead.)

$ 5000 7 days with Urku (We welcome you to spend a week with our team and get to know what wildlife rescue involves. You will also enjoy a personalised tour of local cultural and natural attractions, from waterfalls to agroecological farms and indigenous communities. Accommodation at an ecolodge included.)

 

SPREAD THE WORD!

If you cannot make a donation, there are many other equally valuable ways to make a difference:

  • Please share our campaign with your friends and family in person and over social networks
  • Talk to people about illegal wildlife trade and the plight of rainforest animals
  • Become a volunteer! We always welcome volunteers to help at our rescue centre. For more information, please visit: www.urkuperu.com
  • Donate equipment and materials directly to our rescue centre. 
  • Write to your local authorities and demand better governance mechanisms to regulate wildlife trade.

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram to stay in touch!

 

Our two "maqui sapas", Peruvian spider monkeys, await a larger enclosure.  In Quechua "maqui" means hand and "sapa" means large. (Photo: M. Helve)

Our alternative vision counts on your participation. We firmly believe that a greater mass of people supporting our mission can be the decisive force to make a change. Be part of the movement to stop the illegal activities that destroy our rainforests and wetlands and deplete populations of wild animals. As Amazonians and guardians of the forest, we seek to restore the lost connection with our natural home. We’ve therefore turned to crowdfunding, as we believe that our voices in concert can act against illegal networks and political apathy. Urku receives no state or regional funding and proudly self-sustains its operations.
However, we now make a special appeal to take our activities to the next level. Our existing enclosures and aviaries need improvement and renovation, we need to systematise our work to become more efficient and thus be able to shelter more animals. Most importantly, we want to rescue to release them. The fundamental goal is always that the animals rescued from illegal trade are released back into the wild and according to correct protocol. Unfortunately, this is often unfeasible because the animals no longer have the skills to survive on their own due to their trafficking experience. 
We currently release, on average, 50 animals to their natural habitat per year. We want the number of animals released per year to rise to 500, focusing our efforts on the following groups: parrots, small reptiles and amphibians. Furthermore, there is a pressing need for the monitoring of released animals in the wild, an activity which currently does not exist in Peru.

USE THIS MINUTE TO HELP URKU
Your donations will enable us to improve our facilities, enrich the animals’ environment, purchase vaccinations and medication, animal manipulation equipment (workwear, leather gloves, nets, sedation kits, transfer cages), high-quality laboratory tests, as well as radiotracking equipment and camera traps for post-release monitoring.
We hope that the global community will hear our appeal and show support for our work and mission. Your participation and help, in all corners of the world, is indispensable. Our goal is to raise US$ 25,000 to scale up our impact. We are eternally grateful for your time, donations and interest, and want you to know that all the money will go directly to the welfare of animals and raising awareness about rainforest conservation. Make sure that Urku is just a phase on the life journey of these wild animals, not the final stop. Help us RESCUE TO RELEASE.
 
 
For your donations, we offer the following gifts:
$ 10 Virtual postcard (Receive a virtual postcard from one of our animals)
$ 30 Virtual postcard + updates (Receive a virtual postcard from one of our animals and monthly updates on our work to your email)
$ 50 Handwoven chumbi (Traditional belt handwoven by the Quechua women from the Huallaga communities. Chumbi brings ancestral energy and strength to its user)
$ 100 Three options, choose a favourite (Choose your favourite out of three options: A Story Book (Kutumachakuy, the story of the first Quechua peoples and the Mother of the Woods. Text in English, Spanish, French, Italian and German), Urku T-shirt or set of 4 small “Urku” glasses.

$ 200 Sponsor a day at Urku for children (In gratitude to your donation, we will organise a full day of activities at Urku centre for 15 children from a local community. They will learn about wild animals, forest conservation and enjoy a healthy lunch with us.)
$ 500 Adopt and name an animal (You get to name one of the animals that we receive at Urku centre and follow its journey up to its release. You will receive updates, photos and videos of the animal’s progress)
$ 1000 Lifetime pass to Urku for the whole family (You and your family have a lifetime free pass to visit Urku centre. The pass includes a Nocturnal Wildlife Walk to get a peek at the diversity of forest animals that come out at night! If you cannot come to Urku, we offer… instead.)
$ 5000 7 days with Urku (We welcome you to spend a week with our team and get to know what wildlife rescue involves. You will also enjoy a personalised tour of local cultural and natural attractions, from waterfalls to agroecological farms and indigenous communities. Accommodation at an ecolodge included.)
 
SPREAD THE WORD!
If you cannot make a donation, there are many other equally valuable ways to make a difference:

Please share our campaign with your friends and family in person and over social networks
Talk to people about illegal wildlife trade and the plight of rainforest animals
Become a volunteer! We always welcome volunteers to help at our rescue centre. For more information, please visit: www.urkuperu.com

Donate equipment and materials directly to our rescue centre. 
Write to your local authorities and demand better governance mechanisms to regulate wildlife trade.

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram to stay in touch!
 

Our two "maqui sapas", Peruvian spider monkeys, await a larger enclosure.  In Quechua "maqui" means hand and "sapa" means large. (Photo: M. Helve)

story:
Our Story

   As a leader in raising environmental awareness within the underground world of skimboarding, Sol Shred Skim will be holding its 2nd Annual UCAN Beach Clean-up at the World Championship of Skimboarding (WCS) on July 16-17, 2011.  Since the late 70s, this highly anticipated contest has traditionally taken place at Aliso Beach Park of Laguna Beach, CA.  Although the landscape of the beach park is quite attractive to visitors and locals, the pollution and debris spewing out of Aliso Creek (which divides the area in half) is certainly not.  Many people do not realize how contaminated the urban runoff is until they see warning signs highlighting the harmful effects of entering the water (especially after rainy days). 

   The question is:  “What CAN U do about the situation?”  The solution is simple.  UCAN Clean-up Aliso!  UCAN stands for. . . yoU Contribute Awareness Necessary.  This beach clean-up campaign was launched last year by Sol Shred Skim at the WCS due to the approval of the contest's main host -- Victoria Skimboards.  Tex Haines, founder & owner of Victoria Skimboards, was so pleased with the conscious idea that he designated it as an annual ritual coinciding with the WCS from 2010 and beyond. 


The Impact

   At the apex of all living organisms that thrive on this planet, humans contain the power to act on anything their minds create.  With such an amazing gift, why not give back to Mama Earth and her oceans whenever possible?  There are plenty of ways to reciprocate the love she offers us freely.  Grocery shopping with reusable bags and drinking water from stainless steel or aluminum containers is more than just a "green" fad nowadays.  The future of our precious planet relies on the choices we make as an entire species and it is our responsibility to acclimate to the changing courses of the present.  Sol Shred Skim's biggest passion is to lead by example and inspire those along the journey with us.  Remember. . . yoU Contribute Awareness Necessary so take the initiative to clean the beaches we love to play on!

  

What We Need & What You Get


   Last year, $1330 was invested in the inaugural UCAN Beach Clean-up (not including product from sponsors).  Every volunteer who helped clean the beach was given a trash bag and a pair of gloves.  When 18 volunteers brought back their stuffed trash bags, each of them received a raffle ticket and a chance to win prizes donated by a handful of sponsors. 


Here is the clear breakdown:

$30 - Trash bags & gloves

$100 - UCAN banner

$200 - Stickers

$400 - Reusable bags printed with inaugural UCAN art

$600 - UCAN trucker hats 


   This year, Sol Shred Skim plans to order reusable water bottles with our logo on them.  Based on last year's budget, since we still have the UCAN banner, we will be able to put that $100 toward our goal to downsize the use of plastic water bottles.  Realistically, Sol Shred Skim needs to raise over $1000 to be on the same level of succession as last year.  We have humbly set a goal for $888 to assure that we reach it.  If we do not meet our campaign's goal, Sol Shred Skim will gratefully take what is available and work with the funds in a frugal manner.  We also have the option of asking previous and/or prospective sponsors for money instead of product.  


Perks


   We have 2 limited edition trucker hats, designed by artist Hunter Trevelyan Wyndham, in black and brown left from the inaugural UCAN Beach Clean-up.  As an incentive, we are offering them to the first 2 individuals who donate $50 to our campaign.

   Also, a one-of-a-kind loose fitting cotton black dress with an adjustable waistline and Sol Shred Skim logos (size Small) will go to the first individual who donates $100.


Other Ways You Can Help


   If you truly believe in our campaign and would like to help us raise the maximum amount of funds, please feel free to share our story and profile through word-of-mouth, email, and social networking.  Thank you for all of your support and love!

story:
Hapiculture is a project, starting locally in Belgium, to help save our HONEYBEE. Our goal is to treat bees as-natural-as-possible and to re-introduce healthy bees in the environment, in "nest-boxes". We see these imitations of hollow trees as bee reserves.

To get to these healthy bees, we use a specific method of taking care for our bees. This method is called "apicentric beekeeping" because the bees' natural needs are central, where they should be.

It is absolutely necessary to do something to save the natural genetics of Apis Mellifera, we have been suppressing swarming and natural selection for too long. To get characteristics that are interesting for human exploitation, we have been selecting one-sided, and many bees are clones, bred through artificial insemination of ONLY 1000 sources! Hapiculture doesn't do things like that, we always work as natural as possible.

Our project

We have the ambition to start this in our own locality, and then to spread this gradually. For the research, we work together with the zoo-physiology lab of the University of Ghent and the Belgian Information Centre for Beekeeping. This will make it possible to exchange valuable information worldwide, and to work towards a transition of how people think about exploiting nature!

In order to take a good start, we need about 100 hives with bees from different, locally adapted sources. They need to be placed in a bio-diverse area at minimal distances of 500-1000 meter. And these bees need to be managed in a way that is good for them. They know best themselves, so we let them bee. We don't open their hive, we don't move them around, and we don't take their honey.

More information about apicentric beekeeping can be found on our website http://hapicultuur.be, you can also ask questions in our forum or by e-mail. (info@hapicultuur.be)

What We Need & What You Get

We are working with nest-boxes for bees, and different vertical top-bar hives. We make them ourselves but 100 hives will cost $ 11,000. Putting bees in these hives will cost about $ 198 each, thats $ 19,800. We feed new hives with honey mixed with special herbal tea; 1250 kilo local honey costs $ 6,875, herbs $ 2,175. Then we have transport costs, estimated at $ 3,000, and we need about $ 29,150 to pay someone to work on this full-time. We prefer crowd funding over subsidy because it makes the project completely independent. Hapiculture is a bio-diversity project, NOT A BUSINESS.

We have interesting and unique perks, and we want every contributor to feel part of our project. Only because of your gifts, we can manage to save the bees. ACTUALY, THIS IS YOUR CHANCE TO GIVE SOMETHING BACK TO THE BEES !

In case we don't reach our funding goal, we would adjust the project and still continue with it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please talk about this important project with everyone, it's allowed to make some noise for a good cause! Share this in personal mail, Facebook, Twitter and such, visit and 'like' our FB page www.facebook.com/pages/Hapicultuur/246934258717439,  use the Indiegogo share tools, post comments, everything you wish to contribute is welcome... After all, it's for the good of every living creature.

Support

This project is supported by some 'famous' people:

David J. Heaf welcomes our apicentric beekeeping initiative. He's a beekeeper and has a similar project in the U.K. He is the author of 'The Bee-friendly Beekeeper'. (http://www.bee-friendly.co.uk/)

Environmental activist Vandana Shiva blesses and supports Hapiculture because of the importance of it and because of the connection between bees and seeds. Seed freedom is one of her points of interest. No bees, no seeds. And vice versa. (http://www.navdanya.org/)

Beekeeper Jacqueline Freeman also thinks this is a great idea. She may even pick it up and start the U.S. version of it together with Michael Thiele. They also give sacred beekeeping classes. (http://www.friendlyhaven.com/)

Michael Thiele is a very enthousiastic beekeeper too. He writes: "I am finding your project very very interesting and even more so: very important. (...) If I could speak as an emissary of the bees, I would probably deliver joy and gratefulness, and love and happiness  from bees to you." (http://gaiabees.com/)

Simon Buxton also supports our project and our vision. He says this is a most important initiative and gives us our blessing. His book 'The Shamanic Way of the Bee" was a big inspiration in the creation of Hapiculture. (http://www.sacredtrust.org/)

Debra Roberts is another known beekeeper who fully supports us. She also runs Holy Bee Press. She writes: "I am following your project with interest.  It is a very good thing you are doing and I am hoping that many many people can give a little and a few people can donate a lot, so you can meet your goal." (http://holybeepress.com/)

story:
Organic local agriculture is in need of reviving here on the North Shore and we are doing it by having a festival on the farm. We are bringing  the farm back to life with new energy and celebrating with music,food,cooking classes,yoga,workshops,wellness, and education. The goal is to save agricultural land and our way of life by putting lands in use and creating new and sustainable business in our area . Mature fruit trees,water,medicinal plants,hardwoods, and animals are already here. Now we need to  bring the local community and visitors together to celebrate, brainstorm, and create more small sustainable businesses that improve the quality of life for all!  This  rural community and visitor destination has enormous potential.  Improvements offer alternatives to over development and gentrification. In honor of Martin Luther King Jr we are aiming to let freedom ring by providing a network of opportunities for anyone who seeks to improve the quality of life.

 

Optimysstique 2013

 

Let's go!

Optimysstique 2013
 
Let's go!

story:
'Help an ambassador of sustainable housing build his own sustainable house!'

Chainge the Cycle is teaming up with the Earthship Biotecture crew to help build an 'Earthship' style house for Romeo and his family in Comalapa, Guatemala. 

An Earthship is an innovative yet simple 'off the grid' home that works with nature to provide an exceptionally ideal living environment.  The most beautiful aspect of this home is that it is largely composed of recycled materials such as cans, bottles, tires and other such useful garbage. 

 

We are asking for support to help install a simple, yet ingenious water management system that will capture, store and reuse rain water a total of 6 times!

This not just the chance to build a home for an amazing man and his family but also an outstanding educational opportunity.  A chance to allow the people of Comalapa, Guatemala to experience the magic of Earthships on their own terms.


Who is Romeo?

Romeo is a former corn farmer in Comalapa, Guatemala, a community where 67% of the population lives of less than $2 a day.  Romeo has continually shown his commitment to sustainable construction with the Long Way Home Project becoming the build team foreman for their school construction project in 2009.  Although Romeo has always been an active ambassador for sustainable housing in his community, he sadly cannot afford such a house of his own.  It is for him and his family that we will be building this home.

 

Who are we?

Mykal and Nico started the project Chainge the Cycle with the aim of exploring the Americas on a self-made Bamboo Bicycle visiting, promoting, documenting and sharing as many sustainable alternatives to our energy-rich lifestyle as they can visit.  They are currently at the centre of Earthship technology in Taos, New Mexico where they have joined up with two other Earthship enthusiasts Justin and Katy for this project in Guatemala.  


You can follow our trip and learn as we learn via www.chaingethecycle.org


What is an Earthship?

An Earthship is a radically sustainable building design where homes are largely constructed using the byproducts of modern society, such as cans, bottles and tires.

Earthships will also:
• Heat and cool themselves naturally
• Collect their own power from sun and wind
• Harvest their own water from rain
• Contain and treat their own sewage
• Produce a significant amount of food indoors and out

Please feel free to explore more at www.earthship.com

 

What type of Earthship will be built in Guatemala?

The type of earthship we will be building for Romeo and his family will be the 3u Simple Survival Model.  This encompasses adapted versions of all the traditional Earthship systems including a stylised bucket shower, an 'outlaw' septic using an ingeniously simple filtering system based upon tires, grey and black water systems encompassed in tandem with internal and external flora development (gardens), a solar electric system and a passive heating and cooling system


What We Need

We estimate the entire house building project to cost around $55 000  All we are asking for in this campaign is the cost of the water management system, which we estimate to be around $4000.  However, please feel free to donate above and beyond that goal as all obtained funds will be used to fund the building of the rest of the house.  An estimated break up of the costs are as follow:

Anticipated Costs:

Sediment Filters                 $100

OGWM Pipes and fitting           $150

2 x 1,700 gallon tank                   $2,200

Tank fittings and pipe                       $150

Cement for planters                               $200

Roofing materials                                      $1200

Estimated Total Material Costs:           $4,000

The installation of the water management system and the built of the earthship will be done entirely by people working on a voluntary base, so there are no costs involved related to salaries being paid for this project .

 
 


If we don't manage to raise the full 4.000 dollars..  Then what?

We Cry. .  . .

More seriously, with $3.000 we won't be able to put the full water management project in practice, but all 4 of us can still contribute to the Earthship being built in Guatemala.
With less than $3.000 it will be less people that are able to travel down to Guatemala, but 2 or 3 can still contribute to the Earthship being built in Guatemala.
With less than $1.500 we won't be able to contribute to the building in Guatemala at all, but we will donate our knowledge and the money raised to Earthship Biotecture for the earthship built in Guatemala. 

The Impact of this project

This is an educational project for local Guatemalan people and all the international volunteers involved!  Chainge the Cycle aims to expand the education by documenting the process in pictures and share knowledge globally through their website www.chaingethecycle.org

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can't donate money at all?
No worries, even if you cannot donate money to this project, don't think there is nothing you can do!
You can help us tremendously by spreading the word about this project and fundraising campaign in your network!  Share your views through Facebook and e-mail

Roofing materials                                      $1200

The installation of the water management system and the built of the earthship will be done entirely by people working on a voluntary base, so there are no costs involved related to salaries being paid for this project .
 

 

If we don't manage to raise the full 4.000 dollars..  Then what?

We Cry. .  . .
More seriously, with $3.000 we won't be able to put the full water management project in practice, but all 4 of us can still contribute to the Earthship being built in Guatemala.With less than $3.000 it will be less people that are able to travel down to Guatemala, but 2 or 3 can still contribute to the Earthship being built in Guatemala.With less than $1.500 we won't be able to contribute to the building in Guatemala at all, but we will donate our knowledge and the money raised to Earthship Biotecture for the earthship built in Guatemala. 



The Impact of this project
This is an educational project for local Guatemalan people and all the international volunteers involved!  Chainge the Cycle aims to expand the education by documenting the process in pictures and share knowledge globally through their website www.chaingethecycle.org


 
Other Ways You Can Help
You can't donate money at all?No worries, even if you cannot donate money to this project, don't think there is nothing you can do! You can help us tremendously by spreading the word about this project and fundraising campaign in your network!  Share your views through Facebook and e-mail

story:
Short Summary

Pragya Seeds International is a international organization composed by Western and Nepali professionals who want to work towards reconciliation between social, material and environmental prosperity in the world. To reach that objective, we are promoting the use of sustainable and efficient technological and business practices that can improve people comfort, their economy and environment.

This work is important for us in a time of confusion between comfort and consumption, which leads our economy to go against our well-being and our environment. PGSI want to show how we can stop accepting a trade off between economical progress and socio-environmental sustainability.

Starting with Kathmandu, PGSI will create community managed decentralized low costs Resource Recovery centers that will transform wastes into valuable resources. As a first project, PGSI has realized a partnership with local garbage collectors, women groups and a farmer cooperative active in Microfinance in order to create a first center, which will transform organic wastes into compost, and biogas that will be used for farming activities.

To reach that objective, we need to work on both infrastructure and community awareness. Although building the compost and biogas production unit is essential, work needs to be done to convince local households already using garbage collectors service to start segregation at home.

After 1 year of preparation on the field, PGSI is convinced that with your help as a funder, it will succeed in creating an example of efficient waste to resource project that will then be replicated in other places of Nepal and other countries afterwards.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Although we are very exited about our project, we must go step by step to ensure final success and proper use of our funders’ money. For the 6 first months, PGSI will invest in the compost production, the training of garbage collectors, women groups operating the plant and promoting at source segregation to garbage collectors clients.

Afterwards, PGSI will invest in a Biogas production unit that will be used to produce heat and electricity.

For the first phase, PGSI is targeting 10000 USD that will be used as follows within 6 months:

 

-       Compost production units for 1 ton per day capacity: 5000 USD

-       Training of garbage collectors and local communities: 1500 USD

-       Office costs for Pragya Seeds Nepal staff working on the project: 1500 USD

-       Monitoring cost (travel, accommodation, reporting expenses): 2000 USD

If we cannot collect the entire amount, PGSI will invest in priority in the two first sections keeping an appropriate proportion.

To those who will support the project:

5 $ or more – You will receive a report on the project progress every 6 months

50$ or more – You will receive e-pictures of the project with your name as a sponsor

100$ or more – You will receive a present made in Nepal at your home

250$ or more – You or one of your relative will be allowed to take part to our volunteering program without any administrative costs

 

The Impact

This project has been designed carefully while learning from similar successful and unsuccessful ones.

Three ingredient to success are gathered here:

  1. Involvement of local communities that includes local inhabitant, private sectors, local government and farmers.
  2. Use of low cost technologies easy to maintain for local communities
  3. Generation of income for sustainable activities: the compost and biogas are sold to local farmers at a competitive price, which help them to improve their production of vegetables.

Local actors are convinced by this approach and are only waiting to see how good it will work.

All the partnerships are ready and now the only thing to add is the initial funding that will make this project real!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come on our local parner facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/PragyaSeedsNepal); like it and share it with your relatives. Send us your ideas and comments regarding our projects and do not forget to ask everyone around you interested in improving our environment to take part to this campaign and become a funder!

story:
Short Summary

We are the UNC-Chapel Hill Sierra Student Coalition, an organization working to protect the environment. Currently we are working on a new Campuses Beyond Coal campaign with the goal of getting UNC to divest its endowment from the coal industry and make positive sustainability investments in responsible, renewable energy. Coal is a leading cause of public health issues and climate change, two things our university is working to combat.  Why are we continuing to invest in something that it undermining our efforts? Last year 77% of UNC students supported our campaign and voted in favor divesting from coal. Together seek to make UNC a leader in the environmental movement, making our planet healthier.

The UNC-Chapel Hill Sierra Student Coalition is requesting funding to allow 9 members to attend the biennial PowerShift environmental conference in Pittsburgh, PA from October 18th-21st. PowerShift is a convergence of over 10,000 youth leaders in the environmental movement from across the country and features a full schedule of workshops, film screenings, speakers, presentations, break out groups, regional convergences and networking opportunities. Since UNC Chapel Hill Sierra Student coalition is currently working on a divestment campaign with a national scope (308 other colleges are running this campaign), PowerShift represents a one time opportunity to network, share stories and swap ideas and strategies with thousands of other students running similar campaigns (especially other North Carolina students). We hope that the knowledge and connections we gain at PowerShift will significantly leverage our efforts back at UNC, leading to the benefit of the university of a whole as we move towards more sustainable investments. 

UNC CH's Beyond Coal campaign is fighting to solve the climate crisis and build a clean, just and thriving economy by standing up on our campuses and in our communities to demand real solutions that work for everyone. We have put our fists in the air and our bodies on the line to stop our university from investing in a industry that is threatening the health of our planet with its emissions.  

Which is why this fall, we want to be where 10,000+ youth leaders will converge in Pittsburgh, PA to fight for our future.

Together we’ll build the movement to fight fracking, divest from fossil fuels, build a clean energy future, and stop the climate crisis.


What We Need & What You Get

In order for us to achieve all of this, we need $1,000 of funding from you!  Below are our FULL costs

Costs
Item Total Per Person
Registration $585.00 $65.00
Housing $405.00 $45.00
Travel $260.67 $28.96
Food $810.00 $90.00
Total $2,060.67 $228.96
Since we have already been proactive, we have about $1,000 secured, which means that we still need approximately $1,000.  This will guarantee that all nine students can attend the conference and be inspired to fight for a sustainable future. 

And there's perks! 

If you donate:

 $10 - We will send you a hand-written thank you card 

$25 - Hand-written thank you card + Beyond Coal Button

$50 - Thank you card + Button + Beyond Coal T-shirt

$100 - EVERYTHING + We announce your name/contribution at our next event in November!

The Impact

We want to go to Powershift 2013 in Pittsburgh on Oct 18th because more than ten thousand youth leaders from every walk of life — college students, young environmental justice leaders, DREAMers, young people of faith, young workers — will be there to learn from one another, and to build and launch strategic campaigns in their own communities.

And Power Shift 2013 is just the beginning.

Power Shift 2013 will launch hundreds of sustained campaigns and mass actions to demand climate justice. Together with universities across the country we will unite in a drumbeat calling for change that will not be ignored.

Your contribution will assure that UNC-CH will not miss out on this call to action, and that change will be felt in North Carolina as well!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, please help us by checking out and sharing our social media platforms.

UNC-CH Sierra Student Coalition:

  The Sierra Student Coalition (SSC) is a broad network of high school and college-aged youth from across the country working to protect the environment. The SSC is the youth-led chapter of the Sierra Club, the nation's oldest and largest grassroots environmental organization. Our mission is simple: "to train, empower, and organize youth to run effective campaigns that result in tangible environmental victories and that develop leaders for the environmental movement.

Check out our facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/sscunc

Follow @sscunc for updates on Twitter

Read our blog at http://coalfreeunc.wordpress.com/

Want to learn more about the national campaign for university endowments to divest from coal? Check outwww.wearepowershift.org/campaigns/divestcoal 


Powershift:

To learn more about the conference we want to attend, go here: 

http://www.wearepowershift.org/conference/powershift2013


Don't forget to share this fund-raising campaign with your friends!

story:
PROJECT CLEAN-UP CENTRALIA, PA

Overview:
Centralia Pennsylvania needs a lot of help. It's borough is nothing more than a vast wasteland of empty streets and now sadly, a lot of trash. Hidden away off of the vacant streets, Centralia is nothing more than a dumping ground. But, with the help and support of EPCAMR (Eastern PA Coalition for Abandon Mine Reclamation), PEC NE Office, Bridgestone Tires, The Commonwealth of PA and a few other supporters, we're going out to clean up and dispose all of the trash and waste that strews along the town. But we still need more help! With this funding through Indiegogo, more donations will go to the volunteers for food and water during the clean-up throughout the day plus will offset the costs for dumpsters, shovels, and rakes.
Your donation will provide these essential items for the clean-up process. The funds go directly to EPCAMR and a receipt can be provided from EPCAMR for your donation. You can donate funds, supplies, or your time, or all three!! We need extra shovels, rakes, trash bags and volunteers for the clean-up crew and food or water will be accepted as well!
After filming a short documentary on Centralia and now in the process of making the feature length documentary on the history of the town, my crew and I shot all through the town and realized just how much garbage there is in the pockets of the town hidden away. As a result, I decided to contact Robert Hughes of EPCAMR and together we're contributing our time and gathering funding and donations towards a great cause with the help of other donations as well from The Commonwealth, ARIPPA, Bridgestone Tires, and the DEP. 
This is an environmental cause to not only keep Centralia clean and beautiful, but PA beautiful as well. Today, the town now consists of three families from a town that was wiped out from hundreds of residents due to a disaster underground fifty years ago and government neglect. On October 25th we will make a difference and clean-up Centralia, PA. So please help out with a donation or join us in the effort! 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!
Please visit www.EPCAMR.org

story:
Don't Panic. Stick With Organic. 
We have a Right to Know if it's GMO.

The 3rd March Against Monsanto rally and protest takes place on Saturday, May 24, 2014 at Westlake Park. We rally at 11 AM and march to The Gates Foundation for protest at 2 PM. This is a Family-Friendly event! 

  • We are the same dedicated group of activists that brought you the first two #MAM events, including MAM 2.0 last October for World Food Day. Despite election results last November, and the dirty dealings of the GMA (Grocery Manufacturer's Association), we are calling for a new GMO Labeling Initiative in Washington State.
     
  • Your contributions are greatly needed to help us cover the expenses of producing this rally and march (permits, tents, tables, sound equipment, and so much more). We're creating literature to help inform Seattle citizens of the need for Label Laws on ALL GMO foods, and to help us begin to build a coalition of like-minded organizations & people. 

  • YOU can help us provide a family-friendly event that will bring our community together to speak out about the dangers of GMO Foods, demand labeling, and to ask our City to ban the use of "neonics" on all city property. This is one of the pesticides responsible for harming bees and other important pollinators! Our parks should be toxin-free!

  • Any surplus funds, after costs to cover the event, will be routed directly back to the parent NGO (March-Against-Monsanto.com) as well as used to help start a #MAMSeattle 501(c) non-profit organization, made up of coalition members, that will be used for on-going education projects and  to continue providing Seattle with a march every May and October! 

    Watch an inspiring CALL TO ACTION video here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tDjnPetPuxs

    Visit our COMMUNITY SUPPORT PAGE on Facebook:
    https://www.facebook.com/MAMSeattle (Please "like" and share!)

                                              

What You Get (And What We Need):

  • A Rally and March on 05/24/2014 at Westlake Park!  
    (event info:  https://www.facebook.com/events/244608745689264/ )

  • Special guests, speakers, and demos from groups like Seattle Tilth, Seattle Farm Co-op, Beacon Edible Food Forest, CAGJ, CISPES, Fair Trade Coalition, Educating the Gates Foundation, and more.

  • Musical performances from local artists such as Smashie Smashie, Sean Gaston, Hip Hop Occupies, Gary Kanter, and the Raging Grannies.

  • Activities for the kiddos, including face-painting & chalk art. We'll also be offering buttons, seed bags, seed balls, patches, and other fun goodies to help you start your own garden and to show your #MAM Solidarity! (*small cash donations appreciated and go directly to cover costs of sound tech)
  • Funds are needed to cover the many cost of permits, staging, sound equipment, megaphones, banners, light actions, info flyers, supplies for kids' activities, street medics, water, security, educational materials, and much, much more.

    **Sadly, the Seattle Community Media Lab closed several months ago. Without their resources & support, we are having to rent tents and tables and things that were provided for free last fall.**

  • What do you get (besides a fun event and a chance to march)? 
    The satisfaction of knowing you are helping to spread the word about the need for GMO Safety Standards, and the need for Food Labels in the United States, starting with WA state! We'll be alerting others about the many ways Monsanto continues to exert control and undue influence over our global food system, while they patent seeds then turn around and sue family farmers who find unexpected GMOs have cross-pollinated into their own crops. We'll shout it to the Gates Foundation: They need to sever ties with Monsanto and think about the impact their policy-making has on our city and our children! It's time to stop worshiping profit over the health and safety of the people! No one should be able to patent what we can eat! We have a RIGHT TO KNOW what we are buying/growing/cooking/eating, so we'll be calling on elected officials to support a new initiative to LABEL IT!
  • Reminder: Any surplus funds after event costs will go directly back to March-Against-Monsanto.com and towards the formation of our own #MAMSeattle non-profit organization! Detailed financial records available upon request.

The Impact:

  • One corporation should NOT own patents on food technology, including the actual seeds!
  •  They should not be able to sue farmers who do not use their seed for accidental crop contamination.
  • We should all have the right to choose what we eat. GMO Labels should be mandatory in every state, including Washington.
  • This rally will help garner more support for a NEW Initiative, which would seek to secure GMO labeling laws for the state, and help us combat the mis-information campaigns of giant lobby groups like the GMA!
  • Monsanto is a multinational corporation (like Syngenta, and others) that seeks to disenfranchise local & global farmers, by selling patented toxic seeds at lower costs, which in turn, can put Organic Farmers out of business!
  • We now know that harmful chemicals like Neonicotinoids are responsible for killing off pollinating insects, including bees. We demand that the City of Seattle formulates a Green Plan for all public parks & properties, and bans the use of these poisons in those spaces.
  • We all have a right to access healthy food, and we need to end neighborhood "food deserts". We have a right to know our food is GMO-free! 


Other Ways You Can Help:

If you cannot contribute, don't despair. There are other ways you can help!

  • Ask your friends and family to make some noise about this campaign!
  • Email it to folks that might be able to help with a small donation. Or share it via Facebook and Twitter!
  • Contact the event coordinators to volunteer. We need extra people to help with work parties before May 24th and people to help set-up and break down equipment the event that day.
  • Please go to our Facebook Event Page and join the Rally and March on Saturday, May 24th at 11 AM.  Be sure to share & invite all of your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers! Share the link to the Community page and check out our posts.
  •  Sharing is Caring!

It's time to stop worshiping profit over the health and safety of the people! No one should be able to patent what we can eat! We have a RIGHT TO KNOW what we are buying/growing/cooking/eating, so we'll be calling on elected officials to support a new initiative to LABEL IT!

Reminder: Any surplus funds after event costs will go directly back to March-Against-Monsanto.com and towards the formation of our own #MAMSeattle non-profit organization! Detailed financial records available upon request.The Impact:
One corporation should NOT own patents on food technology, including the actual seeds!

 They should not be able to sue farmers who do not use their seed for accidental crop contamination.

We should all have the right to choose what we eat. GMO Labels should be mandatory in every state, including Washington.
This rally will help garner more support for a NEW Initiative, which would seek to secure GMO labeling laws for the state, and help us combat the mis-information campaigns of giant lobby groups like the GMA!
Monsanto is a multinational corporation (like Syngenta, and others) that seeks to disenfranchise local & global farmers, by selling patented toxic seeds at lower costs, which in turn, can put Organic Farmers out of business!
We now know that harmful chemicals like Neonicotinoids are responsible for killing off pollinating insects, including bees. We demand that the City of Seattle formulates a Green Plan for all public parks & properties, and bans the use of these poisons in those spaces.
We all have a right to access healthy food, and we need to end neighborhood "food deserts". We have a right to know our food is GMO-free! 


Other Ways You Can Help:If you cannot contribute, don't despair. There are other ways you can help!
Ask your friends and family to make some noise about this campaign!
Email it to folks that might be able to help with a small donation. Or share it via Facebook and Twitter!
Contact the event coordinators to volunteer. We need extra people to help with work parties before May 24th and people to help set-up and break down equipment the event that day.
Please go to our Facebook Event Page and join the Rally and March on Saturday, May 24th at 11 AM.  Be sure to share & invite all of your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers! Share the link to the Community page and check out our posts.
 Sharing is Caring!

story:
I am Jerry Becker, Executive Director of Wild Rivers Land Trust (WRLT). Our small nonprofit organization buys and protects land that is vitally important for the fragile ecosystems that our forests, wildlife, and people depend on.

There’s a Project We Need Help With —We recently purchased this 217-acre forest from a timber company because I believe it’s crucial to protect its erosion-prone headwaters, especially for endangered birds and fish who live there. The place is now called Bear Creek Natural Area. (BCNA) The property has 11⁄2 miles of sparkling, clear mountain streams where wild salmon leap and 200’ tall trees where endangered seabirds nest. 

Help Pay For This Natural Area —If the Land Trust is not able to pay off the loan that we took out to save this exceptional place, the bank will seize the land and develop it, destroying the promise and the vision of a forever-wild
Bear Creek Natural Area.

A Big Impact —Together we can assure sparkling clear mountain streams and convey a priceless legacy to future generations of all species!

Permanently protecting BCNA magnifies other nearby conservation successes. The entire area is key to protecting water quality for the unspoiled Wild and Scenic Elk River and her world-renown salmon runs.

Donate Generously to Safeguard Bear Creek Natural Area — Please!

All donations are tax deductible and all money you send goes directly to pay off the bank loan.

Our 501(c)3 nonprofit organization’s work started 14 years ago when we purchased and forever-protected 163 riverfront acres at risk of being clearcut and sprayed with herbicides. Since that triumph our service area has grown to include the wild and sensitive watersheds of the entire south coast of Oregon. We now have an office, a small staff and several volunteers working to protect the breathtaking scenery, the remarkable water quality and the important fish and wildlife habitat on Oregon’s Wild Rivers Coast.

Please Help Protect the Bear Creek Natural Area in Perpetuity!

Together we can assure sparkling clear mountain streams and convey a priceless legacy to future generations of all species. 

Wild Rivers Land Trust 2014 Land Acquisition Budget

Bear Creek Natural Area

Loan amount: $264,000

Annual interest: $10,000

Restoration budget: $22,000

Total amount needed: $296,000

For More Info —Visit our website for more information and to find out other ways you can help us Protect the Working Lands and Natural Treasures of Oregon’s Wild Rivers Coast.

I genuinely appreciate your interest in saving our wild watersheds.

Please use Indiegogo’s share tools to get the word out, and make noise about our campaign. Thanks so much for your help! 

Jerry

Wild Rivers Land Trust, PO Box 1158, Port Orford, OR 97465

www.wildriverslandtrust.org

story:
An english description follows beneath

Collecte de fonds pour la Ferme Morgan

Nous sommes extrêmement heureux d’annoncer que nous construirons une serre solaire passive quatre saisons au printemps 2014 à la Ferme Morgan. Cette nouvelle construction remplacera la serre actuelle de la ferme (voir la vidéo). La nouvelle serre s’inspire des principes des Earthships et de différents bâtiments construits au Québec durant l’été 2013 à partir des concepts de Christian Desilet et de Francis Gendron de SolutionEra.

L’équipe

Jean-Nick, Félicia et moi-même (Jesse Richman) sommes très reconnaissants d’avoir l’occasion de travailler avec la coopérative de la Ferme Morgan (CoopéraVie Morgan) pour construire une serre durable à partir de matériaux recyclés. Nous accueillerons des bénévoles désireux d’en apprendre davantage sur les bâtiments de style Earthship et sur le fonctionnement d’une coopérative bio.

Jean-Nick, Félicia et moi avons tous trois suivi la formation de l’Académie Earthship (Earthship Biotecture Academy) au Nouveau-Mexique, et nous voulons maintenant appliquer ce que nous avons appris et contribuer à l’évolution du secteur du bâtiment durable au Québec et ailleurs dans le monde. Nous n’aurions pas pu imaginer un meilleur scénario : l’occasion de réaliser un projet de serre avec une coopérative axée sur l’engagement communautaire, la durabilité et les pratiques agricoles sécuritaires. 

Jean-Nick et moi au Nouveau-Mexique

Un retour aux sources

Pour moi, ce projet est doublement stimulant. D’abord parce qu’il nous donne l’occasion de travailler avec une coopérative dynamique, mais également parce qu’il s’agit d’un retour aux sources. En effet, j’ai grandi sur cette ferme, et je suis heureux de découvrir la communauté qui s’est créée ici et qui continue d’évoluer au fil des saisons. Pour moi, le fait de découvrir les mécanismes d’une coopérative et de contribuer à son objectif d’autosuffisance toute l’année s’aligne parfaitement avec les valeurs que j’espère explorer plus en profondeur. Ça semble évident. Il s’agit d’une occasion d’établir des liens avec un réseau grandissant de personnes qui cherchent des façons de s’entraider dans leur découverte d’un mode de vie durable et différent.

Dessiné à l’échelle par Félicia Monette

Un autre pas

Fort du succès de ma dernière expérience de financement participatif, je m’apprête maintenant à lancer une deuxième campagne. Nous ferons ainsi appel à toutes les personnes qui sont disposées à donner un appui financier à un groupe de gens motivés et inspirés afin de les aider à réaliser leur rêve : appliquer des solutions pratiques à des problèmes environnementaux et sociaux. Voilà ce qui me motive, et je sais que nous sommes nombreux à partager ce rêve, y compris à la Ferme Morgan.

Les voix de la coop

La CoopéraVie Morgan est heureuse de collaborer avec Jesse Richman et son équipe et d’ainsi profiter des fruits de leurs actions. Nous avons plusieurs valeurs en commun, par exemple un désir d’autosuffisance alimentaire toute l’année. Cette serre permettra à notre coopérative de produire des aliments 12 mois par année et d’appliquer progressivement nos principes fondamentaux entourant l’engagement communautaire, la durabilité et l’utilisation de pratiques agricoles sécuritaires. 

Des membres et amis de la coop durant une pause-dîner

Où va l’argent?

L’argent donné au projet servira à l’achat de matériaux et d’outils que nous ne pourrons pas obtenir par recyclage. Par exemple, le matériau qui couvrira le toit orienté vers le sud. Nous utiliserons de l’ETFE, un matériau idéal pour ce genre de bâtiment, puisqu’il est isolant et résistant et qu’il transmet un spectre de lumière plus large, ce qui favorisera la croissance des plantes.

Nous sommes sûrs que votre soutien dans le cadre de cette campagne nous permettra de couvrir toutes les dépenses matérielles du projet. De plus, nous accueillerons les groupes et les individus disposés à offrir leur temps.

Qu’est-ce qu’un earthship?

Earthship, modèle global

Le concept de Earthship a évolué en réponse à l’incapacité de nos économies à répondre à nos besoins de base, c’est-à-dire l’accès à de l’eau potable propre, à une alimentation saine et à des abris dynamiques et respectueux de l’environnement. Essentiellement, les earthships recueillent l’eau de pluie, produisent leur propre électricité et utilisent les rayons du soleil pour chauffer l’intérieur de façon passive et pour faire pousser de la nourriture.

De plus, les earthships utilisent des matériaux recyclés (comme des pneus) qui s’accumulent partout dans le monde. Earthship Biotecture a été créé il y a 40 ans par Mike Reynolds, un architecte avec une vision originale. Selon lui, notre économie est un obstacle qui nous empêche de subvenir à nos besoins de base. Notre société produit des ordures qui polluent la planète. Les earthships recyclent ces matériaux afin de transcender l’économie et d’accéder à la liberté qui accompagne une vie en harmonie avec les éléments de la nature. Simple, n’est-ce pas?

Les six principes des earthships

Collecte de l’eau de pluie

Chauffage et refroidissement solaire thermique

Utilisation de matériaux naturels et recyclés

Électricité solaire/éolienne

Traitement des eaux usées

Production d’aliments

Ce projet sera axé avant tout sur le volet production alimentaire. Puisqu’il s’agit d’une serre, nous mettrons de côté la dimension traitement des eaux usées, mais nous conserverons les cinq autres principes.

Les ingrédients d’une vie simple et pleine sont à notre portée. Voyons maintenant ce que nous pouvons en faire...


Photo prise par Leslie Carbonneau. Serre solaire passive à Bromont, au Québec

Une autre façon d’aider?

Partagez cette campagne avec toutes vos connaissances, quelles que soient leurs opinions!

Et n’oubliez pas de nous aider à atteindre nos objectifs financiers en faisant un don.

De plus, si vous souhaitez donner votre temps, contactez-nous directement (unpneualafois@gmail.com). Venez nous donner un coup de main sur le site! Vous apprendrez à construire une serre solaire passive quatre saisons. Les bénévoles seront logés et nourris, et les repas seront préparés avec les aliments de la ferme.

Merci pour votre temps et votre considération!

Au plaisir de vous voir à la ferme!

...................................................................................

Fundraising for Morgan Farms

We are extremely happy to be announcing the construction of a 4 season solar passive greenhouse in the spring of 2014 at Morgan Farms, which will be replacing an existing greenhouse (as seen in video). This design is inspired from Earthship principles and is based on several buildings that have been put up throughout Quebec in the summer of 2013 designed by Christian Desilet and Francis Gendron from SolutionEra.

The Team

Jean-Nick, Félicia and I (Jesse Richman) are extremely lucky to have the opportunity to work with Morgan Farms cooperative (CoopéraVie Morgan) in building a self-sustainable greenhouse out of recycled materials. Together we will be welcoming volunteers whose desire is to learn about earthship inspired buildings as well as the workings of an organic cooperative. 

After having followed the Earthship Biotecture Academy, Jean-Nick, Félicia and I where excited by the opportunity to put into application what we had learned and contribute to the evolution of self-sustainable buildings in Quebec and around the world. We couldn’t have dreamed of a better scenario, realizing this project with a cooperative committed to community involvement, sustainability and safe agricultural practices. 

Jean-Nick and I in New Mexico

Back to the roots

I am excited not only to work with the cooperative but also to come back to my roots. I grew up on this farm and am happy to be discovering the community that has flourished here and that continues to evolve with each changing season. Discovering the workings of a cooperative and contributing to their goal of sustaining themselves year round is perfectly in line with values that I hope to explore more deeply. Seems obvious. This is an opportunity to connect with a growing number of people who are looking to support each other in their discovery of a sustainable, alternative lifestyle.


hand drawn to proportion by Félicia Monette


Another step

Because of the success of my previous crowdfunding experience I feel comfortable and confident in launching a second campaign, reaching out to people ready to support financially a group of motivated, inspiring people in our dream of applying logical solutions to environmental and social issues. This is what I strive for, my motivation, a common dream I believe is shared by many others including the folks at Morgan Farms.

Voices from the coop

The CoopéraVie Morgan is in gratitude to be cooperating with Jesse Richman and his team to take advantage of the fruits of their actions. We share deeply certain values that we take at heart like growing our food year round. This greenhouse will allow our cooperative to produce food year round and start sprouting for the spring as well as progressively embracing our fundamental principles that touch on community involvement, sustainability and safe agricultural practices.


coop members and friends on lunch break

Where do the pennies go?

The money donated to the project will be essential for the purchase of materials and tools that we will be unable to recycle such as the south facing roof slope. This slope will be covered with ETFE an ideal material for this type of building as it is an insulative, resistant material that transmits a wider spectrum of light to allow the plants to fully thrive.

We feel confident that through this campaign and your support we will be able to cover all material expenses and welcome groups of volunteers motivated to offer their time.

What is an earthship?

global model Earthship

It is a concept that has evolved in response to the way our economy fails to address our basic needs? If in a day one can have access to clean drinking water, good food and a shelter that is dynamic and sensitive in respect to it’s environment and our fundamental needs, then you begin to have your answer. Harvesting water from the sky, using the rays of the sun to passively heat your house and grow your food and produce your own electricity.  

 On top of this you have built your house out of societies leftovers, recycling materials (such as tires) that have until now been accumulating with no further purpose all around the world. Mike Reynolds who started approaching architecture from another angle forty years ago and founded Earthship Biotecture has an interesting way of putting things. Our economy stands between us and our basic needs. Our society creates garbage that trashes the world and so, we use garbage to transcend the economy and access the freedom to finally have a life that can be in harmony with nature’s elements.

Simple, right?

There are six principles

Water harvest

Thermal solar heating and cooling

Building with natural and recycled materials

Solar/wind power

On site sewage treatment

Food production

We are looking to optimize the food production aspect of this concept. As it is a greenhouse we will be setting aside the onsite sewage treatment aspect of the building while respecting the five other principles.

The potential for the foundation of living simply and fully is at our fingertips. Lets see where this potential takes us…..


Photo by Leslie Carbonneau. Solar passive greenhouse in Bromont,Qc

Another way of helping?

You can share this campaign with those who might think likewise or otherwise.

 And!

Help us achieve our financial goal and donate.

And!

Donate your time, contact us directly (unpneualafois@gmail.com) and give us a hand on site and learn how a 4 season solar passive greenhouse is built. Volunteers will be lodged and fed with food from the farm.

For reading this far we thank you for your time and consideration.

See you at the farm!

 On top of this you
have built your house out of societies leftovers, recycling materials (such as
tires) that have until now been accumulating with no further purpose all around
the world. Mike Reynolds who started approaching architecture from another
angle forty years ago and founded Earthship
Biotecture has an interesting way of putting things. Our economy stands
between us and our basic needs. Our society creates garbage that trashes the
world and so, we use garbage to transcend the economy and access the freedom to
finally have a life that can be in harmony with nature’s elements. 
Simple, right?
There are six principles
Water harvestThermal solar heating and cooling
Building with natural and recycled materials
Solar/wind power
On site sewage treatment
Food production
We are looking to optimize the food production aspect of
this concept. As it is a greenhouse we will be setting aside the onsite sewage
treatment aspect of the building while respecting the five other principles.
The potential for the foundation of living simply and fully
is at our fingertips. Lets see where this potential takes us….. 

Photo by Leslie Carbonneau. Solar passive greenhouse in Bromont,QcAnother way of
helping?
You can share this campaign with those who might think likewise
or otherwise.
 And!
Help us achieve our financial goal and donate.
And!
Donate your time, contact us directly (unpneualafois@gmail.com) and give us a hand on
site and learn how a 4 season solar passive greenhouse is built. Volunteers
will be lodged and fed with food from the farm. 
For reading this far we thank you for your time and
consideration.
See you at the farm!

story: Green Energy, LLC, is a renewable energy startup based in Laramie, WY that focuses on electricity producing consumer devices. We are currently developing a multi-stage process that will produce electricity while removing carbon from the atmosphere by using photosynthesis and cutting-edge biotechnologies. We intend to integrate this process into a single, marketable, and affordable consumer product, enabling individuals to produce environmentally friendly electricity in their own homes.

We are currently developing a multi-stage process that will produce electricity while removing carbon from the atmosphere by using photosynthesis and cutting-edge biotechnologies. We intend to integrate this process into a single, marketable, and affordable consumer product, enabling individuals to produce environmentally friendly electricity in their own homes.

story:
Short Summary

Foundation Climate Fund Bulgaria is a small foundation run by three passionate environmentalists in parallel with their full-time jobs in energy, environment and climate change: Lucy Naydenova, Hristo Panchev and Asen Nenov from Sofia. Its objective is to make a difference for climate change, bidiversity and the environment through action. Bulgaria is one of the few countries left in Europe with rich biodiversity and large forest cover. However, in the past decades, due to weak implementation of legislation and scaled-up commercial logging, native forests protecting the climate and giving home to unique plants and animals are dissapearing at a rapid rate. 

With your support, we would like to make a statement that this cannot continue and contribute to forests and biodiversity preservation. The Foundation intends to buy for the lowest price as much as possible forest areas and waste land for afforestation with endemic trees that are either protected by law or threatened. These forestst will be  converted to natural reserves that will be managed sustainably and will stay forever. 

The purchase is expected to happen before July 2017. Contributers who wish so, will be informed on the progress and can receive a symbolic present. For this purpose, please send a confirmaiton e-mail to info@climatefund.bg

If you are not in the position to contribute, but like the cause and want to help, please share the link to this campain with others.

story:
For the Love of Bert and Nature 

"Far Afield" is a documentary about a conservation icon, but it's also a love story involving two people, a place and an environment that inspires us all. Bert Raynes is a man everyone should have the joy of knowing. With a keen intellect, sharp wit and twinkle in his eye, this 91-year-old continues to inspire the people of Jackson Hole, Wyoming to observe and care about their wild neighbors. Young, old and in-between flock to him to discover how to be better stewards of the natural world.

The goal of this film is to introduce the world to Bert and his vision for how Citizen Scientists can play a meaningful role, working in tandem with experts, in caring for the wild places we love.

"I don't think you can know too much about the environment. As my wife Meg used to say, 'I like the environment. I live in it.'"   - Bert

PERKS

We have great perks ranging from Bert’s books to a pre-screening dinner at the director’s house. Perk packages have bird names, so whether you're a yellow-rumped warbler or Clark’s nutcracker, we want to hear your song.  We also have some great “add-on” perks, including DVDs of the finished film and Bert T-shirts.

Become a Friend of Bert (FOB)

By helping us make "Far Afield," you'll be spreading Bert's message that we can band together to make a difference for wildlife and wild places. We hope this film will inspire other communities to find and celebrate the "Berts" in their backyards, linking multiple generations of conservationists!

Get Us to the Finish Line

We have worked hard to gather early support for this project and are immensely grateful to our initial donors, who have contributed funds for pre-production and production. Our first grant monies came from 1% for the Tetons.

                                                           

Other early supporters include numerous individuals (FOBs) and non-profits, such as the Community Foundation of Jackson Hole, The Nature Conservancy of Wyoming, National Museum of Wildlife Art, Teton Raptor Center and Center of Wonder. We are half-way through filming and have film shoots planned for spring and early summer; post-production is scheduled for mid to late summer.  Funds raised through our Indiegogo campaign will go toward post-production expenses including editing, music and graphics. Indiegogo allows us to go far afield – beyond the small valley of Jackson Hole - to invite others to participate in “Far Afield.”  The heart of this film is Bert and his connections and commitment to community (humans and animals).  Become part of our Indiegogo campaign community – the community that will help us with the last bit of funding and allow us to share Bert's vision!

Bert's Vision of Caring for Wild Places

A distinguished naturalist, award-winning author, Jackson Hole News & Guide columnist and retired engineer, Bert inspires passion in people to protect the environment, but he's not a firebrand. He leads through humor, curiosity and compassion. Learn more about Bert, Meg and the genesis of Jackson Hole's Citizen Science program, Nature Mapping, by watching this short film, "BERT."


Our Team

The diversity of our team reflects the eclectic cast of characters that Bert attracts. Our team includes filmmakers, a journalist, an economist and a scientist, who all share a love of nature and Bert. 

JenTen Productions is making the film.  Jennifer Tennican, an award-winning documentary filmmaker, and Rebecca Huntington, a multi-media journalist, worked together on the documentary, "The Stagecoach Bar: An American Crossroads." Our team also includes filmmakers Blake Ciulla, Ella Farnsworth and Katy Bell. Jonathan Schechter is the founder and executive director of the Charture Institute. Peter Ward is a geologist and member of the Deaf as a Post lunch group, founded by Bert. 

Giving to a Sustainable Future

This film is being made under the auspices of The Charture Institute, a non-profit focused on growth, change, and sustainability in Places of Ecological and Aesthetic Significance (PEAS).  Founder and Executive Director, Jonathan Schechter is a huge fan of Bert and his worldview.

After production costs are paid, all funds donated to or generated by this project, will go to the Meg & Bert Raynes Wildlife Fund, a conservation non-profit whose mission is to:

Initiate, augment, or simply fund projects or activities to help maintain viable and sustainable wildlife populations into the future, especially in Wyoming and Jackson Hole, through support of research, education, habitat protection and habitat restoration.

Building Community

We build community with our films. We produced the “The Stagecoach Bar: An American Crossroads" for the non-profit Jackson Hole Historical Society and Museum. We made the Stagecoach film with grassroots support, with over 250 individuals, families, foundations and businesses giving anywhere from  $5 to $25,000. Distributed by American Public Television, that film was and continues to be broadcast on over 150 public television stations in over 30 states. With your help, we can build a community of nature lovers to spread Bert's inspirational message!

Risks/Challenges

We have an experienced and committed team, but creating a film is challenging, so it's fair to ask "What if you don't reach your goal?"  If we don’t reach our goal, we will put the funds raised where they are needed most in post-production and continue to recruit supporters and donors.  Quick reminder, though 1) we have a track record of successful fundraising and community engagement and 2) Jennifer Tennican, the director/producer of the film, is nicknamed “Jen Tenacious."

Other Ways to Help

We have lots of contribution levels and great perks, but maybe you just can't help us in that way.  So...

  • Help us spread the word via an email to friends - copy the campaign URL and paste it!  Let friends know it's worthwhile supporting the film.
  • Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks.
  • Use the hashtag #BertFilmJH
