story:
Short Summary

Nine Lives Mattress Recycling was started by Ralph Bogan Jr with commitment of his own funds in 2006. Our purpose is responding to the need for more space in our landfills and to recycle  the components of a mattress and box spring in order to not only save landfill space in our communities but to save our natural resources in the manufacturing process of new goods.

Nine Lives is determined to keep the fees low.  We are determined to be successful and to keep everyone motivated.  "Be Green" sounds great, but to "Be Green" should not create financial strain rather make financial sense.

We manually deconstruct mattresses and box springs and separate materials for recycling.  The units are stripped, sorted and baled and the materials are sent to respective manufactures that include cotton, foam, wood, polyester, shoddy pad and steel. 

·Metal : is recycled at our local scrap yard .

·Wood : can be shredded to provide mulch, boiler fuel, or reused in the arts and crafts field

·Poly foam and Poly-pad from mattress covers or "toppers" are used to manufacture carpet pads.

·Cotton stuffing can be used as filler for packaging, shipping pads, wall insulation, mops and rags


US Navy in Norfolk Participating in Pilot Program to Recycle Material from Ship Mattresses

Posted on November 7, 2012 

As of late October 2012, the U.S. Navy is conducting a pilot program to recycle mattresses that are no longer usable on ships.  Currently the mattresses are being sent to a South Carolina company that recycles the springs and foam.  So far, the pilot program has involved three ships, including the carrier USS Enterprise, based in Norfolk.  According to Gregory Jeanguenat, head of solid waste and recycling at the Norfolk Naval Station, the program may be expanded to other ships and to barracks and other Navy lodging around Norfolk.  Some Army and Marine bases also participate in mattress recycling.

The Navy says paying Pamplico, S.C.-based Nine Lives Mattress Recycling to take the Enterprise's mattresses off their hands is about $12,000 cheaper than paying for them to go to a local landfill.

"It had to be cheaper, even if it's greener, in order for us to want to do business," said Gregory Jeanguenat, Naval Station Norfolk's Integrated Solid Waste and Recycling Site manager

Source: Navy sending fewer ship mattresses to landfills, Associated Press, 10/26/12



What We Need & What You Get

Scope of project:
Foam Baler New                           $14,000.00
Delivery and setup                       $1200.00
Concrete and supplies                $1800.00
Rotary Phase Converter              $900.00
Electric upgrade/supplies         $1100.00
Crowd funding fees 
and anything I forgot                   $3000.00
Total needed                                 $22,000.00  

We need a new baler to create a new employment position and to capture more of the post consumer materials that we reclaim in our recycling process. We charge the lowest recycling fee in the country and in doing so this leaves little capital to buy the expensive equipment needed. We are determined not to increase the recycling fee so that the recycling option is affordable and comparable to land filling costs if not lower.

To date we have saved over 2.7 million cubic feet of landfill space. With this baler we can save even more. The magnitude of what contributors will help us achieve is the creation of much needed jobs,  additional post consumer material recycled, additional landfill space gained.



The Impact

It is estimated that 1 Billion mattresses and box springs are sold in the US each year. In the US, 33 Million mattresses are produced annually and most of these are conventional mattresses that contain man-made materials. They‘re derived from petrochemicals and from natural gas, which are nonrenewable resources.

According to an  ABC news report, about 20 million mattresses get thrown away each year in America.

See a mattress wont compact.  When a mattress goes to the landfill it doesn’t go away, it doesn’t rot away, like say food waste.  It just sits there for years!  The spring steel in the mattress is some tough stuff.  So as other waste is buried on top of a mattress, the mattress keeps coming up, rising if you will.  Also when hospitals, universities, military bases, cruise ships, college dormitories, hotels and other institutions discard their old mattresses, it is usually done all at once which causes soft spots in the landfills  Okay now picture those great big heavy duty machinery they use at the landfill,  So those trucks drive over a mattress and this spring steel gets wrapped all around the tires or the axles of the trucks, immobilizing them. 

Now they have to repair it, right.  How about that the cost to repair just one of those wheels is going to cost around $40,000!  With our services, that same $40,000 could recycle 10,000 mattresses.

The average mattress takes up 23 cubic feet of landfill space.  In 2012 Nine Lives saved approximately 920,000 cubic feet of landfill space.  Now picture 14  Boeing 747's airplanes  sitting in the landfill and they wont compact!

Risks & Challenges


We want to avoid raising the recycling fee in order to cover the costs needed to operate and provide this recycling option. 

Our challenge is to keep the recycling fee lower than the landfill cost in order to  make our recycling option more appealing and financially smarter and environmentally smarter to the customer so that the mattresses and box springs are not taken to the landfill.

story:
Help us make Giga Impacts on Climate Change

Giga Impacts Corporation is developing the Climate Change Navigator™ and will also be offering the direct sale of Renewable Energy products. Our website will bring together many disparate information sources and daily news streams on Climate Change into a framework providing actionable new knowledge on the relationship of economic activities and their impact on Climate Change.

Once our Phase I website is developed, Giga Impacts plans for immediate revenue with the sale of our energy product, Renewable Energy Credits or REC's. This is a key Climate Change mitigation step everyone can participate in, which directly supports the increased use of renewable energy.

Our target customer's range from individuals to businesses of all-sizes who are looking  to become better informed on Climate Change, through understanding their own impacts, and educating them to take action to offset their energy use with the purchase of renewable energy.

Meet the Leadership Team: Joel Schatz and Chris Rathe were co-founders of Metacode Technologies, Inc., a San Francisco enterprise software company. Where they led the development of innovative technology with million dollar sales, and led the company through a $150M merger with industry leader Interwoven, Inc.

Giga Impacts will be leveraging the experience of our leadership team and the professionals in our technology development and renewable energy sales, both focused on helping make a positive impact on Climate Change.


Introduction to Renewable Energy Credits (RECs)

The Chart below shows how RECs are created by renewable energy generators, and through REC suppliers, such as Giga Impacts, are sold to businesses and home owners with no geographic restrictions within the United States.

For every unit of green energy generated (1 MegaWatt hour or 1 MWh or 1,000 Kilowatt hours), one renewable energy certificate (REC) is produced. Your purchase of a REC is directly helping to build a market for renewable electricity.

  The renewable energy certificates (RECs) are a product from 100% domestic renewable Energy generation projects. They represent unbundled renewable energy attributes that originate from green energy production; wind, solar, biomass or small-scale hydro.

There is no need to switch electricity providers when you buy a renewable energy certificate. Your home or business continues to receive your electricity from your existing utility.

Your purchase is real. All RECs from Giga Impacts will be verified by Green-e Energy, an independent consumer protection program providing certification for renewable energy sold to households and organizations.  See Green-e.org



What We Need

$25,000 is the budget for the Giga Impacts Phase I website which will allow us to begin offering commercial sales of Renewable Energy Credits, generating revenue to support the development of our full scale website development.


What You Get

One Month of Cleaner Air for $10 We will provide you with 1 REC. Equal to one month of offsets for the average home electrical use (1,000 kilowatt hours or 1 MWh), and will support the development of Giga Impacts’ integrated and collaborative Climate Change information website.

Three Months of Cleaner Air for $30 We will provide you with 3 RECs. Equal to three months of offsets for the average home electrical use (3,000 kilowatt hours or 3 MWh), and will support the development of Giga Impacts’ integrated and collaborative Climate Change information website.

Twelve Months of Cleaner Air for $100 We will provide you with 12 RECs. Equal to one year of offsets for the average home electrical use (12,000 kilowatt hours or 12 MWh), and will support the development of Giga Impacts’ integrated and collaborative Climate Change information website.

One Big Clean Year for $250 We will provide you with 36 RECs. Equal to one year of offsets for the average large home electrical use (36,000 kilowatt hours or 36 MWh), and will support the development of Giga Impacts’ integrated and collaborative Climate Change information website.

Sustainable Business for One Year for $500 We will provide you with 90 RECs. Equal to one year of offsets for a business' electrical use (90,000 kilowatt hours or 90 MWh), and will support the development of Giga Impacts’ integrated and collaborative Climate Change information website.


The Impact

By supporting Giga Impacts development, you will immediately be part of the Climate Change solution. Your contribution will provide you with certified RECs, along with supporting the development of the much needed integrated Climate Change Navigator information technology.

The Chart below shows the positive impact the purchase of twelve RECs can have offsetting the CO2 emitted from a year of electricity use for the average home in America. You can be part of reducing 9 tons of CO2 emissions, or 928 gallons of gasoline consumed.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

If we each do a little, we all do a lot more.

Your support is not only limited to direct monetary participation. The following are other ways you can help this Climate Change information site and renewable energy credits sales become a reality. You can still help us reach out to others:

  • Share by posting to your social networks: Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest etc.
  • Use the Indiegogo.com share tools to easily reach your friends online!
  • Raise awareness through email, or your blog and/or social networks
  • Sharing offline with your friends and colleagues; talk about Giga Impacts.

Each new supporter brings us is a step closer to reaching the goal of launching a comprehensive Climate Change information site, and offering Renewable Energy Credits and other offsets from solar, wind and biomass renewable energy sources. Even better, helping us find support for this project is a noble effort towards reducing your friend's carbon footprint, and doing something today to make a positive difference on Climate Change.

Please take some action right now.

Thank you,  the Giga Impacts team & the Planet

story:
Hello, 

 

We are Rez-Cycling at the Salish Kootenai College (SKC) located in Pablo, Montana.  We created this recycling campaign to kick-start recycling for SKC tribal students. The College is only our start-up, we have plans to create change throughout the community to help better the environment. 

Recycling helps protect our resources, our environment, and our quality of life.

Short Summary

The Rez-Cycling campaign is focusing on the importance of the recycling systems on Tribal reservations. Tribal people want to do their part for the care of the environment, but it can be difficult to understand the knowledge of ‘How to recycle.'

Rez-cycling anticipates to access and expand to recycle and to enhance educational aspects to kick-start the recycling venture along with the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes and Tribal College. 

SKC has 55 student family houses and 2 separate dormitories that are in need of your contribution.

With your donation, Tribal College students will have the opportunity to begin new Eco-friendly projects that help alleviate the transition to modern waste management. 

#dontbetrashy #onerezatatime  #cyclecontinues

What We Need & What You Get

We need your donation today for recycling bins & machines for breaking down plastics. We have a time limit on our campaign, every donation helps!

Target Goal: $ 15,000

55 housing units and two (2) separate dormitories.

Goal - 80 indoor bins, 9 collection bins, 10 sorting bins, 2 recycling machines (Shredder and Compressor)  

The funding for the Rez-cycling will go towards purchasing two machines (shredder and extruder) which allows #1- #10 plastics to be shredded and composed into a thread of new plastic. 

Also, three tier stackable recycling bins for inside our two (2) SKC student dorms, all family housing units, as well as outside in the family housing parking lots, and for the last step of sorting the collection of #1 - #10 plastics.

SKC says Thank you!

We appreciate our donors, not only are you helping the environment, you are sustaining recycling for generations to come at the Salish Kootenai College, as we charge into the future!

Your donation will receive a customized perk with Rez-cyclers Logo. 

  Personalized with recycling logo:

  Tier 1         Shout out on Facebook: when donating $5

  Tier 2        Decal/Sticker: when donating $25

  Tier 3        Shirt: when donating $50

  Tier 4        Hydro Flask: when donating $100

  Tier 5        Desk bin with campaign logo: when donating $500

  Tier 6        Native American beaded item: when donating $1,000

 

Where do the funds go if we do not reach our goal?

Our first priority for any funding gained through Rez-cycling’s campaign will go towards the purchasing of recycling bins for collection and sorting efforts.

Reaching our first target goal for the recycling campaign is at SKC student dorms & family housing units by having accessible bins within the area for on-campus students. However, if the target goal isn’t met, the funds will be used towards marketing materials that provide educational awareness on how to properly recycle plastic items.

The Impact

Your donation today will kick-start an extensive first-ever recycling program for SKC campus student family housing. Salish Kootenai College is located on the Flathead Indian Reservation, approximately 1,317,000 acres. In addition, the efforts from your donation will help carryon the project with the community around SKC and sustain recycling efforts for generations to come. This is an opportunity of a lifetime, for students to be able to finally start recycling, by donors like you, who provide resources students need. 

The impact of this project is extensive. Since, we are starting up a recycling program for the Salish Kootenai College Student Housing, we are raising money to create an opportunity to expand around the SKC community to make a difference in the lives of our community and the communities of the students they go home to after college.

Rez-cycling Objectives:

  • Raise money through the Indiegogo campaign for the SKC Student housing and dormitories and overall campus.
  • Raise awareness to create a better understanding of 'how to recycle'.
  • Your donations will help us provide recycling bins to all students who live in the SKC Dormitories & Family Units.
  • Your donation will help donors with good quality Rez-Cyclying merchandise. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The #1 risk is starting this campaign so that we can eventually transition with other recycling projects on the Flathead Indian Reservation and Lake County. We anticipate to take on every internal and external obstacle to implement such a huge change within only 7 weeks of student planning. 

Our biggest challenge here is, we need the final funding to execute our campaign. Our campus is overflowing with eager students who want to recycle; however, our campus is 128 acres: students need recycling bins. 

The risks and challenges of accomplishing our goals are being able to raise enough funds to get equipment. Our number one priority is the equipment.  The equipment provides the resources to continue our goal of recycling. 

Why recycle?

We are overcoming pollution and waste through innovation and promotional efforts. The risk we face is that our efforts may be in vain. We are exploring avenues of effectiveness in our endeavors. We are currently sourcing departments within our college community. We are also coming up with innovative ways to utilize plastics.

We are brainstorming and constantly researching and looking into new ways of utilizing recycled materials. One of the ways we are considering is 3D printing recyclable materials. We are communicating with the community, promoting awareness as well as providing points of access to recycle waste materials. We would like to become a part of a global organization to share ideas as well as become a part of a movement, a global effort to nurture this world we care about so dearly. We would like your help to make a better recycling environment.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Our main goal is to create a recycling environment on the SKC campus, but that does not mean that we don’t want to grow and expand outside of just the College.

Rez-Cycling wants to spread awareness throughout the area so that we can influence our fellow community members to join us in creating a healthier environment.

Here is how you can help us to bring awareness towards recycling!

Share our link: 

Educational links:

  • https://www.preciousplastic-usa.com
  • https://earth911.com
